description:
A decent and cheap fast-Korean spot in Westfield Mall that achieves what it sets out to do. This place is not fine dining. But for a Korean spot in a food court, Sorabol is actually quite good. 

Sorabol is located on the ground floor of Westfield. There are many Asian fast food spots within the mall, many of which are right next to Sorabol, so it faces stiff competition from other vendors. I was intrigued by this spot from the start because you don't see Korean fast food too often. The line at this place was also noticeably longer than others.

The "plates" are cheap and filling. I got the Lemon Chicken plate. It came with rice, Korean noodles, kimchi, broccoli, and a large portion of chicken. While decent, the lemon chicken did not strike me as authentic. It actually reminded me of the orange chicken they serve at Panda Express. Next time upgrading for $1 to the bulgogi or spicy pork is probably worth it.

Pro tip: when they ask you if you're eating there or taking the food to go, say you're taking it to go. They will use a plate if you're eating there, and a  plastic food container if you're taking it to go. The latter will give you  1.25x - 1.50x more quantity.
author: Chris W.

description:
Omg the coconut shrimp they gave us was completely raw. Be careful what you order. 

I didn't even get an apology for the raw shrimp but they did give me a new plate.  They transfer my beef from my old plate to the new one and put the serving tongs back on the counter. 

Not very sanitary and the food was definitely not worth it for the price. You are better off going to another restaurant unless you want food poisoning at his place.
author: Hong P.

description:
What can you expect from mall food? 

Portions are okay and taste is laking. 

I had a problem with the attitude of the staff. Tried to get a manager. Was told her name was teresa or theresa. She never came out. I asked for a call back. Still waiting. Rude staff and probably not a caring manager. Maybe it was not the staff- maybe that's how the managers train. 

Many other options nowadays. Go somewhere else unless you want cheap eats.
author: Jayden R.

description:
This place is actually really impressive for a food court. If someone told me this was an actual Korean restaurant, I would believe them. Firstly, the portion sizes are CRAZY. Crazy big. I have a huge appetite, and this absolutely makes me stuffed. I have gotten the Spicy BBQ Chicken and the Bulgogi. They both come with rice, broccoli, noodles, and kimchi. 

Spicy BBQ Chicken- Super spicy and super flavorful. Even though the chicken may be a little dry, it still tastes amazing. The flavor is amazing. It is actually pretty spicy, so get your water ready! 

Bulgogi- Super tender and delicious. You can absolutely taste the flavors that the meat marinated in. This isn't spicy, so if you can't stand the spice, this is an awesome choice that won't disappoint.

Overall, I would come here again and recommend this to everyone.
author: Felicia C.

description:
Overall, this place is good enough for a food court.  Generous portions of meat whose excessive seasoning compensates for the fact that it's being scooped to order (instead of cooked to order).  It is fine for a quick fix.

BBQ Short Rib: It's no wonder these are priced at a premium, they're one of the tastier items offered.  Like something you'd get at a Korean BBQ joint, except if it spent 30 minutes under a heat lamp after being cooked.  Same great taste, but some of the fresh-off-the-grill crispiness was missing.

Bulgogie Beef: Huge portion of medium-thin meat heavy on the marinade.  I'm used to bulgogi being thinner and more seared, but the marinade and well-done cooking made it good enough for a food court approximation.

Noodles: Didn't waste my time on the rice and went full-on on japchae.  Might as well get a type of noodle not offered by the other Asian food court stands.  Tasty enough.
author: Adam B.

description: This Earhart is located within Westfield San Francisco Center's Emporium, and is actually very decent for a food-court type setting. what brought be to their line is their pricing. I got probably the most basic plate with bbq chicken, rice, noodles and broccoli. It was really good, however it's definitely not like authentic k-bbq. My order came out to $9, and was pretty satisfied with what I got. The servers were actually impatient and rude (-1 Star). Overall, good choice compared to other options !
author: Marc R.

description:
Overpriced for the quality of the food. The meats used were not that good; they were on the coarse and chewy side. I ordered a combo meats plate because everything looked so good, I wanted to try more. The meats ended up way too salty. The japchae was dripping in oil. It was tasty japchae, but just too much oil. It's a pretty difficult meal to swallow. You'd need a lot of water to go with this. I purchased an aloe drink, but that was not enough.

It's a system where you go down the line and point at what you want. At the end, I was asked whether I wanted kimchi or not. Of course I did. At that same place where the kimchi was at, they have a whole section of banchan that was completely full and untouched. Strange.

I asked if I was able to get some banchan and the guy shook his head and said, "No." So I asked, "Really? Then what is the banchan for?" He shook his head some more. I asked, "What can I order on the menu that I can get some banchan?" He shook his head and passed my order to the lady to his right. I added in a final, "Can I purchase banchan as a side?" He ignored me and moved on to the next person. Seriously? Why have banchan on display if you're not going to sell it? If you're too cheap to give it for free like normal Korean places, then sell it. I was willing to pay and even offered. So ridiculous. Are you just going to leave the banchan to go to waste?

The lady wrapped up my order, totaled it up, and was passing it to the cashier. I had to stop her and say, "Uhh, I actually want an aloe drink, too." She made a frustrated sound, grabbed an aloe, threw it on my tray and passed it to the cashier. Do ya'll not want to make money here? Wtf.
author: Jasmine P.

description: . The food that I ordered was ok. I ordered bibimbap but it didn't even tasted and looked like one . Their potstickers didn't have much flavor to it and the wrap was too thick. Tempura was mehhh and not crispy at all. That's all.
author: Kim D.

description:
Summary: Good deal for food if you want to catch a quick bite before the movies. 

This restaurant is located in the food court of the Metreon theatre. This place definitely make me full for under $15 bucks.

However, the korean food is so-so. It just feels like Panda Express with kimchi or a ton of gochujang sauce.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 3.5/5
Ambiance: 2.5/5
Overall: a good staple of a meal when you want something quick and easy.

The extended review...

Food: 

Bbq chicken entree - pretty tasty.  The chicken is pretty ample in portion and it comes with jap chae (yam noodles) and rice.   Plenty to make you full and satisfied.

Service: decent service for a cafeteria style place.

Ambiance: In normal malls it would be ok but this is the Westfield in downtown sf which is a mess in ur own.  Typically there will be pan handlers walking around and asking for money while you are eating.  This makes for a WONDERFUL experience...
author: Spencer Q.

description: Busy location. I got the bulgogi beef, glass noodles and veggies. Was all right.
author: Sunil R.

description:
This place is located within the Westfield Mall food court, and quite frankly it is not good. I would go as far to say as it was pretty bad. There was quite a line when I went so I was surprised the quality was below what I expected.

I ordered the bibimbap which was $9, and while the menu says you can add any meat and the total would be $10, they actually charge you for two separate orders if you choose galbi ($9 + $3 = $12), and you only get one slice!

The bibimbap that they display is a poor imitation of what you actually get, since the version on display looks way better than the actual product, and I had a lady in front of me who complained that she only got one tiny slice of chicken when the display model had multiple chicken pieces.

The toppings on top weren't all that good either, it just seemed like a hogwash of random pickled items, rather than the good variety you normally get with a good bibimbap. They also barely gave you any of the sweet chili sauce that normally comes with the dish.

Overall it was just one big disappointment.
author: Tyler T.

description: Okay, even though this is fast food this place really hits the spot when you're famished after a long day of shopping and are craving Korean-esque food. It's not authentic enough to call it Korean but it's still very tasty and good quality. The prices are fair for what you get and you can design your bowl or plate to include the things you want. The service is what you would expect from a mall court restaurant. I always get a chicken bowl with cellophane noodlesThe best thing is that they offer kimchi.
author: L. L.

description: Its about what you would expect for food court Korean food.  Kalbi was ok... You get 3 strips... Not sort tender but it's the food court.  The Kalbi at the metreon food court is much better.
author: William L.

description: Yuck. Cheap meat, cold veggie and really, really greasy. Would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Anne S.

description: Food was okay and decent portions of most things, but the staff were fairly rude; they gave me an incredibly small portion of kimchi and when I asked if I could have slightly more (they seriously gave me half a tablespoon), they told me I was welcome to buy kimchi for $2. The woman at the cashier also made some joke about how I must not live in San Francisco since I wasn't sure if they charge for bags. Overall quite rude people and I would be hesitant to return.
author: Steve A.

description:
I like the Spicy Beef Soup with either rice noodles are white sticky rice. The bbq chicken and spicy pork is also good (from the grill) but the low score is for the quality of Sorabol not improving over the years whilst the prices have gone up & portions seem to have become smaller. 

The staff here are super stingy. I have seen them be quite rude to customers who request more of something or want to customise their food.

They've are always shocked as if I'm asking for extra when I want broccoli with my soup & when I dare ask for some kimchi. The kimchi used to be self serve! The portion of kimchi they give is too funny to believe it's so tiny!

Also what is the point of having the pickled veg if they don't serve it with the food. If you ask for pickled veg the first thing they say is that it's going to cost you extra. 

I wish they'd just serve me what I want & make me happy with no argument, after all I am a paying customer. Sometimes I just avoid coming to Sorabol now.
author: Julian I.

description:
I ordered the beef stew and had the worst beef I have ever tried in San Francisco. It was so inedible I barely took two bites. 

The bad appearance of the soup did not prepare me to try food I wouldn't give to a dog on the street. They have no shame, and will never choose them over coriander that's right next to it and doesn't give customers such terrible food. 

Stay away.
author: Gabriel B.

description:
One of my go-to's in the Westfield food court! Yummy, quick, and filling! 

Japchae- My favorite part. Consistent glass noodles, overall delicious!

Bulgogi- decent amount with a tasty marinade! 

Overall it's a good portion size and one of the better buys in he Westfield food court!
author: Jessica W.

description:
I ordered their 2 entree plate with only noodles, with lemon chicken, and crispy chicken. I got the bottom of what was left for the lemon chicken. While the server was scooping the chicken, there a new fresh batch of the same chicken that someone else had just brought out. I wish he had given me the fresh and not the on sitting on the bottom. But he had already scooped the chicken into the container before the new batch arrived so I didn't say anything.

Both of the crispy and lemon chicken tasted old and was tough to chew. It was not soft on the inside and not crispy on the outside like it should be if it were relatively freshly prepared/cooked. Panda express orange chicken is way better than this. The noodles were standard and typical. Nothing wrong with them.

Maybe I went on an off day but I probably won't be coming back if the chicken doesn't even taste like it was cooked recently.
author: Shaina D.

description: The food here is good and fresh! Way better than the location down the street. I gave them a 1. I would recommend this place. Loved the fresh veggies and the ribs are amazing!
author: Sean V.

description: Found mouse fecies in my rice. And i know its mouse fecies cause i had one as a pet. Never coming back... and i suggest you never risk to try...
author: Mangirdas R.

description: Fast food in this high end mall really makes me angry. The noodles they use in noodles soup menu is just the noodles from a ramen noodle soup from  a cheap packet. And they explain,,that's how it is. What??? ...
author: Fe Y.

description: About to finish my food look what i found in my food perfect extra food haha , I found a piece of hair in my food .
author: Linda M.

description: I really used to like this sorabol compared to the locations at stonestown and at the Westfield food court. However they have really cut down on the portions! Seriously, I paid $8+ for just a few skimpy pieces of chicken ? When I got it I felt ripped off. Even the closest chipotle looked like it gave more. This will be last time I come here sad to say.
author: Ryan T.

description: I am writing this as a public service. I ordered the noodles with salted fish. The tiny fish dropped into the sliced lemons. The server put down her thongs and used her bare hands to pick the fishes that fell into the lemons. I mentioned this to the manager and she said I can fix you another plate. How would that help if the entire tray of fish is contaminated? Health Department if you are reading this, you need to monitor this place and make it sa
author: Sherlyn C.

description:
I came here after a long day. There was a short line when u arrived but they serve you quickly. 
I ordered the BBQ chicken and potstickers which comes with rice, Jap chae and broccoli. Food was good, but not amazing. You get huge portions for the price. So that usually means leftovers for the next day. 
Overall, food was decent for the price you pay. Food is filling and satisfying.
author: Goku U.

description: I'm working in Westfield mall for a long time and you have a big options to buy a lunch (in case, if you don't have enough time for cooking for yourself). I try eating a healthy food and this location is not so bad. The vegetable bowl with a beef is my favorite dish here. Their portions are huge !!! Nice price policy. Sometimes it can be crowded, but it's okay. Friendly stuff.
author: Norton W.

description:
There used to be a Sorabol Korean restaurant at Great Mall @ Milpitas, we loved the california roll and BBQ chicken there. The rice was the best we've ever had in bay area. They've also very generous in portions. When they serve BBQ chicken or short ribs, they used a food scissors to cut the big chunk for you.

This one is totally different: the first thing I noticed was that, there was no clear price, the server in this Sorabol was very stingy, even when adding kimchi and broccoli. They didn't cut the BBQ chicken for you either.
Finally, there was no california rolls! what a disappointment.

The food was eatable, BBQ was a bit dry.
author: majia m.

description:
Nope nope and nope. 

First nope to customer service, was rushed through the line. 

Second nope to the food, bland. I loved Korean food, lived with Korean roommates. Know authentic Korean food. Their jap chae lack flavor, and I think they used kale in it, ughhh nope! Real Korean jap Chae use spinach, try again! Beef bulogi is no, meat is tastes like ground beef,. Steam vegetable, came with 3 broccoli and baby carrots lol really? Well can I at least get it steamed instead of raw? It's so hard!!! Carrot was not sweet like come on yo how can ur baby carrot be bland?

Third nope to the price. Got the 2 item combo, came with ONE short ribs and small amount of rice... omg really? Bill was $14.05 after tax... Noooooooo!!! And everything cost, ask for a little more noodles, it's going to cost $4, a small dab so ban chan, it will cost $3.... what doesn't cost? Oh yeah your attitude 

Heck no.
author: Kris J.

description: I have been here before and it's better thann what i served today. Food is kind of too much sugar and their service also sucks. I was thought that people get a long line then they are supposed to be good but actually they don't. Don't go wrong guys their food was bad. I paid $11 for this plate. Not much but their food was bad even I was so hungry at that time.
author: Đng T.

description:
The one saving grace for this place is their black bean noodles.  The texture of the noodles is al dente and a delight to eat, but I wish they had seafood with their sauce.  The rest of the food is average, but this is the only reason I keep coming back even if the sauce is served in a box, which is bound to make a mess from leaking, in the box without a sealed container.

The staff is friendly especially if you're Korean, but I wish they would be a bit more generous with napkins.  When sauce is dripping everywhere from a container, you don't want to put it on the 2 napkins that the customer needs to wipe their mouth and/or hands.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This food sucked. I pretty much threw it out without eating much because it was so bad. 

I should have checked the Yelp review before ordering. Somehow Yelpers always get it right! It's 3 stars for a reason. It sucks. 

I waited over 10 minutes for my soup to arrive, by which time my dining partner had already finished his food bought elsewhere and was ready to leave. So much for fast food. 

I had no idea a beef soup would take so long. If they'd bothered to ask me whether the wait was OK (or just written words to that effect on the menu!) I would have been thankful and said no. 

After the long wait when I was just standing there getting more and more annoyed with no information or not knowing whether they'd forgotten my order, I tucked in to the bowl of soup. It was really horrible. 

Gristle-laden beef, loads of broth with not much in it. I don't even remember what was in it because I pretty much left it after eating a couple of mouthfuls. 

Ugh. 

Avoid this place at all costs.
author: Zoe L.

description:
You know you're not in for an authentic experience but for something tasty and relatively cheap in SF rents it's not bad.  My fell safe on judging a place is if there is a line, which there was and it included lots of Asian folks in line for a rice place which is always a good sign.

Located in Westfield's basement food court it's also easy to get to. Exit Powell BART, go left and you're there.  The hardest part is avoiding all the yummy junk food, I had to drag myself away from the hot cookies at the market.  

Thank goodness I asked to sample the short rib stew before selecting it because it was sweet - what the?!?! PASS!  

Based on my reaction, the lady dishing up the food from their hot plate options steered me toward the spicy pork which was a play on words because it wasn't spicy and the spicy beef which had a nice slow roasted flavor with a kick of spice.  I had the lady put some of the sauce on my rice, with the kimchi it was tasty.

We're talking cheap quality meat and barely luke warm food but I grubbed and have plenty for lunch tomorrow.  Veggies are great, steamed to just done with a crunch to them.  

I was sitting among a group of other folks who had their food and their noodles looked the best, it was made to order and served hot, next time I'll try that but it's hard when you're going for Korean and the food you get can pass for Chinese.

Even more impressive an Asian girl half my size polished off her entire container of food WITH some Chinese sticky rice that was wrapped in banana leaves.
author: Ann T.

description:
I was a big fan of their korean noodles and used to come here lot. However, everything seem pretty disappointing now. The noodle does not taste as good as it used to be any more. It's so soft now and it breaks easily. I don't know if it's because they changed to some other brand of noodles or it's becuase thier chef is different. 

Also their spicy chicken and spicy pork are not as spicy any more. I still remember the first time I came and they spicy the crap out of me (I enjoyed it tho). 

Will check out other food at the food court when I shop in westfield next time.
author: Hazel B.

description:
I am a fan of the Food Court in the basement of the San Francisco Centre.

I tend to lean more toward the Korean restaurant "Sorabol." For a two item combo at $11.88 tax included.

Often I have the Spicy BBQ Chicken & the Spicy Pork with half rice and half noodle. 

Note: their quality of food is not at all consistent. More often than not, the chicken is good except when it is horribly overcooked or just plain cold.  Also, they should but they do not always ask you if you would like the included vegetable/broccoli or the kimchi. And, the self service water is no longer available thus, one must for a cup of tap water.

My friends and I are not big eaters so for the price we are content sharing just this one decent sized combo.
author: Caesar A.

description:
This is food court food!? I never physically came to this place before, so I'm so surprised it's from a food court, because I think the food is great! I'm not sure if it is super authentic Korean food, but it's tasty!

My go to is the Spicy BBQ Chicken ($8.95) with rice and japchae. I love the sauce they put on the chicken, because it has a hint of kimchi flavor, sweet and spicy. The rice is a great addition to soak up all of that sauce. Sometimes the chicken is kind of dry, but the flavor really penetrates the whole chicken. Japchae is pretty good. Also the portion sizes are huge! The whole to-go box is basically packed with food. Most of the time I can eat this with another person and we would both be full.

Overall, love the food here! I think it's just Asian, you can't really classify it as strictly Korean. Awesome food court food! Really fills you up.
author: Vivienne C.

description: Chicken has way too much breading and it's really hard as well. You're better off going to Panda, also the broccoli is very hard too. The only decent item off the menu was their spicy chicken but wouldn't say it was all that great.
author: Peter S.

description:
Ah, that mall food court life. In comparison to the other food court options, Sorabol usually has a longer lunch line. Wut da kimchi, lem'me give it a try. 

I got an entree for $8.95 (one of the cheaper options). Let's deconstruct it- 
- Choice of meat: I got bbq chicken. Large portion of 3 skinless chicken thighs. 
- Rice: white or brown (and no extra charge for trying to be healthy) 
- Jap Chae Noodles: very oily, yeesh-ka-beesh
- Steamed Vegetables: a few pieces of broccoli
- Kimchi: Of da cabbage variety

Overall, huge portion and decent from a food court. They also offer other options- soups, bim bim bop, etc. You can get a good portioned meal for around $10. 

Afterwards my stomach had that "Ergh, i ate my weekly dosage of msg-infused, oily take-out food" feel. It lasted for a good 4 hours. I'm not craving to come back, but it did the trick for a quick lunch.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Pretty good Korean food within the mall! Pricing isn't exceptionally bad.

Also the portion sizes are easily splittable!
author: James D.

description:
I always come here for my lunch shopping break when I shop at Westfield mall. The food is affordable, portions are large, and the food is pretty tasty for mall food. The BBQ chicken is sweet and tender and comes with 3 grilled thighs! The japchae noodles as a side are my ultimate favorite because the dish is very well seasoned and is mixed with vegetables. I also got the soft tofu stew with seafood which was okay. The stew wasn't as hot as I would like and the soft tofu was already shredded into small pieces. I usually like to break up the tofu myself.
Overall I'd definitely make a point to come here versus the other options in the Westfield mall food court.
author: Hillary C.

description:
One Saturday, the other half and I ended up at the Westfield Mall food court, in search of a quick lunch.  After perusing the entire selection of eateries, we joined the masses in the Sorabol line.  This place seemed the most popular probably because the portions were huge and seemed like less of a ripoff than the other places.  

Turns out, the food was much better than we expected.  I ordered a chicken bibimbap which was filled with all sorts of veggies, picked veggies and chicken thigh meat.  The other half ordered the kalbi beef rice plate which also came with some banchan side including vermicelli noodles.  Not super authentic Korean cuisine, but food was decent.  We spent under $25 for the two of us and were stuffed.  Not bad for a tourist trap.
author: Liv A.

description: They literally violate food safety standards one an hour. Food made me feel sick. So sad
author: Steven B.

description:
There's always a long line at this place and I can see why. The food is very worth it to me, especially the bibimbap (which I order pretty much every other time I go). It's very cheap, but it's very delicious and filling at the same time with plenty of vegetables for you to eat. Sometimes, there is a lot of oil used in the dishes, but it's reasonable since sesame oil is very important in Korean dishes. It almost never feels like they're cutting you short on portions of the vegetables or the meat, so I highly recommend it if you're looking for something to eat in the Westfield mall.

In the end though, it's pretty much tradition for me and my family to stop by here and grab a bite to eat before we start exploring SF!
author: Renneth D.

description:
i have been coming here irregularly for a long time. Bascially every time I shop at west field and I feel hundry, the first thing come into my mind is this place. Their portion is huge. I can totally eat half and save half for the next meal ;) 

I normally order their 2 items option. You can choose to have rice or noodle with it. Their rice are just...rice, plain and that's it. Nothing to brag about or nothing bad about it. However their noodles are SO GOOD! It's soft and tasty. So now i bascially ask them to replace my rice with noodle. 

I like their spicy chicken/pork a lot too. Maybe too spicy for you if you don't eat spicy. You can choose one spicy item and one non spicy item to balance it out. 

Love this spot! I guess their lines are long for a reason.
author: Gerald J.

description: I got a tempura rice noodle soup to go.  The soup tastes like MSG favored.  The noodles and tempuras were fine.  The order came in 3 packages, the bowl with soup base was super, I nearly burned my hands.  When I asked for a carrying bag, they said it cost $0.10.  They could have told me when I paid for the order.  I don't usually carry cash. Luckily I found a quarter after digging in my purse.
author: Stella S.

description: Food was colder then the ice age , it was like eating ice cubes with seasoning on BD foe.
author: Ike J.

description:
Okay so you're at a mall in San Francisco and you want to eat lunch or dinner. Fast food is not an option and anywhere else you go near union square will either have a long wait or cost a gazillion dollars,  so you come to the food court. 

This is a pretty good place,  it's a line that you go up in and order the type of meat you want.  It all comes with white or Brown rice,  stir fried noodles,  and vegetables. You can also order multiple items and get a combo deal.  They don't have fountain drinks,  but they have bottled water and canned sodas. You can't go wrong worth the barbecue chicken which is very good for mall food.  I also like the lemon chicken. Their ribs are also pretty darn good. There are a ton of seats as well,  cafeteria seating so enjoy. 

Again,  if you're wanting to have a 5 star experience,  don't come to the mall,  but otherwise this place is very decent.
author: Arman J.

description:
When I was a teenager, I remember being kind of annoyed when a classmate told me that he decided he didn't like Filipino food after eating at... Goldilocks.  

That said, I would not write off Korean food just because you had something you didn't quite like at Sorabol Korean Restaurant.

While I have yet to fulfill my K-Drama induced dream of visiting Korea, teaching English, and somehow crossing paths with a chaebol who looks like a K-Pop star, I can get my fix of japchae by hitting up the Westfield San Francisco Centre.  Don't be intimidated by the lunch rush line.  The team behind the counter know how to keep it movin'.

Here's what I got -  

BBQ Beef - 9.25 (all japchae) 

Normally the lunch plates come with a scoop of rice and a scoop of japchae, but I'm a noodles over rice kinda gal so I asked and received.  It's kind of Chipotle-esque the way they pass your plate down the line, each person handling one item.  When my clear, biodegradable clamshell made it all the way down to the end, I got kind of excited at the thought that I would get to pick any number of ban chan.  Notice I said "Chipotle-ESQUE."  :(  I guess it's only for the people who get bibimbap.  Makes sense.  Whatever.  Over it.  The woman at the end did motion to the large container of kimchi and steamed broccoli - to which I nodded an enthusiastic yes.

Find out from the cashier that they don't take Discover.  Whatever.  Not the end of the world.  Handed her my "It's everywhere you want to be" Visa card, grabbed some utensils, and headed to Pacific Puffs to grab a snack for the BART ride back to the office (that's Powell to Embarcadero... it lasted to Montgomery).   

Under/around $10/person lunches (that aren't sandwiches) are kinda hard to find in the FiDi (unless I've just been looking in all the wrong places).  For a good price, Sorabol will fill you up for sure.  I ate about half for lunch and then the other half for dinner since I had to work late - perfect!  I used to love going to the Sorabol in New Park Mall when I was a tween.  Brings back good memories.  :)
author: Iona C.

description:
This place use to be a staple of people who work downtown. Idk where something went wrong but it has just gone downhill. They use to have generous serving of the food now it barely fills the plate. The broccoli taste like soap and the kimchi is now slimy.
They are really cutting corners.
author: clark b.

description: Food was very cold and has no taste. Service is bad. They should be more inviting when you walk up to ask them what they recommend because you are a new customer..
author: Valeria R.

description:
A few weeks ago I was pining away for some Westfield food court fare but those I was with nixed the idea in favor of someplace that was approximately one million times more expensive.  This time, nobody cock-blocked me but perhaps someone should have.  Sorabol is not quite "horabal" (say it aloud) but it seems to be well on its way.

What happened?  When did Sorabol jump the shark?  

I once recommended this Sorabol over the one in Yerba Buena Center but now I'd not recommend either.  The BBQ Chicken Plate ($8.95), while cheap and ample, was a sea of mediocrity.  Sorabol seems to be trading in inferior product produced without care and with little regards to taste.  And they've become so miserly stingy with their kimchi - the one thing that could've rescued this meal - that it almost made me laugh.  Almost.

What Sorabol lacked in Kimchi generosity they more than made up for with the rest of the platter.  White rice was supplemented with a mound of cellphane yam noodles, a stack of icy cold (why icy cold?) broccoli and carrots, and a ridiculously large portion of something they called BBQ chicken.  This was like the old trope "it wasn't very good but there sure was a lot of it".  The serving of chicken was far more than I've ever received in past visits but it tasted like anything but BBQ.  No char marks and absolutely nothing special about it.  The same could be said about the rest of the plate's ingredients.

Sorabol received a 74/100 on their most recent Health Department inspection.  That score isn't enough to send me running but it's poor enough to remind of a similar score at another once-decent-now-gone place.  It just feels like they've given up trying to produce good food with quality ingredients.  There was a muddled lack of flavor to the whole meal.  

I'm not kidding when I say that a reasonable sized serving of kimchi could've worked miracles here.  Westfield's food court is big and I'd not sat anywhere near Sorabol.  By the time I realized how little kimchi I'd been given I opted not to go back and beg for more.  What I was left with was dry, meek, and uninteresting.

If you insist on coming to Sorabol I won't try to dissuade you but I will warn you:  as you move through that line pay careful attention to the kimchi portion and then keep saying "more please" until you can envision yourself being satisfied.  It'll probably take quite a lot to achieve.
author: Tracey A.

description: I have been coming here for about a decade.   For some reason, this location has decreased the size of its portions.
author: Joshua W.

description: This restaurant is mediocre at best. I give the spicy wonton soup a 2/10 and their rice plate with lemon chicken and wontons a 4/10.. it was pretty expensive as far as mall food goes so I was expecting more. I have to say I'm pretty damn disappointed.
author: Katie F.

description:
Twas okay. You get a lot of food for a good price. It is not the best Korean food I've eaten, its eh. It's decent foodcourt food. The service was fast, and the staff was nice. One order is more than enough to share between 2 or 3 people. 

I am not sure that I would go back. I am not totally against it either.
author: Ursula T.

description: I usually like my meal at Sorabol, but today it was off. I got BBQ chicken and the chicken was not fresh and juicy...instead it was hard and dry chicken. Also, the kimchi serving was too small. I asked for some more and she didn't give me very much. I think I'll try a different restaurant at the Westfield downtown food court. Buckhorn, Thai, Greek--next time?
author: Denise C.

description:
Yes it's in a mall food court but once you get past that this place is underrated! Nothing gourmet but a nice filling lunch to keep you going in your day. 

Got the entree plate with tofu stew, veggies, kimchi and half rice half japchae. Tofu stew was flavorful and veggies (mostly broccoli) were tasty, though japchae was a bit stiff. Portion sizes were great, will fill you up for around $10.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Food tasted like cardboard. The crispy chicken was so dry I could hardly choke it down. I highly recommend finding a different restaurant. Maybe a place that cares about flavor??
author: Asa H.

description:
For the amount of business that Sorabol is doing, how do they not have more reviews?

As a self appointed Korean food expert, here is my take on this location.  

All dishes come with white rice and japchae and only two banchan.  

The japchae is good, but a little salty. 
The bulgogi is tender and a good.  I wish that it wasn't so wet.  
The kimchi is not good.  Too fresh and missing the umami salty fish sauce taste.  It is just bland. 

This is my first experience with fast food Korean.  If I could do it all over again, I would probably pass. 

What did I learn today? This definitely did not satiate my Korean food craving.
author: Ryan C.

description:
It's interesting that Sorabol gets a lot of low reviews. That's not to be unexpected when you're dealing with food court culture in a mall. And my review today may not have been  any different. But instead of ordering what the majority of the folks ordered, I ordered the fried rice with kimchi and spicy chicken. Now, normally this dish is not made with the spicy chicken, but they did it for me. 

I have to tell you, that was some of the best fried rice I've ever had. The spicy sauce from the chicken, along with kimchi really added great flavor to the rice. The other thing to note here is that this dish is somewhat custom and has to be prepared. So you have to wait about 8-10 minutes. I think this add to the distinction of this dish versus the standard orders that most people place. Looking at the picture I posted, you can tell the rice is tasty.

Now for sure, when I go back to order this dish, I'll make sure the sweet lady who fried this dish for me is there.
author: Anthony W.

description:
BBQ Short Ribs (Kal-Bi) are a lunch favorite for me. The line was shorter here than many of the other restaurants in the food court. Maybe that was a clue? I've had these ribs many times from Sorabol at other malls and they have varied in taste and quality.  The menu describes this wonderful dish as thinly sliced L.A. style short ribs. I had never read or heard that before.

Unlike the now closed location at Sun Valley in Concord, where they were cooked to order, these ribs sat in a container on the steam table. One of ribs was very tender and favorable and the other was dry and tough. I was disappointed, however, that will not stop me from trying this location again.
author: Terry T.

description:
My white friend chose this place. I'll just start my review with that. Generally I refrain from accepting advice from my fellow Caucasians unless I'm inquiring about certain really specific things. Top 40 music. Toyota Priuses. Inexpensive beard wax. Gardening tips. 

But on this particular day with this particular friend, he knew that my preferences, culinarily, lean toward the east, and as luck would have it, we were in the process of returning some dress slacks at Banana Republic (told you he was white), so down to the food court we went, in search of some quick sustenance to quell our rumbling bellies.

He cautioned me thrice about the lack of authenticism of food-court Korean food. He accused me of an innate bias against mall food. He assumed I would write a Yelp review about it that same day. Joke's on him, that was two days ago, thanks very much. I've been busy.

So, at the risk of cutting off my boobs to spite my chest... it was a pretty decent food court meal. Legit. The beef galbi was appropriately chewy, flavorful, and hot. The noodles were savory and delicate. The BBQ pork, while not award-winning, was definitely better than I expected from a place that was serving from an aluminum pan.

Best Korean food in the Bay Area? Don't be ridic. But you'd be hard-pressed to find better food in a mall. Just careful with that hot sauce. It's hard to get stains out of merino wool, you know.
author: Sean B.

description:
Sorabol is like the Korean Panda Express except Sorabol portions are gigantic

+BBQ chicken
+korean potato starch noodles
+shredded beef

big portions of delicious grilled korean food for $10, come & get it boys and girls!
author: Philip M.

description:
This place always has a line, so I figured it was a good sign. I ordered the spicy pork plate, but unfortunately they were out and it would have been another 15 minutes until there was more. 1 star off for that. I got the beef instead and the guy gave me a good portion of meat, along with white rice, glass noodles, steamed broccoli and a spoonful of kim chee. The guy serving me was really nice too.

The line went fast and my food was fresh and filling. I would go back again if I was hungry for Korean bbq and in the area.
author: Mel L.

description:
The Japchae (glass noodles) is great even if the beef bulgogi is quite oily. Generous amount of meat. Yay! Haha
Bibimbap is also decent. I came back for the glass noodles though. Not bad.
author: Christina O.

description:
My take on this Korean cafeteria - like restaurant was overall pretty decent. It was enormously crazy busy yesterday due to the victory Giants celebration parade that let out the same time we reached here:( They were very efficient in taking our orders and ringing us up. They do take credit cards if you don't carry much cash.

Because of that situation we had to bring the food back to hotel to eat. The tables there were all taken up by people from the celebration. And it was jam packed!!!

We all ordered pretty much the same. Korean shortrib,
BBQ chicken, broccoli, rice and japchae. My HB did ask for Kim chee too. That actually made the food tasty. I loved the japchae which is this clear tan color noodle with green onion and sliced carrots. The shortrib tasted good but better to eat it right away or it's cold. It was a bit gristly. The BBQ chicken was not really too flavorful. Maybe better to get the spicy chicken?  I can't really handle too spicy foods so I didn't want to take a chance. Maybe next time as the Kim Chee wasn't too spicy. 

We'll see if there's a next time as we usually don't come out this way unless there's a reason.
author: Karen K.

description:
A long time ago I got a plate with the normal sides and I think it was the BBQ chicken as the main.  Everything on the plate was so cloyingly sweet that I couldn't eat it.  Since then, I gave it a try one more time out of desperation and it was better, but still not good.  They need to calm down on the sweetness of their food.  Their potstickers are heard and thick and flavorless.

The item to get here, though, is the stir fry noodles with either chicken or shrimp.  I order shrimp.  Sometimes they use a handful of small-medium shrimp (peeled with no tails) and sometimes they use 4 or 5 medium, tail-on shrimp.  Great value at like $9-something and it's made fresh instead of scooped from a steam table so it's nice and hot.  You order it and pay and then a few minutes later they scream "stir fry nood-oh!". So, if you must eat here, get that, but note that sometimes they are really heavy-handed on the oil.
author: Emma H.

description:
I was having a mad craving for rice and this placed help settle that craving.  I decided to get the lemon chicken as my food item.  The plate came with a decent amount of rice and noodles.  It also came with kimchi and vegetables. I asked the lady for some extra kimchi She literally gives me like 2 extra pieces of cabbage.  

The food was mediocre, much better places in the mall and better priced.  The lemon chicken I had was dry and flavorless.  I will say the rice was fresh and was the best part of the meal.
author: Stephen O.

description:
Korean food can be heavily meat-oriented on the plate. In fact, BBQ meats prepared at the table over coals are often found in Korean restaurants.
That's why yesterday @ Sorabbol, a dish with a rainbow of color caught my eye &, given the humidity of the day, I decided to go with this hot & cold dish.
As I watched the woman assemble the plate, I got to choose brown or white rice; cellophane noodles or not; then the plate went to her neighbor who proceeded to arrange marinated cucumber slices, cabbage, grated carrots, bean sprouts, mushrooms, yellow daikon,etc. It was beautiful to see!
I could also choose to keep the dish vegetarian or add BBQ meat, so I chose beef.
For $9.95 this was a really good deal! After my first few bites, I was so happy ;0)
I was eating healthy, had a really good balance between veggies, meat & carb.
And there was so much food! I had leftovers for sure.
I think Sorabol is one of my favorite eateries in Westfied Center. Vegetarians & carnivores have options to choose from. And the portions are good for the prices charged. You can't go wrong here!
author: Joanna T.

description:
Sorabol is a popular chain of fast casual Korean restaurants in the Bay Area.  This location can be found at Westfield's stylish and hopping food court.  It's a nice concept: affordable Korean BBQ, noodles, and banchan served up quick in a casual setting.  They've got an open, flame grill behind the counter, where you can see the beef, chicken, and pork being freshly cooked.  It smells delicious.

The restaurant serves Korean BBQ chicken (dak bulgogi), beef bulgogi, and pork bulgogi (dwaeji bulgogi).  They also have beef short ribs (galbi), seafood (mackerel, salmon, calamari), and an assortment of noodle, wonton, and tofu soups.  Entrees are reasonably priced at around $10 each.  The quality isn't great, but the portions are big and for a food court meal, you'll walk away feeling satisfied.

Most of the foods have already been cooked and are sitting in a cafeteria-style ordering line.  Plates start off with white rice and japchae noodles (slippery, translucent Korean sweet potato noodles) followed by meat(s).  I tried and suggest the beef bulgogi and short ribs.

At the end of the line, they throw some sauce onto the rice, give you a small cup of kimchi, and top the plate off with a few pieces of broccoli.  There's also a selection of a dozen different types of banchan (complementary Korean side dishes).  Unlike a sit-down Korean restaurant, the banchan at Sorabol is not included with your meal.  It costs extra.  The banchan consists of different vegetables, mostly pickled.

My plate of beef bulgogi and short ribs hit the spot.  I've rarely had galbi (short ribs) that didn't taste good.  It's just one of those dishes that's apparently hard to mess up.  Galbi is served on the bone and is easier eaten with your hands.  Therefore, you may want to grab extra napkins.  The bulgogi was savory, soft and well marinated.

I recommend asking for just noodles instead of rice *and* noodles.  The japchae noodles are more appetizing and unique.  The kimchi is savory, but served in small portions.

Service is speedy.  Large glasses of water are available free of charge.  Silverware is self-serve and is located around the corner from the register.

I think Sorabol is one of the most popular (if not, the most popular) restaurant at Westfield's food court.
author: Daniel B.

description:
Hot noodle soup - best hangover food.  Got lunch here at around 11 am and the line was pretty empty.  I ordered the tofu and vegetable soup with ramen.  You can choose ramen, udon, wide rice noodles or egg noodles too.  I was really looking forward to my soup and it took a few minutes for them to make it.  

I was actually pretty disappointed with what I got.  It looked good from appearance - glistening oil in a red broth full of noodles, vegetables and tofu.  It was surprisingly pretty bland with little flavor.  I still enjoyed it because I was tired and hungover, but I feel like there could have been so much more seasoning and taste.  It is also a bit too oily, leaving an icky feeling/residue in your mouth. 

I don't expect too much of "ambiance" from a mall's food court, but the quality of the food didn't meet expectations. The service was also a bit slow.

Ambiance: 2/5
Food: 2.5/5
Service: 3/5
Overall Experience: 2/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Ive always been in love with korean cuisine! I always order their spicy rice cakes (my fav) which is really tasty and hot! My order came with rice and a side of kimchi. Their food is a bit pricey but it really fills you up. I will try their other hot stuff the next time i go :) 


*The line's always long around lunch time. It dies down around dinner time.
author: Tiffany B.

description: I got the salmon entree. The salmon looked and tasted like it had been sitting there for a while. It was relatively stiff in texture. The cooked vegetables were really cold. The only thing that was good were the noodles. They were warm and nicely flavoured.
author: James S.

description: Come hungry! We were when we went searching the food court for some good and cheap eats.  It was around 8:30PM and we were checking out the fast food places.  I saw the line up for this place and went to see the food.  When I saw the items you could get on the menu, I saw that some of the food items weren't available anymore, likely due to almost closing time.  We joined the line and I ordered one item but it also came with rice, glass noodles, and vegetables.  The BBQ chicken looked fresh and most popular so that's what I got.  The girl starting putting chicken pieces in my take out container, and she didn't stop! Definitely a big portion, and I wasn't able to finish the chicken and rice.  The rice was a little dry but overall a good meal for less than $10.
author: Violet P.

description: Food was cold despite being served from the hotbar. Crispy chicken was stale and hard to chew. Nothing much else to say. I didn't expect much from the mall on a Monday, but this is just horrible.
author: Denny D.

description:
Pros: Generous food serving, Decent price for food court
Cons: Bulcogi was oily and gross, chapchae was oily and too sweet, kimchee was sour
author: Sunny S.

description: Love this place! For the price and convenience it's perfect. I always get the tofu seafood stew. It takes a while but it super tasty and healthy (and carb free without the rice)
author: Amy Y.

description: FOOD WAS COLD! The taste is there and what I expected. However rice and noodles were Luke warm. I ordered the spicy chicken and it was rock solid cold...I think this was from yesterday and had just been pulled out of fridge.  I asked if they could hear up and they said no...too bad cause I really like this place, but I don't want to eat cold food.
author: Hazel H.

description:
First thing that came to mind when I got here is... Korean Panda Express. That's right I went there! Korea uses Tiger as a symbol.. so Tiger Express? Maybe that name refers to some other thing in this world. Anyways on to the meal~

I ordered spicy pork and bulgogi, I think that's my pretty standard go to for most korean spots, be it a fancier restaurant or a sit-eat-go one or kbbq, but definitely my first korean fast food joint. The meal came with Japchae which I would say is pretty good, not greasy or salty, just right, and it's part of a korean meal, definitely liked that. Nothing spectacular of the meal, but also definitely not bad. The bulgogi is a bit more on the sweeter side, nothing too flavorful but that, and the spicy pork wasn't spicy enough but I would say it's made to cater to more? It was a good experience. 

Overall giving it 3.5~4 stars because it's a cheap meal at a mall food court. Service is fast and they give quite a good amount of food as well. If you are out to find good korean food, there are definitely better spots around and more worth the calories and palate sensation. However if you are on the go, want a quick bite, Sorabol is definitely not a bad option. Cheap, quick and decent meal, it's what I like from my mall food court meals.

Oh, it seems like you do get more food if you dine in? I'm not sure, friend with me mentioned it when I got my order.
author: Joel L.

description: I always get the bibimbap with bulgogi.  You can ask them for a little bit a glass noodle on your rice.  It's a perfect post-run meal!  Service is ok but this is a food court so it's as expected.  Not authentic Korean food but close enough for when you're on the go.
author: Chris L.

description: Ordered bibim bap and i thought i was going to get some actual bibim bap. But got a paper plate with small portion of rice with bunch of stuff on top which looks like banchan (side dishes). So i paid $9 for small rice with banchan on top. This is not authentic korean food. Gives a bad name to korean food called bibim bap.
author: Jn K.

description:
This is a food court take out place that reminds me of Panda Express, except serving "Korean" food. On my first visit, I asked for bulgogi and the lady looked confused and pointed at the broccoli with a question mark on her face. It sounded like she had no idea what bulgogi was but I guess that's why the place actually calls it BBQ beef with bulgogi in brackets. 

After realizing I'm not at a Korean restaurant, but an American restaurant pretending to serve Korean food (Yay it's Panda Express but Korean)... I quickly lowered my expectations and went for a non traditional BBQ Chicken. It came with rice, "asian noodles" - jap chae, and vegetables (broccoli mix + kimchi). Since I got to go, the food came in a plastic container which probably didn't take the heat too well. The BBQ chicken was excellent, and my only complaint was the vegetable offering was too little. The jap chae was also on par with traditional Korean restaurants.

I'd probably be back for some quick service and to try some real Korean food next time.
author: Alfonso C.

description:
~$10 for a lunch in San Francisco is pretty great. (Anything less than $13 is affordable in this area...) For their prices, I was surprised by the huge amount of meat they gave me. The portion was really generous, which can be a rare find in SF. 

I'm not a hugely picky eater tbh, so Sorabol definitely satisfied my Korean food craving. I got the bulgogi with half rice, half jepchae. Though after I was done, I really regretted not getting just jepchae. I love that stuff, and there's didn't disappoint. 

I was STUFFED after I finished eating everything, which is partially the reason I'm giving it 4 stars. I just couldn't get over the generous portions - it wasn't like they gave me one scoop of meat and a ton of rice. Half my box was bulgogi. 

There was a line but the line moves fast. All in all, affordable for SF & generous portions wins it 4 stars in my book.
author: Jessica J.

description:
The bulgogi here is disappointing. Taste stuff before you order if you've never been here before. 

And $4+ for 1 short rib. No thanks!
$1 for 1 shrimp. 

But the yam noodles and the BBQ chicken is pretty good. 

Also, cashier gave me a dirty ass glass for water. It had a ring of crust on the inside!!Luckily another lady dispensing water told her to give me another one.
 
Too expensive here but that BBQ chicken is something I won't mind having again.
author: bcast b.

description:
Nothing like waiting in a long line behind a homeless guy who's trying to talk the woman behind the counter into selling him one large piece of chicken with some rice and noodles for $5.

Watching them argue was like watching a Key and Peele skit.

The man was saying, "I'm gonna give you $5 and you're gonna give me a piece of that chicken and some of your rice and noodles."

"No," the woman said, and afterwards  they went back and forth as she tried to explain that things here start at $8.95.

Maybe he thought he was in the wild, wild west instead of Westfield Mall wherein bargaining would have been allowed.

When I got my BBQ chicken plate I wished I would have chosen another place in the food court since the chicken was as dry as my napkin.

But hey, this dinner came with a show.
author: Jack R.

description:
I went with the two topping platter and left as an unsatisfied customer. Everything here is very sweet and would be a far cry from authentic Korean food. But what did I expect?! It is a Korean place at a food court/mall after all!

The really disappointing things were the somewhat hard/stale noodles that were served in place of the rice and the small portions of my order (bbq chicken and bulgogi) and side dishes (3 pieces of broccoli and 3 small leaves of kimchi). It's as if the owner gave the employees a formula on how much (or little) to serve customers: "they get 3 and nothing more!"

I will not come back and I've made it a new year resolution not to.
author: Lee T.

description:
Sorabol is located in the food court of Westfield mall. So as you can imagine, you'll be fighting your way through shoppers and baby strollers. As you navigate around the various obstacles of the food court, you'll probably notice that Sorabol will have one of the longest lines. BUT surprisingly, they do a great job of getting through the line quickly. 

Portions. Are. HUGE! I ordered a BBQ chicken plate for $8.95, and was surprised to see nearly half a chicken on my plate. In addition to the basic BBQ chicken entre, you also get a serving of glass noodles, white rice, broccoli and kim chee. This meal can EAISLY serve as lunch and dinner for those with lighter appetites. Flavor overall isn't something to write home (yelp) about, but the food fills you up at a cheap price. 

Bottom line: Serious bang for your buck with lots of chicken.
author: Jaime W.

description: On our way to catch the BART from Powell Station, my co-worker and I decided to grab dinner from the food court.  Since I've been craving Korean food, i suggested Sorabol. I orderedthe spicy pork ($9.25) and a soda ($1.01) while she got the bbq short rib ($11.95).  The portion size was just right, the taste was so-so.  She thought the japchae was too greasy, but I didn't mind because I like greasy food.
author: Janice T.

description: It's hard to find an abundance any Korean food in SF, so I'm glad there's Sorabol. I always get the Korean BBQ rib, which tastes like the marinated kalbi from any Korean BBQ restaurant. However, each order only comes with only 2 pieces for $12.95, which seems a bit pricey. You can get the order with half noodles and half rice, as well as kimchi and broccoli. All together it comes to $14. It tastes great but it's certainly not a cheap option. There are other things that I'll try in the future, but this food court shop is the Korean Panda Express.
author: Nick A.

description:
Running around town on a busy San Francisco weekend, I stopped at the Westfield Centre for lunch during errands.

I ordered the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup. The meat was already well done and the noodles were dry tasting. The broth was pretty good. I stocked up on kim chee, because I love the spicy pickled side dish. 

Overall it was good, yet doesn't compare to a freshly made hot and spicy beef noodle soup with freshly cooked medium rare beef. Still one of the better options for fast food at the mall.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Sunday, lunchtime: this place was packed and how! And yet the quick service made sure that the line kept moving. We opted for the two item combo which comes with rice and noodles, kimchi and steamed broccoli. 
Combo 1: Stir fried tofu (very tasty, bit of gravy that goes well with rice) & Lemon chicken (slightly dry, but was crispy so it made a good side). I asked for less rice as extra noodles and got just that. 
Combo 2: BBQ chicken (not a winner) and Calamari (I usually try and avoid these things at fast food joints kinda places but my husband really wanted to try it, was very chewy and avoidable because they have better options)
I liked my combo way better than my husband liked his. Over all a 3 for me.
author: Shruti D.

description:
Been to many malls and many Sorabols. One...just ONE...lukewarm piece of BBQ SHORTRIB. Not shortribS...just shortrib. I feel short of a rib. Asked about it and the cashier tried to justify. Um...no matter what they said...I felt shorted. Next time I'll walk up short a couple of steps and go to another restaurant next door. Never ever had this problem with other Sorabols. Rent must be high. 

But I must say...I made the effort to get up from my table, ask about the ONE piece...just give me another one. I'm obviously not happy. Don't you want your patrons to be happy?
author: Jazzy B.

description: Definitely not as good as Korean food in SoCal, but when I'm craving Korean food, this is where I go. I usually get the short rib stew, which is a little too sweet for me, but it's passable. It comes with japchae (not authentic), rice, broccoli, and kimchi. Any other side dish is extra! In any case, I'll still come back here to get my Korean food fix, but I'm never super excited to pay so much money for subpar food...
author: Trisha V.

description:
If I could I would give this place ZERO stars. The meal at this place is suppose to come with a main entree, rice, kimchi, and sweet yam noodles. My parents and I went to this place at 8:20pm and made our orders. They informed us that they did not have anymore sweet yam noodles. We asked them politely if they could just give us extra kimchi instead of the sweet yam noodles. The girl who was serving us very rudely told us no. Then we ask her why not. Then she turned around and grabbed another guy and pointed to us. The guy asked us how he could help us. We ask him if he could give us more kimchi in the absence of the sweet yam noodle. Like the girl who was helping us before, the guy very rudely to us no. We ended up having Udon at Japanese place in the other food court in the mall.  

My advise is never go to this place. There are other places to eat that have better customer service and MUCH BETTER FOOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Richie A.

description:
Okay. So I do like this place but I'm a bit annoyed. I always get the bibimbap with bulgogi or just vegetables and it's always 9.95 with one topping. 

This time my boyfriend got salmon as his topping and the bowl was charged at 13.95 because of the salmon. I don't mind paying that, it's whatever. The problem is that we got zero warning thay salmon wasn't a topping. If we knew, we would've got something else as a topping. 


When I saw I was charged by the cashier for a 2 item meal instead of bibimbap, I thought that she was mistaken. Instead, she kind of barked at me and said "i already knew that bibimbap with salmon is the same price as a 2 item" glad she knew...because no one told me until they had my card in their hand. 
Maybe the menu needs clarification so there won't be surprises in charges.
author: Courtney A.

description: This is Panda Express for Korean bbq, cheap and can get a good variety. Not meant to share with others. If that's what you are looking for, this is the place. They don't give you sides, bulgulgi is dry and not too much flavor
author: Victor D.

description: It was my first and last time in this place. Everything was delicious and cold! Girl who imposes rice was very rough! It was written on her face that she was tired of all customers! yes, it was really busy, but I think she should be happy that all these customers bring money in her place!! I also work in the service sector, and we are taught that the customer is always right and the customer is king! unfortunately I do not know the name of this Asian girl, but it was the lowest and full lips. I hope that someone who is important to service, after reading my post will think of visiting this place...
author: Daria D.

description: The absurdly small portions are not worth the price. Maybe if the food was excellent. But it was definitely not worth it.
author: Nick B.

description:
Favorite Sorabol location

Friendly service

Huge portions

Always satisfy

Way better than the stonestown location. It's not even compareble!
author: Carol Y.

description: Food is decent. Service is terrible. I had a receipt and the buzzer that they give and the girl was acting like she was doing me a favor by giving me the food I paid for. Not necessary to eat here. Will not return.
author: Imani G.

description: Lots of side dishes. Good food. Nice and warm. A lot of options. I would come here again.
author: Kris C.

description:
I have a soft spot for spicy noodle soups. I crave it all the time. When I see it in a food court, it is really hard to resist as one of my best childhood memories is getting noodles at food stalls. 

Combined that with my love for kimchi, of course, then, I have to order the noodle soup here. The spicy one. 

It's actually decent coming out from a food court eatery. The soup was spicy and savory, and while the beef in it was just so-so, it didn't disappoint.

Remember to ask for kimchi on the side.
author: Alice C.

description:
This is awful, even for food court standards. Meat is bone dry, cold, and chewy, vegetables are excessively chewy, and the service has listening comprehension deficits. I had to throw away most of the meal.


On top of that, because it's SoMa, you're paying 15-20$.
author: Hans H.

description:
I will never order from this place again! Thats what i told to my self a  many times..since i just craving for their noodles, i tried and forget what was happened from the past. A really bad experience!! The customer service from the women getting your food is horrible and they look like zombies when you tell them what you want.

I had to repeat myself a few times to the first girl.

I got the double vermicelli noodles,(which the lady gave me an almost one servings )  and three small pcs of tempura  and  a pc of spare ribs. 


It was horrible even though the plate is huge. The only thing I  liked was the vermicelli noodles which is very dissapointed because the lady will give you small amount,  which was warm and tasty but the tempura was so small and spareribs was cold and very very very dry!

The meal cost $14.19 and I should have ponied up for a better at another place in the food court!
author: Meda C.

description:
I don't know about authentic. I don't know about "cheap" in San Fran.

All I know, is because I wanted some kimchi, and they had glass noodles, and chicken, that it served my needs.

So - the kimchi lived up to my expectations, the chicken wasn't bad for the price, and the glass noodles were tasty.

All-in-all, a win for a food court, since most food courts seem to be lacking in Korean flavor.
author: Keith B.

description:
Alright, Yelp Peeps~here's the bottom line:   You don't serve hefty portions of Korean food to your patrons, they'll stop eating at your restaurant; the same applies to all restaurants in South Korea.  After all, Sorabol is a Korean restaurant, arrasoyo!?

It's my second time visiting this location; the lines waiting to place your order indicates the food served at Sorabol is exceptionally good.  I have a great affinity devouring Sorabol's seafood . . . so delicious!
author: Shirley M. J.

description:
I will never order from this place again! The customer service from the women getting your food is horrible and they look like zombies when you tell them what you want.

I had to repeat myself a few times to the first girl.

I got the BBQ chicken entree which includes white rice, broccoli, Korean vermicelli noodles, and two big slabs of BBQ chicken. 

It was horrible even though the plate is huge. The only thing I  liked was the vermicelli noodles which was warm and tasty but the big slabs of chicken was cold and not tasty at all and very very very dry!

I was so hungry and I didn't even finish the plate. I finished the noodles but didn't touch much of the veggies or the white rice.  As for the chicken, I used my knife to cut it up since it's so freakin big but it's really quantity over quality here. 

The meal cost $9.74  and I should have ponied up for a better meal at the Brazilian steakhouse Fire of Brazil or another place in the food court!
author: Gangsta G.

description: this place is not worth your money, they even charged extra for side dishes or banchan for $2.00 and kimchi for $1.00 and i think they had nothing on their menu to indicate that! in any korean resto you can even ask for 2nds on banchan so i 'll never go back to this place for sure! even the bulgogi they had was not tasty at all, the japchae is OK but they gave you small portions! it's too costly but  they claims on their info page that it's under $10.00, they also were not generous in portions!! avoid this place if you're in Westfield mall!
author: Pinkangel U.

description:
The portion sizes are nuts. When I thought they'd stop putting food on my plate, they kept piling it on... then they added even more, and more. Think about the plates you see some pros hefting away from a buffet - that's not too far from what I received as the standard menu item.

I sat across a table from two Sorabol ajumma on their work break. You know, gossip and all that. Further evidence that the servings are big: one of the workers snapped her chopstick in two to (attempt to) use the stub as a toothpick after her meal. If the toothpick had to be supersized, picture the food that came beforehand. BAM.
author: Dan B.

description:
The food here is low quality even by food court standards. Do not get the noodles. It's a bowl of beef bouillon water with instant ramen topped with an oily stir fry of onions, scallions and beef. All for about $10 (with tax) and 15 minutes of waiting time. There is no banchan aside from a tablespoon of kimchi. 

If you want noodles, go to the Ajisen. For a few dollars more, you get real broth, ramen, and several different toppings in under 10 minutes.
author: Albert H.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat in this food court, the my provide great service which is key ! 

For food I like to get the BBQ chicken and short rib combo, :) although I get super full I like to come back often.
author: Megan M.

description:
Quick, cheap and good. Can't ask much more for mall food when you're on the go. If you're looking for some decent Asian food without the usual fast Chinese food with fried rice, come here for the Korean jap chae and BBQ chicken. Portions are large too so it's pretty cost effective for anyone simply looking to re energize after a day of shopping.

Service was efficient since ordering is cafeteria style.
author: Steven C.

description:
Located in the food court of Metreon in the heart of downtown, Sorabol is a decent Korean restaurant that offers a variety of fast food items with generous portions.

The food isn't super great, but it's not bad either. There are plenty of Korean dishes to choose from, and you can get a generous 2-item combo for $10.

Come before or after the lunch rush! It tends to get super packed (since it's right across the street from the Moscone Center). There's always a line, but it moves pretty quickly.

(+/-) FOOD AND VARIETY: Big hefty portions, plenty of dishes to choose from (bulgogi, galbi, japchae, kimchi, and more!). I always get the 2-item Combo, includes white/brown rice, clear noodles, the 2 entrees that you can pick, and free toppings (veggies, kimchi, etc). They're not fantastically amazing, they could use more flavor and texture, but hey you're at a food court inside a mall. So the quality is better than average for a food court restaurant.

(+) PRICE: All of the prices on the menu are roughly between $8-13 depending on what you get (for the main combo/entrees). As if I didn't mention this enough, they give you a huge portion of everything. So I say the price is pretty reasonable! 

(+/-): SERVICE: Aside from the long line, the service is pretty fast. The staff is very friendly. If you come during the lunch rush though, good luck finding a place to sit.
author: Xin W.

description: Judging from a mall food court stand point this is reasonably priced and provides a lot of food to fill you up. 10$ is plenty for a big eater like me. Plus their short ribs are my favorite outside of Asia and all you can eat places.  Keep an eye out for this place and try it.
author: Andrew W.

description: Great amount of food. The food is a bit pricey but it's decent for what you get. The chicken is probably the best thing you can get there and the chicken is a solid 8.
author: Kevin A.

description: Food was greasy and service was very very slow. When asking them they keep saying two minutes. Eventually it took 30 mins from ordering to actually get a lukewarm bowl of soup. Would not come back and advise others to stay away.
author: Philip K.

description: I agree with the previous comparisons of this place to a Panda Express selling Korean food. This place is located in the mall food court in downtown. The portions are huge and it was nice that the food was placed in a real plate rather than some Styrofoam plate/box. I got the Korean BBQ Chicken and it came with noodles and rice. The combo also comes with kimchi and vegetables but I declined those. I'm not very familiar with Korean food so I can't say how Americanized it was. However, it was tasty and good enough to feel a starved tourist after a day of endless walking!
author: Allie S.

description:
Good place for a quick lunch if you work in Fidi or Soma! The food is not going to win any awards, but the generous portions will keep you going through the rest of the day.

I usually go for the 2 item combo with rice and jap chae. Last time I was there, I got the bbq chicken and spicy pork. Both were cooked and seasoned well enough to warrant coming back for a quick lunch. My main complaint is with the spicy pork; the slices of meat were not very thin and a bit over cooked, so it was a bit difficult to chew. Also the jap chae felt oily and a bit underseasoned for my taste.

Pros:
- Quick lunch
- Generous Portions
- Chicken was cooked very well

Potential Improvements:
- Meat could be seasoned a little bit better
- Pork could come in thinner slices
author: Jeff M.

description:
Terrible service. I've waited more than half  an hour and no one gives a shit about us. The made the wrong dishes and kept us waiting. It is lunch break. No one has 2hrs or 3hrs just for a stupid noodle soup!

Worst service. Don't go. It is totally disaster.
author: Wenchao M.

description: Great place 2 get my korean noodle fix when I'm  in town. Excellent location just off market. Lots  of shops closeby. Quick, easy, convenient and inexpensive.
author: Doug B.

description: I work across the street from the Westfield mall where sorabol is located. I have become a regular customer. My favorites are their bibimbop and udon noodle soup. Portions are very generous.
author: Francisco N.

description: This is my go to location when eating in the Westfield mall and I have eaten there dozen of times. They do a very nice job keeping the quality up - it's not typical mall food at all. Its probably important to mention that the food at this location is orders of magnitude better than the Sorobol over in the old Metreon location on 4th. I generally get the spicy chicken on brown rice (you have to ask for brown rice) and they usually give me a very generous serving. The beef short ribs are good but are smaller portions. The Kim Chi is very good, but I always ask for extra since it is a small amount otherwise. The cold steamed broccoli they offer is good if you ask for some chili sauce to dip it in. Generally theres a line (because it is good) but they keep the line moving at a rapid pace.
author: C S.

description:
The food @ establishment is brilliant - clean, well-prepared & presented, affordable and positively delicious. The employees are quick and friendly; the overall experience is outstanding.

(Unfortunately it's located in the basement of Westfield Mall and mirrors immigration & customs on a busy day @ SFO.)
author: John D.

description:
It looks as it it should be better than usual food court fare, but I am not sure that it is. 

I like the Westfield Centre food court, but Sorabol was disappointing. The portions for the standard combo were small and not good value for the price. 

The beef ribs were not great, the chicken and the japchae noodles were adequate. Everything was barely warm. The combo was served with rice (choice of brown or white) and a random, purposeless dipping sauce. 

I will try another option the next time I go to the movies.
author: Augusto T.

description: Went here with my girlfriend after a shopping tour. We chose the crispy chicken with rice and a Snapple Lemonade (paid 13$ each, which is a VERY good price, given the huge pile of chicken they put on our plate). Everything tasted delicious! So if you're looking for tasty and fair priced food, this is definitely worth a try  keep in mind you will dine in a food court, so don't expect anything too fancy or posh.
author: Cyrill E.

description: Great for cafeteria food!! for $8-10 you get 2 sides, free kimchi, rice or noodles, and etc. The kalbi beef with bones is a bit dry and hard to eat. Overall it is my go to place for food and the portions are so big you can eat 2 plates for 3 people easily.
author: Lily P.

description:
Yes, in case you were wondering, I am a bit 'sore about ordering this bowl' at SOR A BOL. True enough, it has come through for me during lesser grey haired days when financial solvency was certainly more of a challenge. 

However, having ordered the chicken noodle bowl recently after some time in the City, playing the day away, I was quite the underwhelmed customer. 

Big bowl, not big on taste. Oh well.... most of all, did not enjoy the texture of what appeared like spaghetti noodles. yuck. Perhaps should have gone for grilled meat and panchan instead. 

I wasn't feeling it.. perhaps the smallish gyoza held the most packed punch of flavor of my entire order. Ho hum.

Westfield downstairs... food court of another level.
author: Jana C.

description: Good value for the price. Try the spicy pulled pork with kimchi, noodles and veggies.
author: Kiran R.

description: Stopped here for a quick bite between other obligations because there was a big line, which seemed auspicious. The be bim bop was good, but not hot or particularly amazing. I'd eat here again, but with so many other options nearby, might consider whether what they're serving is really your top pick.
author: Michael F.

description: As a low cost lunch place, this is a place worth your $. Lots of choices and huge serving of food.  Serving speed us good too. Don't forget to request more kimchi free of charge if you live it.  Meat is grilled very well.
author: Anne K.

description: You can get lots of food for less than $10 here, and in San Francisco that can be hard to come by. Had the Spicy BBQ Chicken entree plate and it comes with rice, japchae, kimchi, and broccoli along with a mound of chicken. It's satisfying and it's a bargain. Will come back.
author: Kenny W.

description: Don't do it!!! My husband ordered chicken, rice and a spring roll on 11/23/15 and got HORRIBLE food poisoning!  Ruined our trip!!!
author: Vanessa A.

description:
Needed some quick food so we headed from the convention center to the new Metreon.

Standard korean fast food fare - kalbi, bbq chicken, rice, kimchi, and chapjie noodles.

Not the best I've had but totally works in a pinch. Prices are reasonable and service is fast.
author: Julia P.

description:
This place offers authentic Korean dishes.. I've eaten here several times and their food is so spectacular  and super delicious..
I get combo-plate.. Two types of BBQ chicken and broccoli,white rice, noodle, Kim chi .. Not bad for 13$$.. It tastes  pure fleshy 
..I always get my food fast and warm..
author: Ronald A.

description:
I eat here all the time because the food is quick and delicious. However, their pricing is inconsistent.
For instance, I order a plate with half rice, half noodle, and a half order of lemon chicken with an egg roll. I was told one time this would count as a one item plate because I only get half the order of meat (they do give you a lot). Today I go and order the same thing and am charged for a 2 item combo. If it's a 2 item combo, then each serving should be equal size. I'd recommend to eat here for the taste but hope management recognizes this incident is leaving a bad taste in my mouth!
author: Josh S.

description: Clear noodles were very greasy / oily. Service could have been better. Tolerable, but failed to meet expectations. Good serving size. Dining in the food court can be a bit challenging with the homeless people panhandling and taking food scraps from tables. I guess they're not wasting food.
author: scott h.
