description: I'm a big fan of Korean bibimbap in general. I had one at Sorabol, with eel. The portions are humongous, but a bit too sweat and greasy for my taste.
author: Kinder H.

description:
Food is tasty for being so affordable, but they are a little stingy with the short ribs.  If you order chicken you get way more than you can eat, but if you order the short ribs, you will still be hungry - unless you eat the mountain of rice they give you.

No fountain soda, just a can.  Why??
author: Lea T.

description:
I loove Korean food but this place is not so great. The chicken and the meat are so dry. Not enough flavors. Sucky service. The skinny girl behind the counter just did not look happy and didn't give me a chance to pick what i wanted on my plate. She Just put broccoli and kimchi. Maybe its what others usually get. Before i could say no, its already on my plate. (Eyes rolling) 
I think the food and veggies been out too long, hence its dryness.
author: Anudari K.

description: One main factor of a Korean restaurant is reflective of their Banchan (side) dishes. The kim chi looked and tasted stale. Also, they should just include the banchan but instead you have to pay extra for the dishes. I ordered the spicy beef noodle soup which was decent. I survived the hectic cattle call line through Sorabol during the hectic weekend traffic at the San Francisco Shopping Centre. If you were just trying to grab a quick Korean fix, this is okay, but for a real authentic Korean culinary experience, I'd recommend elsewhere.
author: Alan K.

description:
Sorabol is what happens when you are extremely hungry & overwhelmed by choices in a large food court. 

I chose this place to eat for my 1st meal in SF & sorta regretted it after a few bite. Yes, it was fast w/large portions at a reasonable-ish price (a full plate cost me around $10 - short ribs & short ribs stew w/rice...I guess in L.A., I can get AYCE KBBQ for about that price...), but I'm in SF, foodie heaven, why did I pick this place!?! The food was average at best & way salty. 

Never pick the place to eat on an empty & ravenous stomach.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Satisfies my asian food craving every time! I especially love the japchae (clear noodles!) 

They are fairly generous with their portions, and the 2-item dinner is the best deal. I also love how they give you some complementary broccoli with you meal! My favorite veggie :D

Highlights:
(+) short ribs --- best item, IMO
(+) chicken
(+) mandu (korean dumplings)
(++++) japchae! comes with the dinner, and you can sub out rice for more of this!

Other notes: 
- Banchan costs money
- extra sauce for your meat is free, so ask for it!
- as with most meats, this can get salty quick, so dont forget to ask for a cup of water
author: Christina H.

description:
For a fast food Korean food, it actually was pretty good.

I was in the mood for something French yesterday but as I walked around the mall, the craving for something specific diminished as I get hungrier and hungrier and could just eat whatever is nearby. 

Since I was already at the mall, I decided to go to the food court. I looked around for something might fancy my taste buds. As I walked by this place, the smell of the spice calamari caught my senses! I immediately fall in line and decided to eat here. 

I ordered the meal with 2 sides (almost like when you order at Panda Express): glossy noodles, beef short ribs (came with steamed broccoli (I am not a fan) and the spicy calamari. The calamari is in hot spicy sauce, not deep fried. I combined it with my noodles, it complimented each other. Since the short ribs has this grill taste plus a really good sauce. Heard of how much food they give you at this place? I left a clean plate, that how much I liked it. Lunch for $11 plus canned coke, deal!
author: Lora M.

description:
I wasn't expecting much from sorabol. I thought it could just be a place that would settle my korean cravings. And that it did UNTIL I found a hair in my BBQ chicken. Hair in food is one of my biggest pet peeves. It was disgusting. I felt nauseous after. If you can't be sanitary with your food, do not run a restaurant!

It was such a disappointment because the food wasn't bad tasting. But that hair really ruined it for me. I can't eat here again. Such a bummer because korean restaurants in the area are so limited.
author: Junel S.

description:
Walked around in a big circle in the food court and finally decided on some good old korean food. I ordered the bbq beef as it seemed extremely fresh and had just been brought out from the back.

It was terrible. The toughest, chewiest meet I've had from a Korean Place in a long time. I definitely won't be getting the bbq beef ever again from Sorabol. My friend's bbq chicken was slightly better, but that was drenched in sauce so it didn't seem too appetizing either.
author: Edward W.

description:
Sorabol is my guilty pleasure. I know it's not "real Korean" food but it suffices when you're in need and you've got 2 more hours to kill standing in line for a movie screening. 

I go vegetarian/pescetarian frequently. This is sometimes an issue when I am out but if I'm around Sorabol it's okay. Loving Hut has been giving me issues lately so that crap is out of the question. 
I can do a veggie bowl from Sorabol for $7.95 and it's big enough to be my dinner AND lunch for the next day! The veggie bowl consists of rice, jap chae, all their pickled goodies (ban chan) and broccoli, shrooms, etc. They're actually pretty accommodating so I was pleasantly surprised when I asked for no rice,all jap chae and WAS NOT CHARGED EXTRA! I've done this before at Stonestown and was charge an additional $3. Am I serious? Yes.
 The location inside Stonestown nickel and dimes you.. They even charge 25 cents for that tiny little cup of kimchi! 
At Westfield the kimchi is complimentary by the way.

So anyway... If I'm in the area and happen to be going veggie, Sorabol is my guilty guilty pleasure. MmMmMMm.
author: Susy C.

description: Usually "mall food" isn't the best but I was in a hurry, on my lunch break, and just came from a quick make up run at Nordstroms. I walked around to see what looked good, and being pregnant I am def super picky right now. I saw that they had 2 item for $8.95 the portions looked okay too. Not only were the portions huge the bbq chicken was really good. I do plan on coming back and getting my bbq chicken and white rice fix here and it's under $10 can't beat that!
author: Irma R.

description: Had lunch here between meetings while at ALA Annual.  I guess I'm spoiled by all the great fast-food korean bbq options in Honolulu.  This place would never make it in Honolulu.
author: Mike C.

description:
I've been looking forward to trying out the new eateries at the new Metreon and Sorabol was first up. The majority of the dinning court is new except perhaps Buckhorn, which was a part of the old food court, and found its way into the new court, and for good reason. A friend and I somehow found ourselves wandering towards Sorabol as the hot table looked rather good with its various dishes.

A quick looks at the menu and most items are $8 and for $1 more, you can get a 2 item combo. I went ahead and got the BBQ chicken, prawns, and brown rice. I skipped the sticky and rice and went as healthy as possible. I was originally going to order the Spicy BBQ Chicken, but I have to admit, it didn't look quite appetizing. My plate was piled high with noodles, chicken, brown rice, prawns, and veggies. A nod and a drizzle of teriyaki sauce went on to my chicken and brown rice.

For $10 and some change, I got a plateful of Korean BBQ. I took my first few bites and it was decent. I'll be the first admit that my knowledge of Korean BBQ is limited, or I should say non-existent. Nevertheless, I do know whether I think something is good or not and this was just okay. The grilled chicken was undoubtedly the best part of the dish along with the brown rice. The remainder of the dish was lacking flavor and rather bland all around. If you're in the mood for Korean BBQ, you owe it to try out Sorabol, but its nothing spectacular; plenty of more options at the Metreon.

Ambiance: 4 Stars (out of 5)
Food: 3 Stars (out of 5)
Service: N/A
Price: $
Overall: 3 Stars (out of 5)

Pros:
+ Plenty of Korean BBQ combo dishes
+ 2 item combo for $10 and some change
+ Generous serving size

Cons:
- Korean fast food
- Lacking flavor and taste
author: Alexander E.

description:
I have passed by this place a number of tie and always wondered about the place since they always had quite a long line. I finally tried the place recently and find it pretty good for the food court!

They have a menu posted on the wall with a number of items to choose from. The majority of the plates are ready to go with the meats pre-cooked. With these dishes, you get the option of white rice, noodles, or both, and then they add your choice meats. Personally, I really like their clear noodles so i just for all noodles but it's nice to have options! they also ask if you would like kimchi and add a few broccoli to finish up the dish but it's really not that much veggies. Basically, it's rice/noodles plus meat. The portion size is very reasonable considering what you pay. The only downside is that there is not that much variety in a single dish (even if you get the combo plate with two meats). I just happened to go with my friend and we each ordered separate dishes and split them, which was a good way to make up for the lack of variety. In addition, they have some dishes that require you to wait a bit for them to cook. My other friend tried it but thought it was only okay.

Overall, I think it's worth the try and would certainly come back!
author: Ken T.

description:
In the past this used to be a decent place to get some cheap Korean food, worth 3 stars. Of course it doesn't compare to eating at a regular Korean restaurant, but it was okay for what you paid (under $10). So this place and the Buckhorn Grill were the most popular eateries in the Westfield's mall food court. It's also nice that you get real plates and silverware.

But lately they seem more concerned on making a sale rather than serving quality food. I was here a couple of weekends ago (last month), to catch a movie at the Century Theatre and dropped by to get something to eat. I got a combination plate with grilled BBQ chicken which was fine, except for the following:
- The fried rice was mixed with partially UNCOOKED rice
- The jap chae noodles were all broken into small pieces

I think that they were probably running low on some food items and someone decided to do a haphazard job of rush cooking more. And either nobody bothered to do a taste test, or they simply didn't care. I didn't bother go back and get in line to complain because otherwise I would have missed the movie.

Dear Sorabol,
Please establish some quality control procedures. If you run out of something then please just offer a substitute (out of fried rice or noodles = offer white rice or maybe extra veggies instead), until the next batch is ready (properly cooked!!). DON'T serve partially uncooked food or broken noodles. Customers will not return if all you want to do is make a quick buck. Thank you.
author: Luis C.

description:
ROTTEN FOOD. DO NOT EAT HERE. 

So I was first bothered that the spicy chicken dish tasted as though it was warmed up from the night before. I guess coming there upon opening you do not get fresh cooked food. The spicy pork was freshy cooked, but the chicken was luke warm and tough, rewarmed most likely. I was so glad I also got a side order of veggies. I love fermented veggies. 

What I do not like are rotten veggies, veggies that were past their prime. They smelled like they should have not been served days earlier. Unfortunately, I did not smell before eating and into my mouth went the most vile tasting...well I don't know what. 

$15 down the drain because after the veggie incident, the rest of the food is not going down without a gag-reflex. Go somewhere else in the food court, do not think this Sorabol is like its surburban cousins.
author: Theresa S.

description:
I haven't been here in about 7 years since moving to the East Bay.  But I remember Sorabol was great back then and it's still around,  so it must be doing well. I was craving some chap che & galbi or bulgogi.  We were waiting for our other friends to arrive so we ordered something for the kids 1st.  They wanted chicken & noodles.  It looked really good.   

Later when our other party arrived,  the Hubs was sent to order food for us.  He usually gets the spicy pork.   He said the galbi didn't look fresh, so he got bulgogi instead.   

The rice was old & cold, the worst combo.  It wasn't even good rice to begin with.  I was expecting like Nishiki rice.  Nope!

The chap che was seasoned well & somewhat warm.  The blanched broccoli was alright;   not really seasoned.   The bulgogi was dry...VERY dry, almost like boiled dry.  The little tiny side of kimchi was good,  with a kick to it.  But that's it.  

Overall,  it was a lot of food. ...but the food wasn't that good.  A big disappointment.
author: Winnie L.

description:
Vegetarian Review:

I really liked their bibimbap with spicy tofu!

Highly recommend it if you're in a pinch and need some good soul food.

Had a hard time deciding between this one and Loving Hut... glad I tried their bibimbap!
author: Yoon P.

description:
Food isn't bad at all given it's a food court and food-to-eat time is under 5 minutes. I come here whenever i'm in a conference nearby and the beef stew, kalbi, spicy pork and japchae never disappoints. a 2-item combo plate will run ya a little over $10 (with 8.7% taxes).

What I gripe about is the atmosphere, the acoustics are bad so there's always background noise. 

Another gripe is with the freaking amount of tourists and cool kids in the mall that will give you a silly look when you chomp down on delicious food and use your hands for the kalbi. Awkward. I mean, er, not that I know anything about it.
author: Kevin N.

description:
I tried bulgogi and spicy pork, with traditional japchae. Comparing only to some of the great Korean eats in Honolulu, sorabol is okay, about 2.5-3. 

Spicy pork was not as spicy and definitely boring if you are used to Korean kimchee. Bulgogi was tender. Not a lot of flavor or fat.   I like japchae though because it was not oily and overlooked. It was good but could use a little flavor. AThe place gives a generous amount of meat. 

Overall, it's ok. Good enough for a food court. But if you are in San Fran, you can't be bored trying the many restaurants it has.
author: Romella J.

description: SOFT TOFU SOUP FTW! I don't even want to add anything else. Try it and you'll see.
author: Shanel S.

description: For a grab and go order only: a good, healthy choice if you just order grilled chicken and veggies on the side (maybe some brown rice).  The portions are generous, fresh and good flavor. Don't think I'd get anything else there.
author: e w.

description: Delicious option in the Westfield SF food court! I had the spicy beef soup (made fresh to order) and will certainly be back again.
author: Jenny M.

description: I ordered spicy noodle soup man customer service is horrible especially rude ass bitch short Hair Dark Skin  and very short women was really rude. Looks like she has  mental problem she needs to stop serving customers please. Her name was Linda be careful people she might put poison in the food. If she is working do not eat !!!!!!!!!
author: Yoki P.

description:
Diners are now limited to broccoli and kimchi for a single protein meal - they actually charge now for extra veggies like carrots or bean sprouts or daikon. This is a new change and you are not informed up front. 

Also, salmon is $3 extra while smaller mackrel fillets are not. Agian, you are not informed until after it is boxed up.

Meat has improved a great deal. Spicy Beef Soup is a winner. Wonton Soup uses beef dumplings - and it's a winner too. Delicious.
author: Nan L.

description: Portion of food you get for the price you pay is great, too bad the food is not good. Ended up throwing it away.
author: S A.

description: This is one of my favorite places for quick bite! I typically go for the veggie bowl with brown rice (no additional cost for substitution of white) and noodles, though these are sometimes a bit on the sweet side. The portions are ginormous, and the vegetables are seasoned well. Back in my pre-veg days, I also loved the chicken! :O
author: Shendi X.

description:
Eating here is a real balancing act.  The options are basic Korean meats, and you get lots of broccoli, noodles, and as much kimchi as you want.  So far, so good -- but the meat is okay, not great, and is too heavily sauced.

You'll walk away from the counter with more than a pound of food, so gauge how much you eat appropriately.  If you're easily distracted, like me, and you don't pay attention to how much you're eating, you could end up ruining the rest of your day.
author: Bill H.

description: I'm a fan of more authentic Korean food, but this place is decent for a mall food court.  I got the two item combo with Spicy Chicken and Calamari.  It was a bit pricy, but it expected in this part of SF.  The one plus side is that the portion size was huge and came with a side of glass noodles and rice.  Apparently you can ask for kimchi on the side with no additional charge according to other Yelp reviews.
author: Richard L.

description:
Korean food court food.  It ain't bad in a pinch, but I wouldn't call it authentic or particularly delicious.  Think the panda express of korean food.

It's not "bad" by any means, just nothing special.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
Decent price for a decent amount of food.  Speedy delivery.  Veggie option for those who are looking to balance out their fiber intake.

What I got...veggie bowl with noodles and tofu.  

Enough to fill you up and some for take away (didn't know that they offered boxes to take home)
author: Hiromi N.

description:
Grub before the movies.   They are many restaurants in the food court but Sorabol was it for me.

Food was fresh and flavorful enough

Price is decent.  try it.
author: Paul J.

description: I was really missing some of my Mom's Korean cooking and was hoping to fill my craving. The service was friendly, but very slow. My friends were already half way through their meal before I received mine. I had the spicy chicken which had great flavor, but was a little too sweet to my liking. I also had the tofu stew which tasted great!! There was tons of tofu and a decent amount of seafood! I would go back for the stew itself!
author: John K.

description:
The food doesn't really taste like the stuff they serve in Korea, but the sweet sauce on the BBQ chicken is freaking out of this world amazing. It's so good you should get 2 cups of it and pour it all over your rice and broccoli and everything else on your plate. 

Order the BBQ chicken plate - it can feed 2 people easily. The plate comes with a heaping portion of chicken, rice, complimentary kimchee (not the best), the best chapchae (thickest, chewiest, clear noodles yum) and 2 big pieces of steamed broccoli (did I mention it is amazing with the sauce?).

NOMMERS.
author: Jess C.

description:
I had an unpleasant experience at this Sorabol location Monday(8/18) afternoon.  I ordered a 2 item combination as usual.  I told the female server that I want the clear noodle instead of rice, no problem.  When I told the same server that I want both of my 2 items to be the BBQ spareribs, she immediately said "NO".  I asked why?  She pointed out "2 item combination".  I said "ok, I want 2 same item combination".  She repeated to me "no, 2 item combination means you only get one BBQ spareribs and another item not BBQ spareribs".  I said again that I want 2 same item combination both items being the BBQ spareribs.  She raised her voice and repeated that would not be a combination and pointed out "combination" again to me like I don't know what that means.  Another female server came over and tried to explain to me combination means you have to order two different items.  I told them that's false advertisement and signage because it's not specified that I have to order two different items.  

A combination means a number of things combined.  They can be the same items or different items combined.  If they don't specify the 2 items need to be different items or same items are not permitted to be in the combination, I should be able to order my combination with 2 same items.  

Oh well, a line started forming.  I left.  I won't be coming back to Sorabol.
author: Gina W.

description:
I wouldn't say this is the best go-to if you want cheap Korean food. But if you want something fast, quick and don't mind spending the same amount of money you would spend in a regular Korean restaurant, then this is the place to go. 

I usually go there for the japchae and chicken rice bowl because it's cheap and it's ready in less than two minutes. All they do is pack it and ask if you want sauce. If you are at Stones, they do it pretty quickly. This one takes a bit or more time because of course, the long lines.
author: Cynthia D.

description: Their spicy beef noodle soup was amazing for being in a mall! It felt like nice Korean food and not just Mall food. And my Korean friend agreed!
author: Athena A.

description:
I haven't been in Downtown SF in a really long time, so it was nice to be back. Sorabol is one of the places I tend to go to because I'm nervous to try anything new, haha.

I decided to get the BBQ Chicken ($8.50) to-go. The BBQ Chicken tasted dry & they don't give as much as I remember. They don't give as much broccoli either (I want my greens!). However, the noodles were appetizing. 

I definitely have had better though. Don't think I'll choose this place again when I'm there. There's other yummy things to try in the food court.
author: Jessica A.

description:
I would normally shudder at the idea of eating at a food court if I didn't *HAVE* to eat there. 

Sorabol at the Westfield is exempt from this. 

Every now and then I'll tell a friend I want to eat at the food court and I have to throw in the disclaimer that Sorabol is pretty awesome. Nobody has disagreed yet. 

For $10,which is on the pricey side you can get a LARGE helping of BBQ chicken, rice and clear noodles. 

The chicken is flavorful and well-seasoned. 

Finding a place to sit is a bit of a challenge as the food court has shared seating with all the other food joints, but it's doable. 

I highly recommend this place.
author: Carlos A.

description:
I've been here a few times now and the food portions are pretty large.  There's never any wait time and the price is decent.  I usually get brown rice and noodles, with salmon and teriyaki chicken.  The salmon is a hit-or-miss option, but I think the chicken tastes delicious.  It's also great that they give out free kimchi on the side.

The last time I was here, I finished eating as they were starting to close.  When I asked a lady who works there for a to-go box, she went ahead and gave me a free container of rice.  She was extremely kind, and as I ended up giving my food away to a homeless man at the muni, I'd like to think her generosity passed on to me that night.  This has nothing to do with their food, but it still led to a great experience so thanks for that waitress lady!
author: Yobel M.

description:
I'm not a fan of food courts but this food court in the basement of Westfield Mall is the fanciest I've seen in US and Sorabol is my fave place to eat in Union Square (sad, I know).

Being a food court stand, I can only give it 3 stars but the grilled chicken and japchae (noodles) are great. Brown rice is kinda plain but goes down ok with sauce and kimchi. It's pricey but portions are HUGE. Much as I like it, I can't eat it  ALL the time so I'm looking for an alternative... I tried the kalbi too but the chicken is better

Food court gets packed at lunch time.
author: pj n.

description: *This place is so lame, don't know why it has three stars, terrible service and my unresolved father issues mean ! They will give the order you want and you think its  right..but when you pay at the counter its all different. you just ended up paying instead of arguing ! not only once ..twice ..many times i dont know why i keep coming back! assuming the manager already solved those past issues! but still the same!  WILL NOT BE COMING BACK.
author: Meda V.

description: As the Westfield Centre was closing I wasn't in the mood to have a full dining experience elsewhere. I asked my wife to pick up something quick at the food courts. She picked Sorabol! I never heard of this place, but from its front it is your typical food court format. You pick a combination plate with items available. I have no idea exactly what I had, but it included two main dishes. One was pork and the other was squid. Both were cooked in the same red spicy sauce. It came with brown rice and clear noodles called chap chae. Also, you get unlimited kim chee! Is this authentic Korean? I doubt it, but man it was good. I love food that can break a sweat. I was chugging down Asahi beer to wash down the fire!
author: Gene B.

description: One of my go-to places at the Westfield mall. I like the free kimchi, what can I say. I usually get the bulgogi or the short ribs. Not very authentic korean, but the portion sizes are nice. Combos come with japchae or rice and steamed veggies. And did I mention the unlimited free kimchi? I tried their soondubu once and it was not good. Don't get that.
author: Sherry L.

description:
This place is awesome. I can never go wrong with the BBQ chicken with noodles only. they always give you enough for two meals so its worth the $10 bucks. 
line moves super fast. 

one of my regular places for lunch
author: Blake R.

description: i think this mall has one of the greatest food court choices.  sorabol being my fav place in this madhouse.  for about $10 you get lots of noodle and two diff meats and a couple piece of broccoli.  the meats are goooood.  spicy pork really has a kick to it.  lemon chicken has a kick to it too.  always a long line so you know the food has good turn over.  never just sits there.  also sells ramen.  gotta try it next time.  i keep saying I'm gonna try a diff place when i go to the food court but i keep returning here. i just know what i like.  they used to give out kim chee in containers but now they just put it on your plate.  maybe too many people taking handfuls.  long lines but they go by quick.  fast food korean! wooooo
author: Matthew G.

description:
I know it's fast food Korean - whatever, we love it! We took the BART from SFO to home in San Francisco yesterday and stopped at the San Francisco Shopping Center for our favorite quick dinner, baggage and all. 

We always get half and half glass noodles and rice with BBQ chicken and short ribs, plus we always order the salad plate with all the pickled vegetables and kimchee. We ate to our hearts' content and we'll be back over and over again! Yummy! :)
author: Maile N.

description:
Not bad if you need a quick bite to eat while at the mall.

But it is not Korean. food.  Cooked meat with some sort of brown sweet sauce is not Korean food.  I had the kalbi rib which was a bit chewy and dry, but they were generous with the portion.  The tofu soup was not bad, again generous with the portion.  

This is basically mall fast food, but at premium fast food prices, it is really hard to give this place much more than 2 stars.  Probably better to go to bristol farms and grab a snack in a  pinch.  At least it would be somewhat healthy.
author: Scott C.

description: While waiting in a very long line, a couple behind me was sharing the BBQ Chicken dinner from Sorabol. After my long a fruitless wait, I made a bee line for Sorabol and ordered exactly what the couple was eating. Everything tasted as expected, there were no lines, and the kim chee was plentiful.
author: Monica S.

description:
Obscene portions?: check
Nuclear levels of spiciness?: check
Absurdly low prices?: check
Excellence in mediocrity?: check
More effective than taking ex-lax?: double-check
author: Laurence W.

description: Wow. Amazing! I will be coming back to this mall just to eat here. 2 item combo under $11.00 and the quality and flavors are there! Everything is great ! Try it all ! Lots of food! I bet you you cant finish it all in one sitting!
author: Roman J.

description:
As a korean shopping for good gear in Westfield it's always nice to find a restaurant of our motherland.

That said eating at Sorabol was like another meaningless quest chain....(you know! one of those where the rewards hardly make up the effort)

Notes ~ Big portions but I would've traded quantity for quality in this case. The pork bulgogi was quite average and its sauce bled everywhere on the plate and the heaping rice and kimchi couldn't resuscitate this meal.  
We're going to need a medic.
author: Daniel K.

description: Had Korean breakfast here, it was pretty good and fast. The staff were friendly and helpful. There was too much food for me to finish, which is a good thing. I would have asked for extra sauce.
author: Jonah K.

description:
Sorabol Korean Restaurant.  For the first time in ages, I'm at a loss for words.  Not much to say about this place.  If you're at SF Centre or the Westfield Mall and craving Korean, it's the only game in town or at least in the complex.

Food won't blow you away, but does the job.  Kalbi isn't too bad and I like the marinade/sauce they use, although I always end up wishing they gave you more.  Then again, I'm a meataholic so your mileage may vary.  The serve yourself kim chi at the end is an interesting novelty.  Some people miss it, but others seem to load up on it.

Sadly, it's still one of the better offerings in a disappointing food court that has high aspirations, but could be so much more, especially for San Francisco.  With a few exceptions, once you get past the newness (not new anymore), this whole food court for me has been a culinary letdown.
This food court could be a proud showcase of the best local foodie finds that San Francisco has to offer, all in one convenient location for visitors to discover.  Sadly, this is not the case.
author: Roy N.

description:
Please don't waste your appetite, money or time eating here. 

-Their menu & menu prices don't seem to match what they actually give or charge you, so make sure you check!!

-The food is mediocre "food court" food.

-The prices are not cheap for what you get.

Bottom line: if you are craving Korean food, go down to Geary Blvd. and try one of the MUCH better options out in the Inner Richmond district. The food is soooo much better, it is a much better deal, you get MORE food and vegetable side dishes, and just slightly more in price.
author: Mari S.

description:
It's ok, I guess, but nothing too special/flavorful and not that great of a value, really. 

Good for kids and wheelchair accessible! Easy to get to BART and Muni! So, you see, it has something going for it.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Before we get to the food, there was this: While I was waiting for my dish a woman came to the counter, was handed a noodle bowl, sat down, and took a bite or two. After a moment she carried her bowl back to the counter; apparently it was the wrong dish. They handed her a new bowl and she went away. 

So I approached the counter, pointed to the bowl she had brought back, and asked, "Was that my dish?" The guy behind the counter picked it up and said yes, it is, here you go, and started to hand it to me. 

Um, no. 

"You served that to her and she started to eat it and then brought it back. I don't want that, thank you." The guy looked a little surprised - I can't imagine why - and there was a brief huddle with a cook, who then bustled about to heat the noodles and vegetables while I wondered whether to just walk away. But what the heck, they were making a new dish, I had paid already, so I decided just to go with it.. "Sorry", the guy said, as he handed me the new dish. 

I had, of course, already resolved never to return, no matter how good the food might be; that was just stunningly weird, and probably broke a health code or two. 

And then I tried the food: Spring roll, crispy but greasy. Broccoli, barely warmed and practically freezing at the core. Noodles, gummy and in several places stuck together in clumps of a dozen or more, and covered thickly in a sickly sweet gummy brown sauce. 

Enough - I bused my dish (this is a food court, after all) and got a sandwich from Bristol Farms. It was okay.

If you go to Sorabol, good luck - and watch your food.
author: Geoffrey C.

description:
The hot dishes here are pretty good, and it's nice that they include japchae as a side dish, but do NOT get the soups here... and most importantly, do NOT get the noodle soup.

It takes forever to prepare, and all they do is throw a bunch of raw vegetables, cold noodles, and what I can only presume is frozen seafood into a bowl, pour some watered down spicy broth over it, and serve it to you.

Korean cuisine is famous known for its flavorful spicy soups, and this place butchers it.

That being said, the rest of the meat entrees are pretty satisfactory. I'd go there for that, but if you're looking for some delicious kimchijigae or yukgaejjang, I'd invest the time to find a sit down Korean place outside of the mall.
author: Huan L.

description: Pretty good variety especially when you get the vegetable bowl. I counted over ten variety of vegetables and they serve brown rice. You can even choose spicy or non spicy tofu to go with the dish. All for under $10.
author: Rrr X.

description: Food tasted okay but was just-out-of-the-fridge cold. Or maybe the steam table wasn't working? Not impressed.
author: V. R.

description:
The place is decent for fast food when you are limited in choices and craving Korean. I won't lie, during my days working at this mall, I came here often. It personally doesn't taste like authentic Korean food to me, but it's decent enough. I don't like getting the meat unless you know it's fresh off the grill. Or else it's hard and chewy. 

They used to let you take your own Kimchi which was great, I would take 3 or 4 for just myself. But recently they stopped doing that, so now you have to ask. Probably because of people like me. STILL! That was the best part of my visits here.

Price is decent. A tad high for a mall.

Service was okay.

Doesn't ever get too busy.
author: Natasha S.

description: I like the lemon chicken and the noodles or rice.  There are a few things that are hit or miss but it is good for the basics.  They have a good amount of choices and it is always fresh.  The potstickers are also very good.  They are always pleasant and the line moves quickly.
author: Lyndsey C.

description: It's a food court. Please don't expect much. For a food court, the food is pretty good. They give you a nice amount of rice, noodles, and what you order on the most part. Sometimes, the person there is cheap and doesn't give me very much. I always get white rice, japchae (so yummy, but more noodle and less vegetables please!), and the sliced beef (bulgogi). The ladies who worked there weren't very nice, but I guess it's because they work all day at a really loud food court. They never offer me the kimchee, but that's okay because I never want it anyway.
author: Victoria L.

description: I've recently been a healthy-eating Nazi so I try to stay as far away from food courts and fast food as humanly possible. Of course every now and then I need to feed my soul something that isn't green or free range to sustain my sanity, that's when I pop into Sorabol. It's the perfect nourishment after trudging through the Westfield Mall. The portions are hearty and the food tastes very good by food court standards. I would recommend getting the BBQ short ribs with just japchae (the clear noodles with vegetables). The meal comes with broccoli and a tiny side of kimchi as well. The ribs are very chewy and flavorful, but I wouldn't say the meat is of the best quality if you're not into chunks of fat. Their meals are a great value since they suffice me for a meal and a half.
author: Charlotte Z.

description:
Since I was nearby, I had a craving for the 5 start BBQ Chicken in a Bowl with Stir Fried Chow Mein Noodles and Vegetables that I can get at the Sorabol in Rincon Annex http://www.yelp.com/biz/sorabol-korean-restaurant-san-francisco-2

This was my first time at this location and I ordered the same thing to go.  At least that was my plan...

Well, while the chicken was good as always, burried under it was a bunch of Jap Chae (clear cellophane noodles made from sweet potato starch) and hardly any vegetables!  Yuck!  Compared to the excellent stir fried noodles at the other location, this was a major disappointment.

I sort of feel sorry for all the people that eat at this location that never know how good this dish can really taste.  I even had to wait a few minutes while they were freshly cooking the Jap Chae noodles!

Next time, I'll see if I can get stir fried chow mein noodles instead.  If not, there's no point for me to eat there.
author: Roy C.

description: Food is amazinnnnng! Definitely recommend this place to go to in SF! Will definitely come back.
author: Raejean N.

description: Not authentic but you can get dumplings, cellophane noodles, lots of broccoli and a heap of meat with a dash of Korean flavor for a reasonable price.  And if you're like me and can basically only eat Asian food, there aren't many other options in the Westfield food court.  Sorabol hits the spot just fine.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I know what you are thinking. Is this guy seriously going to send me to a food court in a shopping mall for some interesting Asian food? Yes, that's the plan.

Mall food courts usually have the obligatory Sbarro and the Subway that is also appearing even more frequently than Starbucks these days. So, one can be assured that the food will be the lowest common denominator of food. It will be bland enough that it won't offend any palette. Heaven forbid a bold flavor shake anyone up. Keep it simple and boring and our Walmart culture won't be put off by the food.

That is why Sorabol is such a find at the Westfield Centre. I've grabbed a quick bite there on a few occasions and been pleasantly surprised by the bold flavors and fresh ingredients. The spicy beef soup actually is spicy and painfully delish! The housemade kimchee they provide with it adds a nice added kick as well. 

The spicy calamari comes in a very bold sauce served with glass rice noodles and rice. It's actually quite a meal and, though the flavor is fantastic, I haven't actually finished one yet. This is fresh calamari in a sizzling great sauce. There's no breading, no dip. This isn't a pub appetizer. It's a very pleasing seafood dish.

To set expectations, you will stand in line and your food will be given to you on a plastic tray. If you need someone in a black mock turtleneck to give you your Asian fare with a little attitude, then just head on over to the Slanted Door in the Ferry Building. The food court is not going to do it for you. If you do decide to stay at Sorabol, you will collect your tray of goodness and then wander around looking for someplace to sit in the busy food court. But, the flavors will be worth it. You'll sit there thinking, "Am I really eating this in a mall?"

Having recently eaten at a big deal Tyler Florence restaurant with a big deal price tag, I can tell you that I honestly enjoyed the bite I had at Sorabol the following week much more than anything I tasted at Tyler's place. 

If you are in the city and looking for a quick, interesting and affordable bite, I recommend Sorabal. I think you'll be pleasantly surprised.
author: Eric W.

description: Well DUH this isn't "real" Korean food, but when is mall food ever 100% authentic?  Sorabol is my boyfriend and I's guilty/hungover pleasure.  Sure they give a ton of food, but I mean, I eat almost all of it, so whatever.  I LOVE their japchae.  If it weren't for the fact that a plate it is $9, I'd probably just get the noodles.  I usually get their BBQ chicken, and it's consistently been well cooked, flavorful, and tender.  It's obviously not something that I'd like to make a habit out of doing, but when I'm shopping and trying to resolve some of my hangover with retail therapy, I'll gladly wait in line at Sorabol.
author: Lisa I.

description:
This mall location isn't as stingy as the other malls I've been to.

I ordered the BBQ chicken and wasn't satisfied with the amount of chicken they gave me, so, I asked for more--they happily loaded my tray with more chicken and spoonfuls of their sauce.
author: Juliette R.

description: Found this place at the Westfield mall off Market st. Decided to order a 2 combo plate Spicy chicken beef short ribs w rice & noodles.My wife and I enjoyed this together for the price it was good and the portion was just enough.
author: Anthony Z.

description: This place used to have great chicken noodle soup, and I don't know if a new manager came on board, but the last time I got it, there was pretty much no chicken in the chicken noodle soup. Don't waste your time if you actually want chicken in your chicken noodle soup.
author: Amy M.

description: They have a good range of option and the bowls are a good portion for the price. Stop by here about once every other week for lunch. Warning though, their spicy choices is really spicy.
author: Vincent P.

description:
If you want truly authentic Korean food, go elsewhere.

But for what it's worth, as a food court restuarant. It was pretty tastey and portion size was very generous. My $8 or $9 dollars for a full plate of food was sufficent for 2 meals worth. However, I was left wanting a little bit more. I mean, this was -supposed- to be a Korean restuarant, right?

The only thing Korean about it was the kimchi they offered and that half assed Jap chae.
author: Ray W.

description:
I could eat their japchae all day long.  I always get the two item combo for about $11. Grilled chicken and Kalbi but today they offered a stewed Kalbi.  WOW!!  It was really good.  The chunks of meat were tender but their sauce was a little sweeter than I would have like it.  Avoid their complimentary "kimchee"  they'll tell you its 1 per person.  They couldn't pay me to eat that stuff.

They use to be generous with their portions because I could never finish it.  Now I can knock it out in one sitting.

The staff is always friendly.  Lets work on consistency folks.
author: Sun T.

description:
Awful customer services.
 After i told this one asian lady that i want rice, spicy pork, and sliced beef, she totally skipped my order. I never recieve my order so i ask her again. She did not apologize and gave me a really bad attitude said" i already gave you the plate" , both of my hands were obviously EMPTY....In normal circumstance, a food server would just give you another plate right away without argument, but she decided to keep giving me attitude instead of my food until this latino lady start doing it for her......
If i wasn't in a rush for interview i would have move on to the thai food next door with long lines..umm maybe because they have better food and customer services.
author: elly l.

description: Awesome for a regular food court - but in this one you've got to step up the game more. Had the seafood noodle bowl spicy. The noodles were horrible and sticky. Pot stickers at .65 each were great though- earning an extra star from me.
author: Michael K.

description:
Stopped in for a quick lunch.

No rice, no noodles but got served a mountain of BBQ chicken and broccoli instead. Low carb delight! 

Will repeat.
author: Jase O.

description: Located inside the awesome food court under the Westfield, this is the best Sorabol location I've been to.  The food is good here, specifically the BBQ Chicken plate.  The portions are pretty big, although you pay the price.  The only off part would maybe be the fact that the chicken is dry sometimes.  Will come back.
author: Brian C.

description: The food here is delicious! If you are in the west field mall food court...come here and have some food! I had the beef and it tasted amazing! The juice from the meat and kimchi was mixed in with the rice and it created delicious flavor!!!!i totally recommend this place.
author: Olivia A.

description:
FAST FOOD korean food. It's not bad for what it is and you definitely get your moneys worth because the size of the plate is just GINORMOUS. I was able to force myself to eat a little more than half an order, which placed me into a minor food coma. 

The food is good, don't get me wrong, BUT the BBQ chicken and the japchae was just too sweet for what it should be. 

MESSAGE to Sorabol: I'm not trying to be a diabetic! But thanks for the offer?
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
Eat like Chris Farley.
Eat like Orson Welles.
Eat like Nicole Richie.
Oh wait...dead, dead and terminally thin...
Eat it...eat it...open up your mouth and feed it!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jw00EUh0GT4

Yes, it's possible to relive your favorite all-you-can-eat experience at Sorabol where you can get the world's largest serving of BBQ Chicken with a major dollop of rice, a pile of sauce-soaked cellophane noodles, and a few sprigs of broccoli to calm your conscience for the reasonable price of $8.95. OK, it's not the world's largest serving, but it's pretty big....and for me to admit that, well, that's a big deal, trust me.

And yet, you need to get to this place at the right time in order to avoid lukewarm food as the mounds of chicken sit in a precarious pile above the actual warmer. Hit it at the right time, and you'll be set not only for lunch but for dinner and for the Nigella Lawson-patented midnight snack at the fridge. You can just forget about getting that Beard Papa cream puff now.

Given the multitude of mediocre choices in the Westfield food court, I have to put Sorabol high on the list. I am a bit biased since I was a fan when they had the one restaurant on Grand Avenue near Lake Merritt in Oakland. They have compromised themselves discernibly since they made themselves a local mall-based chain, but I still keep coming back. I'm loyal that way.

FOOD - 3.5 stars...big portions...no, BIG PORTIONS...and good, hearty stuff if you're there at the right time
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...it's the mall, dude....fer sure
SERVICE - 3 stars...scoop the rice and pass it down
TOTAL - 3 stars...I'll leave it at 3 for now, best as a lunch option...hope you didn't have breakfast
author: Ed U.

description: The food looks good on the menu and the price was right for the Westfield Mall but what they gave me was a big plate of room temperature slop.
author: Manny F.

description:
I work around here and anytime I dont bring home lunch ( Meaning my mom doesnt feel like cooking ), 80% of the time I would go here. Considering theres like 100 other places I can go to around here for lunch, it says alot. 

Since this is a "pick and go" joint, you cant really rate their services but the food is 5 stars because I am addicted to their spicy chicken. Yes, its expensive...almost $8 dollars but they give you enough to eat it for lunch and have some for dinner. Simple math says thats $4 for lunch and $4 for dinner.....winner winner spicy chicken dinner.
author: Viet N.

description: There's something appealing about a big plate of rice topped with heaps of meat when in a mall setting... The food isn't exactly gourmet, but there's a lot of it. I like my savory food on the sweet side and this place satisfies that pet peeve, and then some. Even for me, the beef stew and pork are a bit sweet, but they're fully seasoned. This is the type of food that I want on a rainy day. There's a time and place for this type of food, maybe once every quarter. It's comforting and filling. See you in 2 months!
author: Alice W.

description:
I'm Korean and this is the closest thing resembling Korean food around where I live.

It's cheap, it's hearty, it tastes like Korean food.

I love the free kimchi and the noodle (jab che) is pretty damn good too.

Definitely not bad for mall court Korean food.
author: kevin l.

description:
The food here looked really good from where I was standing behind the counter top. I ordered the BBQ Beef plate which came with rice, clear noodles, beef, and veggies. My plate was overflowing with food, I knew I wouldn't be able to eat it all, but maybe I'd have leftovers for dinner later which was nice.

Uh no. It was terrible. I ate maybe half and threw the rest away. The beef tasted dry and flavorless, and was so fatty it was hard to cut. The broccoli was undercooked and very crunchy. The rice was okay, but the food was all so dry that I couldn't really get much flavor mixed in with the rice. The noodles were just disgusting, I hardly ate those.

I got so sick of eating my food that I actually felt like I was going to throw up if I ate any more of it. I walked out feeling completely unsatisfied, sick, and grossed out. I won't be eating here again. No way.
author: Ashley D.

description: The food court on the Bloomies side is actually really nice. With that being said, skip Sorabol and eat at one of the other places. The food is mediocre at best and it's not even that affordable. They do give a good portion but what I hate is a lot of the dishes are very greasy. If you're really craving Korean you might be okay with it, but otherwise it's not worth it. I recommend Buckhorn or Catch Isle. If you walk to the Nordstrom side there is Ajisen ramen and Chipotle.
author: Alice J.

description:
I'm half Korean, and my mother is a great cook. So I suppose this makes me a bit of a snob when it comes to Korean food. I've had plenty of hit and miss experiences with it in the Bay Area, and unfortunately, I'd have to call this one a miss. 

I was in the mall, and my mom was craving some kimchi, so we decided to stop here. The line was huge, so I figured they must be doing something right. 

They have a big steam table with all sorts of options. We decided to split the 2-item combination plate, which comes with rice, jap chae (clear noodles), and literally 3 pieces of broccoli. We chose the BBQ beef ribs and chicken. We only got one rib and one piece of chicken that was burnt on the outside and undercooked on the inside. The rib was really fatty and rubbery. 

They do have a clear plastic box full of little cups of kimchi which you can help yourself to, but it didn't taste right. Kind of bland, maybe? Not up to snuff. We paid almost $11, and nothing on the plate was delicious. 

Sorry, Sorabol. Pretty horrible.
author: Brandi W.

description:
Matt and wife ate at the busy and lively food-court at Westfield Mall for dinner. She checked the Sorabol Korean Restaurant out!

She got a one-item dinner containing the popular Barbeque Lamb over rice. She enjoyed it very much. Matt had a bite of the item, and likewise it was very flavorsome and tasty. The Kim-Chee was very tasty as well. On the hot-counter, it looked arid, and since it was dinner, the foods fly-by quickly. We don't have to worry about food sitting in the counter for long-extended time. The meal including diet-cola was a pretty good deal for about $10.00.
author: Matt G.

description:
Let's go straight to the point: food quality is poor, customer service is away, prices are too high compared with what you get for it (worst quality / price ever). Mushrooms tasted javel water (yes, really), the whole plate was cold (like cold out of the fridge) - how is it possible with the heaters supposed to keep the food warm?, beef was cut with very small pieces of bones (ideal if you want it in your throat), and I don't even talk about the rice.
The two of us did not finish our dishes and we will definitely never come back again.
author: Damien G.

description:
4 stars for solid food court fare. 
It's all about the chap chae! Luckily it comes included with any 1 or 2 item entree. The chicken bbq and soft tofu are also very good!

Damn I love the mall especially the food court ;)
author: Helen Y.

description:
While the Emporium food court is slick...it's still a mall and thus, this is considered mall food.

So, I am basing this review on the following:

1)  Popularity with fellow patrons (ie: whose line is the longest)
2)  Portion to Cost ratio
3)  Tastiness to Cost ratio

1 - Sorabol is a clear winner.  Very tough competition.  I think that the other restaurants are just a bit too chic.  Sorabol is like a taste of your more ghetto, less shiny mall at home (in my case, Newpark, which used to have a Sorabol).

2 - For 8 bucks, you get a HUGE portion of rice, chap chae and some meat.  And, best of all, UNLIMITED kim chee.  Well, you're probably supposed to only take one...but PFFT, self-serve = unlimited.  I usually ask for double chap chae because I think it's actually some of the best I've had - greasy, but not TOO greasy.  

3 - Granted this isn't Brothers or Han Il.  But, you're paying a fraction of the cost for a good, solid meal that provides enough energy for a few more hours of shopping and doesn't make your tummy hurt.  The chicken is pretty tender and they don't overdoes the sauce.  I like that it comes with broccoli because it makes me feel like I'm eating "healthily".  I've also had the fish ball soup - again, a HUGE serving with tasty broth.  Not such a fan of the thicker noodles though.

So, in conclusion...this place is a great alternative to some of the other stuff in SOMA.  One day, when I'm feeling braver, I'll try the other places...
author: Helen F.

description:
Ditto to what Ed U. said: http:www.yelp.com/biz/sorabol-korean-restaurant-san-francisco-3#hrid:9wf-YbUjxf5OhL_hSOLgTw  . He just posted exactly what I wanted to say, but managed to write it last week. Nicely played sir. Plus he's way more eloquent than I ...

Anywhoo, they give you a huge serving of fresh bbq meat, atop a pile o' rice, with a big side of tasty cellophane noodles, some conscience soothing broccoli, and free kim-chee.

I went with the Gal-Bee and a diet-coke for $10 and change. They were delish. I'm a sucker for  those BBQ beef ribs, and Sorabol had a very competent interpretation (and a generous serving hand).

I wish they offered a half-order for $7, I could never finish what they gave me.

For mall food, this was actually pretty damned good!
author: Aaron M.

description:
Tofu soup craving strikes again. Luckily I was at Westfield SF, and Sorabol was there to deliver the goods. I was expecting it to come bubbling in one of those bowls they serve to you at regular Korean restaurants (you know, the ones they say don't touch, it's hot!). This was served in a plain bowl, albeit a large portion (for me). Comes with a side of rice for less than $8.00. Spicy and tasty. Good amount of seafood included. I wish they had some free banchan for "for here" orders. I also ordered a side of japchae. Simple, nothing fancy. Homemade is always better.

Always a little wary with mall food courts, but Sorabol is worth checking out for Korean fare.
author: Carolyn J.

description:
Expensive and gross.

For over $10 I had the two item combo, and while tipping the scales at over a pound, I could hardly make a dent.  The beef was sooo fatty, the chicken gristly, and the noodles gross.  I ate my scoop of rice and three pieces of broccoli and then glanced longingly at all the other delish options in the food court that I could have
author: Meagan C.

description:
Before watching Captain America with the boy, we stopped at the food court to grab some dinner. The smells of BBQ from Sorabol immediately made our decision on what to eat!

We both got the two-combination plate - it came with rice (I got steamed rice) and noodles, and I chose the lemon chicken and a side of potstickers. They are reallllllyyyy generous with the food portions - a mound of lemon chicken and three huge potstickers...oh my! I guess it was worth the price since the combination plate was about $10.

The rice was rice, nothing special. The noodles, I didn't really care for and kind of grossed me out. The lemon chicken was good, sweet yet spicy. The potstickers were good, but also nothing special. It was all pretty filling, but I felt like overall it could have been so much better.

I think this is a good option for lunch/dinner AFTER shopping, because honestly, I wouldn't want to eat all of that and then continue shopping and trying on clothes. I felt horrible after! TOO much food. I also feel like it's kind of out of place with the rest of the food options on this side of the mall. Everything else seems like "higher end" food options, when this place is also found at other malls like Stonestown.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Typical type of food here I got the rice along with the chicken and they give you some vegetables. It fills you up but nothing really stands out. There are better options out there in the food court especially buckhorn for there tri tip but if your craving some Korean go for it and get it nothig wrong with that. Overall food is food so if I'm ever in the mood I might come back again and get some .
author: Leonard I.

description: Being a vegetarian, my options were limited. I got the vegetable bowl with Tofu and didn't like the Tofu part... it was in a sauce which barely had any taste. Their kimchi was okay and. Rest of the bowl was pretty decent with a lot of veggies, noodles and rice. The intoxicating flavor of sesame oil on a hot plate that draws me to Korean places even though I don't have many options was missing and becasue of that, this place will only get 3 stars. Overall not bad considering it's in a food court of a mall.
author: Ravi C.

description: Food is alright. I've had better Korean food. But then again what can you ask from a food court. Customer service sucks. First of all, it took her forever to be ready for me to pay. Then I asked her for water she didn't respond the first time and then the second time I asked she responded with the rudest tone and said "go ahead!" Then I realized the glass cups were hidden on the side...you can barely see it. Would appreciate it if she told me it's self-served and the cups are on the side. RUDE. She needs to be fired.
author: Ptc C.

description: Good kimchi. Sorabol was the first Korean restaurant I've eaten at and since then, whenever I see a Sorabol I've to eat there.  my favorite is their spicy pork, not to spice and not to bland. just perfect for my taste.  its I can only eat Sorabol when I'm in SF or Emeryville.
author: Rico L.

description: Mmm.. fab food.  They have little kimchi containers for you to pick up after you get your food, grab as many as you like... or at least I think you can hehe.
author: Ravo Y.

description: For being in a mall and being a fast food Korean Establishment its really hard to give a good or bad review on them. The staff are very polite and even remember my face when I come and order some short ribs from them. Its a little pricy......, but it doesnt really surprise me though its in a mall and not supposed to be super fancy or anything. The Short Ribs are hit or miss though. Sometimes they are great other times the line is so long that they really are not cooked as long as most people like them to be.
author: Kyle R.

description:
WARNING: Unsanitary dishes and utensils!!! My glass had lipstick marks. The spoon I took was actually 2 joint spoons glued in some old black residue of who knows what. The 3rd spoon I picked was still not clean, same with the fork. 

Today's special: I had no idea Wonton soup was Korean...

I will not go back. I love Korean cuisine but this place made me sick and the only Korean thing about it is the kimchi.
author: Isa M.

description:
I know this is the mall food version of Korean, and under that premise, I like it.

They have them everywhere but they all seem to taste just as good at every location. I always want to order every variety of meat! Their spicy food is actually spicy and has a lot of flavor, i mean seriously --- this place is a bargain and it is so good (keep it in the context of mall food)! (have i lost my credibility on asian food now?)

There are nothing but positive points here: cheap, big portions, full of flavor, very filling, their assembly-line service is so quick, and they give you extra kim chi if you ask.
author: Stella C.

description:
Decent for mall food!

Spicy pork - flavorful, but on the dry side
BBQ chicken - good taste
Tofu soup - A-ok
author: Coco L.

description:
This is exactly what you sh/would expect from Korean food in a mall food court. Well, not just any food court--the Bloomingdale's food court (yuppie-uppity voice). I know better, but I've been craving Korean food something fierce ever since eating at Han Il Kwan. I needed it. Real bad. 

What $9 will get you: what seems like 2 pounds of rice, clear noodles, beef, and vegetables in a plastic bowl...oh, and a little dish of kimchi. Sounds good, right? It would be if it weren't 2/3lb of rice, 2/3lb of noodles, 1/3lb of vegetables, 1/6lb of beef, and 1/6lb of FAT. Literally, half of what was to be passed off as meat was inedible! The actual meat was tough, dry, and flavorless--like it had been sitting out all day in the sun. 

Oh, I ate it, all right. I ate it all (sans 1/6lb of fat)...but I wasn't happy. I waddled out of the Westfield 1.83lbs + 3oz (damn you, Beard Papa) heavier, $12 lighter, with my head held high and my gut spillin' out of my pants.
author: Kristine W.

description: I LOVE this place! They give large portions at a very reasonable price and have excellent customer service. They gave so much in my to-go plate I have enough for lunch tomorrow!
author: Jenn D.

description: I've been here twice before and both times I got the 2 item entree with Spicy Pork, Jap Chae, and Beef. The portions are pretty big, but then again it costs like $11. I guess for that food court this isnt considered TOO expensive. The Jap Chae is really good. The spicy pork is good but a little salty. Everything here is pretty legit but I walk away feeling kinda gross because I guess the food is pretty greasy.
author: Isabella L.

description: The only decent Korean place in the shopping area. The lines prove it
author: M C.

description:
The chicken lord giveth, and the chicken lord taketh away. I feel like I ate here once, and I can never eat here again. I felt like a gluttonous meat sloth after I was done! The portions are huge!

I am not shy in my love for Korean BBQ, or the mall (sometimes). I run my errands during lunch, I do some shopping or I work out, and then, I get famished. Sometimes, a goddamn Lee's Deli sandwich ain't gonna cut it when I'm in the FiDi heading back to my desk.

Oh, I had seen Sorabol, I heard about it, I smelled it and dodged eye contact with it on my way to Coriander, my beloved mall food court Thai messenger. I felt so sorry for myself that I never got a bowl of this funky chicken or veggies that everyone speaks of at Sorabol. So one day I did.

The service was indeed fast and friendly and generous. Gotta love the free kimchi. It was ok, even really tasty at times. And I ate. I ate. And I ate at my desk bite after bite of bbq chicken, thick, chunky broccoli and some rice splashed with teriyaki sauce. And then I fitfully passed out head first into my keyboard, the space bar lodged above my eyebrows. I knew I had to end it. 

It was cheap, fast and good, albeit a bit much for me to handle. I probably won't be back out of sheer guilt and the fact that I am trying to eat less and less meat. But, at least I can say I've been there. And I conquered.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Huge portions - Two people can get full off of one 2-item combo! Their spicy BBQ chicken is good (although a little too much red sauce) and so are their spare ribs and lemon chicken. Beef and broccoli is okay. I usually ask for half rice, half noodles (because I can't make up my mind). They pile it on pretty high. With a drink, we've spent about $10 - not bad for two people. If you're eating alone, you'll have enough for dinner or lunch the next day. The food court is always crowded, even at 2pm on a weekday, so thelines are long but they move fast.

It's a buffet, hot-plate type setup but it's pretty decent, especially for the price.
author: Mariela D.

description:
It was alright.
I like the one at Stonestown better.

I go the makrel plate - rice, vermicelli noodles, 2 small pieces of fish and 3 stalks of broccli.  The fish was great - maybe a bit oily but makrel is like that, the rice was calrose not long grain and I love calrose,  the vermicelli didn't have much flavor.  

I also got 2 potstickers.  Too much dough, and the meat was good.  But I like my potstickers fried/crunchy a little on the outside.  This wasn't.  I think it was steamed.  

Pricey too!!  A lot pricier than the other mall locations.
author: Erika G.

description:
This place is excellent for the bbq short ribs and chicken.  You get a really big portion and it is quite tasty for the style of food it is.

Every time I am in this mall it has the longest line and that is for good reason.  I will definately be coming back.
author: James H.

description:
Geez.  I should have looked at the logo, I was lured in by my colleague & my hunger pangs.  

I swear this place is a normal mall food courts.  

SF center has WAY better food than a normal mall.  

Dammit.  

It was alright.  Price was right, fed me twice today, but dude, where's the heat?!?!
author: Cynthia C.

description: #sorabol #koreanfood. I know it's fast food but this food was horrible. I ordered spicy pork and chicken, both were cool and not warm. The spicy pork was very mushy (almost undercooked)  with more than any reasonable amount of fat on the spicy pork. Nasty. I eat Korean food often and this was the worst I've ever had. FTR: I ate inside the food court. Not again will I order food from here.
author: Danny R.

description: I guess is okay.. Is like a fast-food for Korean foods! Is good when u got no time n Ur super hungry! :)
author: Lala B.

description:
I would probably liken it to Panda Express but Korean and better.  You can get full off of a two-entree plate.  I had the fried rice/noodles, spicy pork, and tofu.  I thought the spicy pork was very good and I wished I had more.  They gave plenty of tofu, which I could barely finish.  I also had the leftover BBQ chicken that my mom gave me because she couldn't finish her plate.  It was ok.  I felt satisfied with the portions.

We came in right before dinner time and the line was very short.  We got served pretty quickly.

It isn't too hard to find this place.  It's just in the Food Emporium on the Concourse level of the mall.
author: Roger M.

description:
The lines for this place was really long... I thought it would be good, but it turned out to be okay. They have the korean bbq meats you would normally find such as bbq chicken, bulgogi (bbq beef), kalbi (bbq short ribs), bbq spicy pork, etc. The lunch combo comes with rice, noodles, and one meat. 

The bbq chicken tasted okay. It wasn't anything too great. Same for the rice and noodles. I had better at korean restaurants... this place is like korean fast food in a way. Cheaper than an authentic korean bbq restaurant but no way near the same quality.
author: Steven B.

description:
It's the cheapest place to get a quick Korean fix. I've had better, but in terms of the restaurants in the food court, this is one of the cheapest and well proportioned.

A good tip: If you go to SFSU or have an SFSU id show it and you get a 10% discount!
author: Jen L.

description:
If shopping gives you an appetite, then head straight for Sorabol (basement of Westfield).  The portions here are truly massive and pretty cheap...for $8-10 (depending on which items you choose) you get rice + Korean glass noodles + veggies + your choice of 1-2 meats (I'd recommend the beef with onions).  The portions are so huge that I'd strongly recommend you share them unless you're absolutely starving.

The food is very solid for food court standards (no, it's not "Brothers"-level Korean food, but it's tasty) and the staff are extremely efficient in getting you through and paid in just a few minutes.  Best of all, I don't think they use a ton of MSG...I tend to get bad MSG-headaches, and having eaten here a few times, I haven't noticed any.  Overall, love it!
author: Dominique N.

description: Fast, easy, somewhat delicious.  It's mall food again but I eat here 2 times for my stay here in SF.   When you are in a hurry and you want to eat something a step above panda express, but not quite Gordon Biersch, you come here.
author: Toby I.

description:
MmM.. Here's another food court restaurant with delicious food! I shared a chicken teriyaki and bbq beef ribs dish with my family. I realy like how the dish came with rice and vermicelli noodles! Yum! 

Cheap prices for two items ($8.95) and the large portion sizes.
author: Jackie S.

description:
It's all about context - this is mall food.  But this is pretty decent mall food - so much so that it's even been work lunch food on a couple of occasions.

When the mall is busy, the line is ridiculously long but compared to the other options in Westfield (or the San Francisco Shopping Centre), Sorabol is definitely one of the better options and worth waiting for.  If you are a big eater, the portions are huge, sickeningly big.  I don't know why my friend and I didn't share...but we didn't, and we each got our own chicken plate.  I ate all of mine (sadly) and she only ate half.  The chicken was good and filling, though the kimchee was underwhelming.  

But for $9, I'm not complaining!
author: Wendy L.

description:
KALBI ON STEROIDS with side dishes delite!

I've had better Asian and Korean food but everytime my girlfriends and I go shopping, catch a theatrical at Bindlestiff Studios, or watch a movie near Union Square we eat at the San Francisco Shopping Center Emporium (food court). I have tried other places to eat but I find myself coming to this place more often then the others. I enjoy their Kalbi with rice dish and love their sides. 

Think about it, alot of restaurants give boney Kalbi but this place gives alot of meat on their Kalbi. Kalbi on steroids? It's worth it. All less for $10 (including a drink to quench that thirst).
author: Jane A.

description:
I've been going to this Sorabol since the mall opened and they have never failed me. Though I think their food quantity decreased from 2 years ago. (I guess that's not a surprise considering we are in recession! - anyway, that's another topic...)

The boy and I have Thursday's as our "date-night" - rushed date night that is. We went here last Thursday - mall was packed but we managed to get a table. The boy ordered Kalbi with rice and veggies - we grubbed! We were both so hungry and it was good, tasty and still a decent amount of food.

Anyway, for the price, quantity and quality - this place gets a thumbs up in my book! 

PS: I've tried other Sorabol's from other malls and I don't know what it is, but this place is SOOO much better than the others. I guess they have to live up to the whole enigma of the mall and having Bloomingdale's next door.
author: Cath M.

description:
I wish I could give this place more like 3 1/2...

When this place first opened I really liked it - it seemed like everyone really liked it.  For some reason I get the feeling that the quality has gone a bit downhill.  If you do go, try the BBQ shortribs or BBQ lamb...I tried their newer lemon chicken and it was a bit weird...it didn't taste quite right.  The glass rice noodles are a good treat.,
author: Ken G.

description: When you think of a mall's food court, you usually think of mediocre fast food type eateries.  However, this isn't your average mall food court!  I've tried many of the places here and all of them are delicious!  Sorabol is definitely one of my favorites out of all the selections.  They have a good selection of meats (teriyaki chicken, bbq chicken, bbq beef, spicy chicken, spicy pork, short ribs, etc.), noodle soups, tofu stew, and other common Korean dishes. The prices are good for the amount of food they give you. They recently started offering a lunch box type option that includes one selection of meat, rice, noodles, spring rolls, potstickers, and broccoli. All for around $10. The kimchi is self-served so you can have as much as you want. Their food is really good for a fast food/food court eatery. My favorite is the beef short ribs but the BBQ chicken is quite tasty too.  Come try this place if you're ever in the area...you won't be disappointed!
author: Angela F.

description:
Bleh, it's whatever type of food. Way too overpriced. I think I paid $12 for a plate of food that did not even give sufficient amount of food. The location of this place is in a high end food court, but the food Sorabol serves was just not meeting up to par. I've seen Sorabol in other malls that offered ordinary mall food, so I expected this place to either be the same as the other Sorabols or up their game and offer better quality food because of its location. 

I got the bbq chicken and the bbq ribs with steam rice and 2 pot stickers on the side. The pot stickers were pretty nasty. I don't know why they were so wet and flavorless? The chicken and ribs were really dry! My dad makes better moist bbq than this place. Nothing else to say, but I should've gone to Coriander (next door to Sorabol) instead!
author: Katrina T.

description:
Sorabol tastes like Korean food that a non-Korean tries to make. I'm not digging non-Koreans who like to cook Korean food, but you have to have grown up with the flavors and textures to really know what you're doing. I also feel the same about any other ethnic cuisine, so I'm not being prejudiced here. 

I suppose, having grown up in LA with the best Korean food outside of Korea and my mom's kitchen, I'm a little spoiled and my standards are way too high, so I'll tone down my review.

If you're looking for a quick Korean food fix and you're at Westfield, hit up Sorabol. Get the jap-chae (the clear noodles with veggies) and...ok, that's really about it. It's one of the few authentic Korean dishes served there that they didn't entirely screw up. 

I don't think I can write anymore. I miss LA.
author: Christine P.

description: Best Korean food ever? No. Authentic? No. Still yummier than any other fast food in the mall? Definitely! It's flavorful and well-cooked and so much better than food court food.
author: Amy W.

description:
Great taste and very affordable compared to the prices of other eateries in the mall! I don't regret stopping by every so often  just for Westfield's Sorabol!

*I strongly recommend the Yu Kae Jang for under $8. If you finish this baby, I guarantee you 99% that you'll be stuffed! The spiciness is perfect -- not too spicy, not too mild. Their other foods also taste great!

However, I DO NOT recommend the Sorabol at Stonestown. I thought that they would serve in the same style and taste but I was horribly wrong. The food is not worth it at all there.
author: Jannet H.

description:
SORABOL
Located inside the Rinkon Center food court, Sorabol is a pretty decent Korean restaurant that is worth every expensive SF $. For $8, I had a two-item combo of BBQ beef and spicy pork over rice and noodles. Not the best Korean BBQ, but in terms of food court food, it stands out! The inside of the restaurant is quite nice and comfy-looking, but it's still more fun to dine outside in the food court itself. Great sauce! For $8, which is average price in SF, it's a great steal here for your mouth and stomach!
author: Stanley C.

description:
I had been to Sorabol at a another previous location and wasn't that thrilled with it. The meat was dry and that just left me feeling unsatisfied with my meal. 

However, when I have come across this location I always see how sizzling hot the food is and the workers just keep the food coming. The food every time looked good and fresh and every time that I came here passed by they had someone giving out samples previously. So as I was looking for something to eat recently I had stopped at Sorabol and the reviews that I read came to mine. As I looked and licked my lips and thought this food actually looks better than what was on display at the last Sorabol I went to. 

I gave in and got in line and remember that I had sampled the lemon chicken. So I went with that and I don't know if it was just me but the lemon chicken was quite spicy. But at the same time I thought I was eating generals chicken. Whatever,so I got egg rolls and I thought they tasted ok and the rest of my order consisted of white rice and broccoli. 

The food overall was quite pleasing unlike my last experience was just a little sadden by my hard broccoli. I tend to like them to soften it up a little bayou it taste better with all the sauces together and rice. 

Oh well. 

The Priscella watch what you get. It adds up. 

I'll be back to this location.
author: Dani D.

description: Just standard mall quality food here. Their food didn't blow me away but it was decent enough to fill me up. The spicy bbq chicken is pretty intense. They're not messing around when they say spicy. I could feel the burn. The sauce could've stood to be a little less salty on the chicken. I was so painfully thirsty when I finished my food. The sauce also had a slightly weird gritty texture to it. Don't come here expecting anything gourmet and you won't leave disappointed. It's basically a Korean version of Panda Express.
author: Nancy C.

description:
This review is just for the Spicy Beef Noodles.

Do not be deceived - these noodles are not spicy. Nor are they tasty. The soup is just red. A big disappointed MEH from me.
author: Genevieve W.

description: I love Sorabol's bbq chicken meal! I always order it when I'm there. It comes with a selection of delicious vermicelli, fried or jasmine rice, and broccoli. The portion is very big for 8.99 and I usually split it with a friend. Delicious and always satisfied!
author: Christina G.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy I got grease in my tummy...

I really like the clear noodles, though I often dwell upon that which makes them clear!

When I get sick of Buckhorn Grill (which does happen sometimes) I eat here. This place has "comfort food" stamped on its forehead. Forehead!
author: Rachel H.

description:
Mall food, what else would you expect? You get a lot of rice and meat for about $9. The meat is decent and you get little bowls of kim chi to take out. I personally think the Kim Chi is their selling point, it's not too crusty and old like a lot of restaurants have it its just the right soggy/crunchy level. 

The regular chicken is meh, the spicy chicken depends on the day and time you get in. Sometimes you get a fresh batch which is just delicious but sometimes you get an older batch which tastes dry and stringy. Always look to see which thing got a fresh dump before ordering.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Meh. Nothing spectacular to write home about except maybe a scribble here and there.

Been here three times now and have had:
1. Dak Gui (BBQ Chicken)
2. Dweg Gui (Spicy Pork)
3. Spicy Noodle
4. Yuck Ge Jang (Spicy Beef Soup)
4. Plate bowl entrees

Funny how each dish's name coincides with how I felt after eating it (dak! gui! yuck!).
