The food just lacks a certain richness, freshness, spice and flavor level that I've come to expect of Korean food. But then again, all its locations are in malls so perhaps an adjustment in expectations is necessary.

At the end of the day, it's mall food. 

If you're not fussy, its decent. 

If you're fussy, head to Korea Town or like me, take a holiday to Korea. AWESOME BLOSSOM!
author: Amit S.

description: Not really Korean food, more like Chinese food but their kimchi was good! This, I would call white ppl Korean food.
author: Yunah R.

description:
I avoided eating at this Sorabol for a long time because of the Sorabols I've eaten at before. Usually located in malls, every time I've eaten at one, all I've gotten was over-cooked meat. So no thank you is what I kept saying every time I visited the food court in the Westfield Center. However the past few times I came to Westfield with friends, they all ordered Sorabol, which I got to sneak bites of. Of course my first reaction was: this Sorabol can't be a Sorabol. No really. I'm serious. There is no way because the K-food here is hecka good for a Sorabol. Still in denial over it all, it's taken me about a month to write a review. I guess I'm finally coming to terms with it all.

This Sorabol serves up terrific Korean classics like kalbi, dak gui, kimchi for the hungry masses that descend upon the lower level of the Westfield  during lunch and dinner time. I ordered short rib stew special that came with a large pile of steamed broccoli, rice and chapchae. Damn that was good. 

Their portions were huge but still pricey at around $10 a pop. I'm not even gonna pretend like this is authentic good Korean food and insult all the Koreans out there reading this post, but damn it's great K-fast food. I kinda sympathize with Sorabol haters because as much as I hate and boycott PF Chang's for their complete bastardization of Chinese food, I still go to Panda Express for their yummy orange chicken. I am a complex woman with hypocritical food tastes. So sue me.

Other cool tidbits about this place is that they offer a self-serve pre-packed kimchi, the menu also includes soups and noodles, and even alternatives to the combo plate such as Bowls.  In comparison to my local Sorabol, this place is totaly different; they offer a large heaping pile of broccoli standard and provide huge portions (the Sorabol at the local mall doesn't). So how do I reconcile the disparity? I can't. All I know is that the smell of grilled meat at Sorabol will probably get me again next time I'm in the Westfield food court.
author: Dawn L.

description:
I love food courts. I've only been to this mall 3 times, and twice I chose only this place to eat at. I'm a sucker for Korean-style short ribs, and their version does not disappoint, fatty goodness and all.

Kimchee could be spicier, but I also am aware that many Asian restaurants "dumb-down" their heat level for the American palate. Plus, who knows what litigious Americans would do if they order something "hot" but not "that hot".

I can't say anything about their standard sesame noodles since I usually sub extra rice in lieu of the noodles. Veggies were a few broccoli.

Pricey, but this is the Bloomingdale/Nordstrom mall's food court in San Francisco we're talking about.
author: Ruiqiu K.

description:
I know this is stupid reviewing a take-out "restaurant" (??) in the mall but I love this place and the food court because the food here is 100x better than any mall food court ever in existence. 

I don't care how authentic it is, it's in a damn mall!
author: Leily P.

description:
it might be that it is in a mall but this was expensive and not that good.

I enjoyed my pot stickers, rice and noodles but my beef was boring and stringy. They did not offer any sauces to spice anything up so a little sad.

It might be a better place in the mall though.
author: Evrhet M.

description:
My favorite place to go to in this food court area. Love this food court, it's unlike any other mall food court that I have been to. Especially b/c it has many other healthier options compared to the typical McDonalds, etc. This one consists of Out The Door, Beard Papa's, and my all time favorite #2 (when I get sick of this place), Buckhorn! 

Veggie Bowl: it's a MUST and it's what I order every time. Love the fact that you get a mix of pickled daikon/cucumber slices, broccoli, chinese mushrooms, carrot shreds, spinach, glass noodles, and white rice (You can also get Fried Rice as an alternative, it's better.). Usually I get this with chicken, but I recently tried their lemon chicken. Fried, glazed, and has a kick to it, nothing like Chinese lemon chicken. It's a little spicy and sweet, doesn't even taste like lemon, but so good!
author: Tracy T.

description:
MY FAVORITE MALL FOOD is Sorabol.

not bad for a meal under $10.
Sorabol never disappoints me and I always get 2 kimchee servings for free.

Love their Calamari and Chicken Terayaki.

i love it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Emily L.

description:
After many years of writing jokes for Schwarzenegger and Marc Anthony, I learned one thing: It's important to partition your life. Never shall your work associates meet your Brown Power buddies, and as for your personage and the guys you play Marco Polo with at the YMCA pool... well, if you're a winner, then never the twain shall meet.

First off, there are two things this city needs: Cheap and good Korean and Filipino food... and for those, I've pretty much given up hope. So the hope is one thing, and the need is another. That much is established. 

On one end, one accepts piss poor service and less than adequate "authentic-er shit" or moderately adequate mall food. Applying the aforementioned philosophy of social separation to food helps when one has a craving for, let's call this Korean Food for now. 

Moderately tasty and sufficiently filling, this place doesn't claim to be fine dining or supremely authentic. It's just fine and dandy Korean plate food with the options of fried rice and... did I see orange chicken? BBQ chicken is hard to fuck up and so are short ribs. The chapchae is actually better than some of the other attempts I've tried in the area (which have all been largely disappointing - so Sorabol being approximately average/adequate is kind of a big deal) and surprisingly okay kim chee. Expedient service in the shitbox that's the mall is always appreciated. 

Perfectly acceptable on all fronts. All that considered, mall food it remains.

So, until some really ass-kickin' Korea-ville eats come in and stomp out the Cocobangs and the Sorabols of the town, I'll continue treating the two as separate beings, lest the Governators and the Mr. Lopezes of my life start hanging out and shooting the shit about who knows what.
author: Roy M.

description:
I've rocked the chicken, the spicy pork, and the tofu stir fry here. I'm pretty happy with my choices and the quality. It's pretty well cooked and seems more healthy than a lot of my other lunch options. I wasn't into Korean food until recently. It was feeling like ground hog day here in SOMA and I needed to branch out. Sorabol has helped me on my quest and they're quick. The damage is alway 11 bucks. This is high-end mall here ladies and gentlemen, watch out :). 

Solid choice for the Westfield.
author: Michael S.

description:
My kids enjoy this place because they love them some meat.  They always ask for Kal Bi (short ribs) when we go there.  For one order you get 3 pieces of short rib, a heaping serving of either white rice/fried rice, japchae (yam noodles) and broccoli. I also ordered a small pieces of cold tofu and eggplant too.  It was really tasty and very inexpensive for the 2 side dish.  They were cooked and topped with a soy sauce/chili pepper mixture and some green onions.  Perfect for a mid afternoon snack and not breaking the bank to much.

The downfall of this place is there is ALWAYS a line....and sometimes the meat is served cold.  You would think they would be turning over the food quickly and the meat would always be warm.  Also, they charge for all the little side dishes.  I usually don't order it and wait to go to a real sit down restaurant where they are served complimentary :)

BUT we'll be back because the kids love the food there.
author: Tammy N.

description:
BBQ chicken
Spicy Pork
Loaded with kim chi

This place is a gem inside the westfield shopping center. Fast service and gets you filled up real fast. i find myself here with friends alot when we go take pictures in the city or go to the city for lunch. Its literally right off powell bart station and you just go to the food court and bam. Chicken and pork is always tender and fresh due to the amount of traffic they have. Place is always packed. around 10 dollars for a 2 item combo
author: Ray L.

description:
I used to eat here for lunch almost every day. Their line is always the longest in the foot court. They give such HUGE portions. I just love their clear noodles!

My fave is the lamb. Their short ribs is pretty good too. Oh and their beef stew.

One day, the person in front of me told them no rice just noodles. Now why didn't I think of that? So from that day on, I only got noodles and no rice! 


They stopped making the lamb! Noooo!!! I'm so sad.

I haven't eaten here lately cuz the last time I was here, the food was just ok. It just didn't taste the same anymore.

They keep their kimchee in little cups in a lil case for you to get yourself. One time I saw a homeless guy just grab cups of them and just eat them at the table.
Okay price for a lot of food and entrees but I ate some bad kimchi (I'm assuming they didn't check), and had food poisoning. Smell the "kimchi" before eating.Beware!
author: Lia T.

description: Line wasn't too long during Tuesday lunch, so my friend and I came here for a quick lunch. I typically stay away from Sorabol or any other chain restaurants while dining in SF, but we were looking for something quick so this was it. I wish their menu had more meals with smaller portions--it seems like everything is upwards of $9 and the portions are quite large, so I'd rather spend less for something I'll actually finish. I ordered the BBQ chicken meal, which comes with rice, noodles, broccoli, and a pretty generous amount of chicken. There's also a side of kimchi, but it comes in a teeny container and I wish they gave more since I love kimchi. (Although my friend and I took our food back to the office, and neither of us wanted to stink it up for everyone, so the kimchi ended up uneaten...so sad) The chicken was mediocre--less dry than I had feared it would be since it was coming from a food court. We did get our food rapidly, which was the goal, so this is definitely a good place for time crunches.
author: Tina T.

description:
I have been here a few times and just realized I have yet to review them. 

I have never been into Korean BBQ all that much, most likely because I simply just didn't eat it all that much. Where I live and used to work, I don't think there is even a Korean BBQ restuarant within 10 miles. Luckily for me now, Sorabol is just a few minutes walk from my work, so it's a place quite a few people from the office frequent on a weekly basis. 

I really like the spicy chicken and spicy pork and although the short ribs are mighty tasty, they just do not have enough meat on the bone. I need much more than they give to satisfy me. 

Overall, a very solid place to grab some lunch.
author: Jason B.

description:
The food at Sorabol at Westfield is okay. You can do better but you can do worse. Browse yelp for Korean restaurants in the Union Square/FiDi area and you will see there really aren't that many options.

Sorabol is probably one of the better places for lunch in the Food Emporium at Westfield. I usually go for the beef short ribs. It comes with rice, clear noodles, and some broccoli. The ribs are tender. As with the Thai place, most of the menu items have already been prepared and are served steam table style.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
Sorabol is a great place to get a quick fix if you have a hankering for some decent Korean food in San Francisco without going to a restaurant.  By no means is it great Korean food, but it is good mall food.  Definitely go here over Panda Express or Sarku Japan.

I highly recommend their spicy pork and their soups, but their other entrees are worth trying.  The prices are a bit high as is the case for most of the food in the Westfield food court if you're not from SF.  

If you have a choice between the Westfield Sorabol and the Metreon one, go to the Westfield one.  They always have lines so are constantly grilling new batches of meat while the Metreon tends to be less busy outside of typical lunch hours (11am to 1pm) so the food tends to sit longer.
author: June P.

description:
Blackened by the grill
Perfect with rice and noodles
Barbeque Chicken

One of the better places in this food court and quite possibly the only Korean food joint I've ever seen that doesn't raise prices for the same item at dinner time.  It's also a superior value to just about everything within a 100 meter walking distance.
author: Jin D.

description:
In the mall food line up, Korean kalbi called my name.  I was flabbergasted.  

Yippee.
author: Jen L.

description: I can't knock this place for being a food court attraction. Rarely do I find Korean food of this quality in a mall but Sorabol prevails. I ordered the not so becoming Beef stew in hopes of it being a generic fast food form of a chinese dish (a typical Bay Area rip-off (Like when Japanese restaurants have fried rice)). I was happily surprised by the tenderness, slight sweetness of the meat and the accompanying clear noodles exceeded my expectations just by not being a disgusting rendition. For under $10, this is a good lunch.
author: Savier M.

description:
Wow. Who knew "food court" food can taste this good? Sorabol is one of the eateries part of Food Emporium (the fancy food court) in Westfield.  The prices are a bit higher than typical food court entrees but the entrees are MASSIVE (you can share the entree between 2 people). I ate here twice during my trip to SF and ordered the same thing: short ribs with clear noodles (jab chae) and no rice (so double the amount of noodles!).  there are plenty of other choices and if you want more than 1 type of meat, get a combo! 

i loved that you get to use real silverware and get an actual water glass (makes water taste so much more refreshing when its in a glass instead of a styrofoam cup) plus self-served kimchee. 

fine, i agree its not  the best or most authentic korean food but it tastes pretty darn good. the entree sizes combined with the convenient location in union square makes this a great place to have a nice, quick meal.  i wish they would open one of these in a mall in chicago....
author: Nancy F.

description: I love this place. I've been in San Francisco for 4 days, and out of those 4 I've been eating at this place for the past 3. I definitely recommend this place. Its affordable and delicious! You should try it. =)
author: Shaun E.

description:
The food here is definitely top-notch, but for a shopping mall food court, it's good stuff. For the price, however there are other options, and definitely better Korean food around.

For $10 I got the beef short ribs combo, which came with 4 pieces of beef short rib, rice, noodles, a small portion of vegetables and free kimchi. The ribs were warm and satisfactory in taste, which is basically how I judge most Korean places. 

Overall, there are better places to go, but within the mall, Sorabol is one of the better picks.
author: Momota E.

description: I love this place. This is the closest and cheapest Korean place. I love the clear noodles! If I am ordering for myself I just order the clear noodles. They give you plenty. If you are a big eater or you are sharing with someone order the combo. Comes with rice, noodles, meat, and broccoli. They have really good yummy meat! A lot of food for 10 bucks! I was full from eating half.
author: Sarah C.

description: I like this place. It was quick and delicious. I enjoyed the spicy chicken and pork, one of the best I've had. It was a lot of food for a good price!!  Looking forward to go back to the mall just for this place.
author: Kelly T.

description:
I love Korean BBQ.  

Sometimes it seems like the meat is less than prime cut quality, but upon reflection I realized this is because the cut is unusual.  Cutting across the short ribs, you get fascia to deal with guaranteed.  This is not like Texas BBQ, where you cut with the ribs.  That said, the marinade here is awesome, teriyaki sauce with extra extra extra extra extra garlic.  

So my Queen of Heaven called from the train on the way into town, and we met here.  We ordered BBQ spareribs and BBQ chicken.  The plates came with rice, glass noodles, and broccoli.  The portions here are the BIG American-style portions, so we were full at the end of our meal.  The two dishes, and a Diet Pepsi, came to $22 including our tip.  

I am not on a diet, exactly, but this morning the scales told me a plate of Korean BBQ weighs 3 pounds.  I guess I'll have take another long walk to work it off again.
author: David D.

description: Nothing remarkable.
author: Michael E.

description:
I eat here A LOT!  It's a great choice because not only is it delicious, but pretty inexpensive too.  You can't go wrong with a big plate of meat, broccoli and noodles for around $7.00.  

I usually have leftovers - that is, unless someone sitting next to me doesn't scarf them down first (you know who you are).

This food court has plenty of good eats to choose from and is right across the street from the Powell Cable Car line and right next to the Bart station.  If you're hungry enough, you can get Sorabol then top it off with either Papa Beards, a tapioca smoothie, or some yummy gelato.
author: Lauren C.

description: This review is for the sauteed eggplant( I watched them make it and flop it on my plate) and something that looks like cellophane noodles..not sure what the dish is called. I am addicted....my two favorite foods in the food court. No need to go to Out The Door. The guy likes the mackerel. I'm not a fan as it seemed a bit dry.
author: Bleep S.

description:
They give you some heaping portions over at Sorabol, and for a chain Korean joint, that ain't a bad start. Ever since the new Westfield opened, this place in particular - out of all the food court options - was perenially the most busy.

Finally, today, managed to get in there early enough to try it. So, it's your typical pick 1 or 2 items sort of place - I tried the spicy chicken and the bbq short ribs - both were were hearty options. Each dish comes with rice and noodles, plus a few pieces of broccoli thrown in for good measure, all for about $12 with a soda. Not such a bad deal, all thing considered, yould definitely make two meals out of it if you took it to go.
author: Nish N.

description: The portions here are great and the chciken is nice and moist I also like the Noodles they are enjoyable and they have a nice texture to them. The Kimchi here is nice and spicy I would come back to this one.
author: Aurelio L.

description: The line at Sorabol was pretty long so I thought there was probably something good in their food.  The best way I can describe this place is.... A Korean Panda Express.  Do they have pandas in Korea?  Whatever, this food was just a mistake for me to try.  Yes they have Galbi and yes they have free Kimchee but nothing great about it.  Plain and simple.  I did like their portions since one dish is enough to feed two but I just wish the food tasted more authentic and not like fast food.
author: Camilo G.

description:
Went there mid-week for lunch and the line was huge, but longer than other places in the food court.  The veggie and tofu bowl was pretty tasty.  The chicken cutlet bowl had to be custom cooked, so it took a few minutes to make as opposed to getting your food in the regular steam table line.  The cutlet was on a bed of scrambled eggs and veggies over rice.  Not tonkatsu sauce, but some other kind of sauce on the cutlet which was fine.  

The food was good and you can't get Korean food everywhere, so I guess that's what makes this place a winner.
author: Doctor G.

description:
There were so many choices in the food court it was hard to decide.  I wanted something Pho like, broth-y and noodle-y and I found it at Sorabol.  I went with the noodle and wonton soup, unfortunately when it appeared it had dead cow floating on top and Mitzie does not eat dead cow, dead cow broth is ok though.  Fortunately for them I wasn't feeling 100% and just quickly picked it off and tossed it in the trash.

The soup was good, flavorful and filling and settled my tummy so I was ready for killing time in the city until it was time for GBF#1 and I to head to the airport.  And to top it off it was cheap too!
author: Me H.

description:
Is it authentic?  Um, kinda.  I don't know about other Sorabol locations but I think this one has decent food.  At a great value.  For around 8 bucks, you can get rice, noodles, veggies, kimchi and grilled meat enough for two meals.  

I almost always get just chapchae and bbq chicken when I'm picking up lunch at the mall.  The food is flavorful, plentiful and thanks to the fast turnover, quite fresh. 

So it's not anything exotic or  "authentic" (however people define authentic Korean), but neither am I and people still like me.   

It is what it is. You're not getting a formal Korean sit down meal with 45 banchans and the "authentic" (aka abusive) Korean service .  This is essentially "fast food" where you can be in and out with your food in 5 minutes.  Adjust your expectations and I think you'll be pleased.

Note:  if you choose to order lemon chicken at a Korean joint, please do not complain that it's not good - you have only you to blame.
author: mia s.

description: Great option in the food court!   The lines do move quickly here so don't be discouraged.  By the time you decide what you want, it's your turn to order.  They have a pretty good selection for meat eaters, fish eaters, and vegetarians.  The tofu stew could be a little spicier but generally the food is good and the portions are generous.  I also like the complimentary kim chi.
author: Bebe W.

description:
Waaaay better than the one at Stonestown, where I swear the people who work there are totally jaded and bitter after years of sassy hoodrat teeny boppers have trotted to and fro.

As far as Korean joints goes, Sorabol is actually below-average in price, which is a wonder, considering its location in a blatantly overpriced mall next to an overly inflated "grocery store." They give you a lot of food for about $9.00 - it would be a good idea to share one of the one or two item meals, unless you are REALLY hungry AND you can eat a great deal. I am usually both, but even I was still having a hard time finishign the food.

The korean barbecue beef was pretty good, cheap quality (some stringiness and fat), but it was a low percentage. The flavor was good and it had just the right amount of green and regular onion mixed in. I've had bad experiences with chicken in MOST Korean restaurants I've been to, but it actually wasn't too bad at Sorabol, a bit undercooked (it wasn't raw at all, but it could be cooked a bit longer, but not to the point of dryness). The clear noodles side dish is also good. It's not as bland as some people have made it out, in my opinion. The complimentary tiny cups of kim chee is really nice. 

Additionally, I love that they give you a huge cup if you ask for water. I mean, it's just tap water with ice - why do most places still try to stinge you on it and give you tiny little Dixie cups? Why, God, why??

Finally, +50 stars because the man who works the registers there is the man I want to have my babies with. A big brawny Korean with mild manners, hot dang, I am in looooove.
author: Joshua L.

description:
I've been cooking Korean food since I was nine years old, and I learned from the greatest cook ever (my mom, of course).  

Needless to say, I'm an admitted Korean food snob who can't in good conscience go out and pay for a Korean meal when I know I could eat better at home should I decide to cook it myself.  It's this last part ... the "should I decide to cook it myself" that seems to be my biggest problem.  

There are so many components to making a Korean meal "authentic", that creating a homemade meal can take hours or even days to do right.   What?  You thought those side dishes they serve at a Korean restaurant grow on trees? Hells no!  Someone's grandma is squatting in the backroom of the restaurant, picking dirt and pebbles from the sprouts and roots.

Needless to say, it's not often that I actually eat Korean food although I love it enough to be completely happy should I be forced to eat it as every meal for the remainder of my life.  

Yesterday, my hunger for Korean food became uncontrollable, and I found myself walking up to the Sorabol counter and ordered a huge container of food.

For ten dollars and change, I got a bottle of water, a heap of steamy white rice, an unexpectedly large mound of BBQ beef with onions (bulgogi), a healthy serving of noodles (chap chae), broccoli, bean sprouts (I paid extra for these), a couple small containers of pickled cabbage (kimchee) and hot sauce (for my broccoli).  

I was transported.  When I was a kid, we would have Korean picnics that consisted of a slightly more elaborate version of this meal.  This was not at all bad for a quick, cheap and no-effort meal from the land of my people (*wink* ... I was born in St. Louis, but you know what I mean).

I'll definitely be back.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Damn Damn Damn.  I REALLY miss the Korean "fast food" places in Hawaii.  Cheaper than this joint, and better food too.

So, I ordered the one entree plate with lemon chicken.  Fyi:  Lemon chicken is Chinese, not Korean.  Anyhow, it came with chap chae (clear noodles), rice, kimchee, and broccoli.  I also ordered a vegetarian egg roll.  So...  the lemon chicken was oily, greasy, and soggy.  I think it was left over from the previous day.  The rice, noodles, and broccoli were good though.  

What I should have ordered:  They have this vegetable plate for $3, which comes with Korean style veggies.  Looked delicious.

Anyhow, portions ARE huge.  Come hungry.  Don't order the lemon chicken.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Don't. Just don't do it. If you did it before, don't do it anymore (esp during dinner time). This used to be my go-to place at the food court, but the quality and taste seems to be deteriorating every time I visit. The last (and final) time I was there, I ordered  the grilled chicken and spicy pork. 

The whole process is high school cafeteria style with the lady (sans hairnet) scooping mountains of mystery meat onto your plate. Maybe I went too late in the day, but everything tasted/looked like it had been sitting there since last night. The broccoli was limp. The chicken was a mess, but more edible than some of the other items. The pork was the worst of them all. It had the meat to fat ratio of a slice of cheap bacon, and the "meaty" taste of the pork was much too overwhelming to be fresh.

I can see how this plate of food can be considered a value meal. You certainly get more for your money than some of the other places in the food court, but it should be noted that the "more" here refers to quantity and not necessarily quality.
author: Rona J.

description:
The best thing about this place is the price to portion size ratio. You can definitely fill up for relatively cheap. Which is super important for any college student. 

They have the food already prepared so--once you reach the front of the line-- you are ready to chow down in under a minute. ALSO, if you are with a group, the food emporium in Westfield is expansive. So even if your friends don't like or want Korean, there are plenty of other options.

Oh, and the food is good quality for a mall food emporium...
author: Adriel S.

description:
They give you big tastey portions for a cheap price~

Thats hard to come by in the mall, usually there is something expensive with small portions making your stomach and your wallet feeling empty.

Quite the smart move there Sorabol~
author: phillip w.

description:
Now I am not an expert on Korean cuisine but I really like this spot. It's located in the over crowded Westfield mall food court , so if you are looking for a fine dinning experience look else where. 

I really enjoy their BBQ chicken and spicy chicken. Which I think is just their BBQ chicken in a spicy sauce but it's still really good. Their spicy pork is tasty but you are almost guaranteed to get a piece of gristle. 

It's a little pricey at about 10-11 with a drink. But they give you a ton of food.  Each combo meal comes with noodles, rice and broccoli. Definitely enough to save for a snack later on in the day.
author: Jeff P.

description:
One small strip of beef rib counted as "one item", unbelievable !

Flavor of grill chicken was not bad, but the Japanese Grill at couple stores down was much better.
author: chao-ying w.

description:
First my creds for making these comments: 
I have been a frequent visitor for years (they recognize me and my kids). So this is not based off of a single visit. But my visits have diminished over the last year because of the points noted below. 

Lets get down to brass tacks here. 

Food is tasty. Love the flavors of the BBQ chicken and the short ribs. (And when they had them the steamed dumplings). 

The wife loves the soup.

But 2 major bummers about this place... Well maybe 3.
1. They no longer sell steamed dumplings, just fried. Hello! This is SF, lets keep it healthy (at least as healthy as Pork filled carbs can be)
2. Portions are hit and miss: sometimes I get loaded up and can't finish. Other times, my 4 year old can polish off the whole thing and want more. And to be clear I am saying that sometimes they give 1 set of ribs, sometimes 2. And the amount of chicken ranges from "covers the plate" to '  "I've seen more real chicken in a McNugget"

I have complained about the inconsistencies before and I just get told food is pricey so they have to cut back. But that doesn't explain the inconsistencies ... and I can do math. They are making out just fine when even they load up the plate. 

And if I had to throw in a 3rd issue that triggers me... the service. Not of the line staff, they are always great. And I suspect I get more food when they are there on their own. But when the manager (owner?) is there, forget it. And he is the one who has cried poor mouth when I have inquired as to why the amount of food varies.

Now that I think about it, in prior visits following the removal of the steamed dumplings from the serving line, when I have asked for them they have run in back and grabbed me a few. But not the last time because the manager (owner?) said no.

While I'll keep going there occasionally because my kid likes the food. I will go less frequently. And for those who don't have kids who love their food, maybe this review will resonate with you and you will not go at all. It is not like there are not 15 other places loading up equally tasty food in the food court :-).
author: Alan B.

description:
You know, if you have to be wallet-raped by the Food Underworldorium beneath the Westfield San Francisco Center, this is a good bet for something edible.  One combo dish can feed 2 people, and if you get the spicy pork or grilled chicken, it's edible and kinda tasty.  

Avoid the beef -- the galbi are tough and stringy, and the bulgogi taste like they come from boiled downer cattle.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Had dinner here tonight.  I know of all the places to eat at Westfield I chose Sorabol.  But damn I love their chicken bowl. 

Bowl: rice, chapchae, chicken and some broccoli with terriyaki sauce.

-1 star they didn't cut the chicken up like the one at stonestown
-1 star it was for here but I wanted it in a to go bowl in case I don't finish it
+1 star its Sorabol's chicken bowl..always tasty
+1 star portions were huge...also right before closing.
+1 star all the kimchee you can take....I love that stuff
author: Allison T.

description: I usually stop by while I'm shopping in the mall, especially when I'm craving a large amount of meat. A 2-item combo is enough for me and a friend and comes with rice/noodles/both, broccoli, and kimchee.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I had my doubts going around the food court on a Friday night for Mall food.. that's right! Mall food!

We paced ourselves around the bustiling food court downstairs and man, was it crowded for a Friday night! :P It t'was the first friday night of opening, but still... I expected more people!

After meandering the court for 1 loop, we looked for "Out the door" (1 of my favorite places to eat at the Ferry Building, and 1 of the places I wanted my SO to try out).. but it hadn't open yet!! Grrr for slow construction!

Anyways, we settled for Korean food because that was the only thing that looked decent and quick, so we found a seat and I waited in line.. me, myself and 30 other people. 

There was no menu, but I was already familiar with their food from another restaurant in the Rincon Center near my workplace, so I was expecting nothing less than crappy food for an overpriced  price. 

Me2Myself: "Great! I'm waiting in line here in line and I already know the food will be bad. Where is the prices so I know how much it cost?... I need to pee."

As I got closer to the warm food tray counter (great, another mew thing to look at) I was like.. 

Me2Myself: "Stop poking me with your damn Bloomingdales Yellow bag little Asian girl with long eyelashes which are sooooo fake!"

"Oh.. a Menu!" I exclaimed! I reached out and grabbed for the single leaflet menu, only to be disappointed by the food choices. 

BBQ CHICKEN
SPICY BBQ CHICKEN
BBQ SHORT RIBS
PORK
SPICY PORK

Each of these items come with rice, or noodles (ask for half and half) some veggies and some kimchi (more on that later). 

After little miss bratz had her way with the employee getting her her food, it was my turn. I asked for two bowls of Rice + Noodles, and spicy pork.

TallAsianGuyLookingLikeHeBeenDrinkingLastNight: "Sorry sir, we don't have spicy pork. How about chicken?"

Me2Him: "Do you have any Short Ribs"


TallAsianGuyLookingLikeHeBeenDrinkingLastNight looks at me like I'm from Mars that I do not see it in front of me and says: "We don't have that either, but we have CHICKEN! Its really good." He points to the buckload of bbq chicken.

Me: "Fine. I'll get the chicken and spicy chicken on each bowl."

Somehow they mixed that order up and gave me 2 regular and 1 spicy chicken in one bowl and 3 spicy chicken in another. 

Finally got to the "sauce lady" and sure enough.. more questions.

SauceLady in a low tone as if she was whispering: "Do you want veggies and sauce?"

Me: "what did you say? Its too loud in here.."

SauceLady: "Veggies and sauce?" She then points to both items as if I am a foreigner and I just give her the nod of the head. (isn't that a universal sign to know)

Finally got to the counter after getting nailed in the leg by Little Ms Bratz and her yellow bag and picked up a diet coke and a water. Granted, the person that rung me up didn't take into account that I had a bowl (50 cents extra by the way) . It should have been somewhere in the price range of $25 for all this, but he only counted me $18.88. 

Guess he saw I was Chinese.

Anyways, he gave me two small sample of kimchee and finally got the food to the table.. 25 mins of wait.. 

We started eating in the high quality bowls and MAN! The flavor was off the hook! The spicy sauce actually tasted SPICY and almost comparable to say Brothers. The chicken was good and tasty with NO skin (just the way I like it)

The portions were decent and the noodles tasted right. I'm glad they did cooked things right on the first day.  The veggies was just broccoli, so nothing to write home about. I'm just glad that I finally had decent Korean BBQ food vs that nasty place with a similar name in the Rincon center.

Money saving tip: I think if you get a bowl, you'll get more food.. but I could be totally wrong there!
author: Wilson L.

description:
All I can say is that Sorabol gives you A LOT of food...there was enough chicken and rice in my BBQ chicken platter to last two meals, and I'm not a light eater.  So its not the best or most authentic Korean food out there, but for shits sake, its in a" food emporium."  They do a fairly good job of getting some decent charbroiled flavor in the chicken, though I have to say that their sauce was sickly sweet.  Thankfully they do offer kimchee in small plastic containers- I wasn't sure if I was allowed to take two, but I did anyway.  The tangy spiciness of the kimchee works wonders on counteracting the sweetness of the chicken.  The clear noodles were a little too al dente for my taste and didn't have enough sesame flavor.  Steamed broccoli was steamed broccoli...not much to say about that.

Overall, a fairly good eat in the Westfield Mall especially if you're sick of the typical Chinese takeout.  I'd say get your order to go since they really pile on the meat and broccoli in the takeout containers, whereas they seem to put less on orders to eat in.  I just noticed I had way more chicken in my to-go order than the people around me who were eating at the mall.  In any case, service can be brusque, but they are dealing with a lot of people, especially now that its the crazy shopping season.  Otherwise, it was an average meal for a little under $10.
author: Angela H.

description:
I want to love it.  Easy-to-get to Korean food?  My dreams would have been answered.  Sadly I cannot say I've liked anything they've served :(  

Large portions doesn't mean good food.  It makes me sad that there are people who think that Sorabol serves Korean food.  Think of it as a variant on the Asian-Mall food experience.
author: MJ C.

description:
Huge plates, yes.  You might have to waddle out of Westfield Shopping Center after this meal.  Don't plan any important meetings afterwards if you have lunch...you might go into a kim chee coma.  Just kidding.  But really, there is not an ounce of moderation at this place.  And you can get different kinds of stuff all mixed together.  I asked for a little mackerel and a little spicy snapper and they were happy to accomodate me.  I like the spicy stuff.  It is hot in just the right places.


My five-star system for accomodating people with special diets:

Responsiveness to questions/needs: ***** (five stars, they answered all of my questions)
Dairy-free: ***** (five stars, a number of dishes are dairy-free)
Gluten-free: **** (two stars, not much without wheatful soy sauce or wheat)
Vegetarian: ** (two stars, not many veggie options)
Vegan: ** (two stars, not many veggie options )
author: Erica H.

description: Every time i pass by this place, there's always a long line. I don't blame them because I love getting their BBQ short ribs which I highly recommend. Usually when I get the combo plate, I can never finish it in one setting. I usually have a food coma then finish it after I wake up. LOL. My boyfriend and I usually spend $20 all together when we come here. I guess that's a good price because usually it's our lunch and dinner since we never can finish it.
author: Janice V.

description:
Pretty good for a mall food court thing!

Service is pretty fast. You point at food, they put it on a plate, and you move along. Item selection is limited for a full Korean restaurant, but reasonable for a cafeteria-style booth in a mall food court, which is what it is. 

The quality of the food itself is surprisingly good. Quite tasty, and in generous portions for a food court booth thingy. Choose 1-2 main items, and they pile them on top of good old sticky rice and noodles. That's roughly 9 bucks. Don't forget to get a little tub of kimchee at the end of the line. Snag as many as you like.
author: Clar L.

description:
I'm so happy. This is GOOD Korean fast food.

For a two-entree I got tofu and bulgogi, and it was yuuummy. Plus chapchae, rice and free kimchi (it's really not that spicy ha) makes it so much better. Only $10!

The tofu was great. It could've been a bit more spicy but I was digging around for more pieces. It's similar to Chinese ma po tofu. Yuuuuummy.
Bulgogi was good too. Some pieces were somewhat big, but whatever. It was cooked just right.
Chapchae was awesome. Not too many pieces of veggies, and not too spicy.

I'll continue coming back when I come to the city. Next time I'll try the mackerel. :)
author: Cynthia A.

description:
Basically, the only reason I would come here is because I am desperately craving some kimchi and this is the only remotely Korean restaurant in SOMA.  Which is exactly what happened a week ago, reminding me of how mediocre the food is here.

I think Panda Express meets Korean food except with inferior quality is an apt analogy here.  Granted I think Panda Express defined a new cult category for super-Americanized "Chinese" food (I will admit that even I crave this stuff sometimes) and Sorabol is probably similar.  But the sugary sweet meats without any remote spicy kick just does not do it for me.  The pork bulgogi was really quite dry, and both mapo tofu and noodles were bland.  They've definitely tailored down the spice and what's left is a shell of what Korean food should be.

Come here if you want a quick fix for Korean craving, but don't expect it to satisfy you for long.
author: Ellen C.

description: My fiancee and I actually went here to get some Beard Papa's and check out the new mall.  We didn't want to eat the cream puffs for lunch so we actually got a real lunch.  The line was long, but so were all the other restaurants.  The line went quick though.  I ordered the BBQ beef short ribs and it came with noodles and rice.  My fiancee ordered chicken.  Both were very good.  We also ordered some potstickers and they were pretty bland.  Even with some sauce, they weren't that great.  Prices weren't too bad and service was okay.  If you go during lunch, it'll be touch to find a seat.  Do yourself a favor after lunch or dinner and have a vanilla bean cream puff (or two) after at Beard Papa's.  Then you can go home and take a nap!
author: Jamie J.

description:
I'm from the Washington DC area which has the 2nd most concentration of Koreans (LA being 1st) in the United States and you can imagine that there are tons of great Korean eateries however in SF, there aren't too many Korean restaurants.  The only other Korean restaurant I've been to in SF is Hanuri which is almost as good as back home.  

Now Sorabol is something I've never seen before....Korean fast food.  Of course it's no way ever going to be as good as a sit down restaurant that has the money gas grill right on the table ready for your grilling of freshly marinated Korean BBQ meat pleasure.  Half the fun of eating at a delicious sit down Korean restaurant is all the abundant little side dishes that they bring you (kim chee, bean sprouts, spinach, tofu, potato salad, etc...  At Sorabol you have your various Korean BBQ meants to choose from...BBQ chicken, spicy beef/chickent/pork, beef short ribs, and more.  So for $8 you can choose 2 of the meat choices and they also give you some white rice, chap chae (Korean noodles), and whatever side dishes I mentioned before that you would like.  Also, the kimchee is free so take as much as you want.  

For the price and lack of Korean restaurants in SF I give this place 4 stars.  I would give it 5 but c'mon, it's fast food.
author: David C.

description:
Sometimes you just craveeee for Korean food, and working in the FiDi just don't really give you much choices.  So I really appreciate the fact that Sorabol is within walking distance from FiDi. 

I usually get the 2-items combo with grilled mackerel and spicy snappers.  The plate also comes with chap-jae, rice, broccoli, most importantly KIMCHEE!  For ~$10, a huge lunch is served with a drink!

The portion is huge and I even have a good amount of leftovers to bring home for the bf.  

If the Korean bf thinks the grilled Mackerel and the Spicy Snappers are tasty, of course, my chinese @ss have no compliant!
author: Gigi T.

description:
now i'm hooked.   it's the best food i've ever had at a food court.  not overly greasy, large portions all at a fair price.

i ordered the bbq chicken which has tons of meat and noodles (think portion size of hawaiian fast food).   everything tasted soooo good.  my cousin said the short ribs were tasty too as well as the unlimited side of kimchi  which i wanted more of but didn't wanna look like a fatty in front of family visiting from Chicago (and we were on a mission to shop for dresses for the wedding while everyone was complaining about losing few lbs before the big day).  While almost everyone split plates, i ordered my own.  while my cousin didn't finish her rice/noodles, i devoured mine.  

Oops, i guess i can't help myself.  see, it IS JUST THAT GOOD.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
This place is great!  The line is always the longest in the food area but the line is crazy fast.  They are INCREDIBLY generous with their portions and when the food is good, it's amazing!

The only downside to this place is that sometimes the food is cold.  I always try to hit the place up when it looks like they are pulling stuff off the grill and tossing it into the serving containers.  If it looks like it's been there awhile, I pass.

The other thing is sometimes the meat has a lot of fat and gristle on it...blaaaagh!

Buuuuuuuuuuuuut all said and done, 80% of the time this place hits the spot like nothing else at Westfield. And when it's good, it's DAMN good ;)
author: Patrique R.

description: Going here is a treat.  The portions are huge, and everything is always fresh.  The service is pleasant and friendly.  I get the BBQ chicken.  Love the won bok kimchee side.  This may be considered 'fast food' to some, but I enjoy it.
author: Lawree S.

description: The spicy BBQ chicken was very gristly and the sauce was thick and not tasty at all. I was very disappointed.
author: Lynna D.

description: It was late and the mall was starting to close around 9pm, so we thought we better grab a quick late dinner cause we hadn't eaten since lunch time. It's an okay place if you're shopping in the area and need to grab something quick. We had the Mackerel fillet which was pretty good, and we also tried the lemon chicken which had a spicy taste to it.
author: Jerod Y.

description: Yeah it's in a mall. Yeah it's 'fast food'. but DUDE, this is an AMAZING value for your money. LOVE it.
author: linda t.

description: Sorabol was my last SF meal before heading to the airport. The portions here are ridiculously large, the price was a little high and the food was decent. I got the spicy dak gui which looked amazing. I loved the dish for the first few bites and then it became way too overwhelming because the sauce just overpowered everything. Overall the place was decent but definitely not a meal you want to be you last considering all the amazingness San Francisco has to offer!
author: Ariza S.

description:
Sorabol is consistently good food and probably the best of the "gourmet fast food" available at the mall.   I know those looking for the traditional Korean experience with tons of side dishes and other offerings might be somewhat disappointed, but the still serve brilliant grilled meets...the Kal-Bi is delicious, bulgogi, is amazing and the spicy grilled pork and chicken absolutely rock.  I love that they have a ton of different offerings to try that make it fun to mix and match.

I base my ratings on a ratio of quality to cost, and this place hits it out of the park.
author: Sven B.

description: Ahhhh, I'm a total fan of this place. I understand why some might not have rated this place higher. The quality of Korean food could be a lot better, but give me a break. I'd venture to guess that this place serves 400+ people a day. It's easily the most popular fast food spot in the food court. You cannot go wrong with the BBQ Chicken if you want a really fast hearty meal. They give you some Broccoli, glass noodles, rice and the BBQ chicken covered with Teriyaki Sauce "If you want some!" Nod yes! For something under $10 dollars and will undoubtedly make you full, there isn't a better value in this expensive food court. The BBQ Short Ribs are incredible as well if you feel like treating yourself on a friday. and there is a buffet of other choices that you can create a mix and match combo with at Sorabol.
author: Michael C.

description:
Tried this place out on my lunch break, because I do love Korean food, but it was a major disappointment. The first tip-off should have been the lack of food knowledge. A sign on the counter said "Spicy Tofu Stew", and when I ordered the "Soondooboo" they told me they didn't make it...Okay, explained that it was the stew that I wanted, then asked if it comes with banchan. They had no idea what I was talking about. This is when I should have left and ran across the street for some tofu banh mi from Cafe Dolci. But I stayed, ordered banchan (the "salad plate") on the side and waited for my soondooboo. 

Short recap - the broth was ok, pretty spicy. But the makeup of the soup just wasn't what I'm used to. It was more like broth with tofu chunks than a tofu stew. There wasn't any cabbage or other greens in it, and it there were various kinds of seafood mixed into it (which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it wasn't noted that it came with seafood. I like mine without.) The banchan all tasted the same, though the kimchi was pretty good. 

I probably won't be coming here again, and I almost feel like I should run to Bowl'd in Albany to get the taste of good Korean back into my mind.
author: Lauren M.

description: The salmon was dry =( I was hungry , spent money on it, and had no choice, but to finish it. I did like how sticky the rice was though.
author: Gerard Y.

description: I suppose theirs worst food you can get in a food court. It's not authentic Korean but once in a while their not a bad option to have. I like getting the Bulgogi with the cellophane noodles but that's about it. They also have steamed fish and Salmon teriyaki I believe.
author: Petra S.

description: I love their Korean BBQ chicken plate. Their chicken is tender and has the  perfect level of crisp on the edges. It seems like I eat here every time I come to the mall. The only issue I have with this place is that sometimes when I get my food, it isn't hot enough...and nobody likes cold Korean BBQ! Overall great food.
author: Sundeep G.

description:
Not Impressed. 
My meat was Lukewarm/ Cold in some areas. My Spicy chicken wasn't spicy. The noodles were falling apart. The only edible thing on my plate was the rice.
Thats what I get for eating at the mall.
author: Karlee D.

description: Korean food usually takes a lot of time to cook, but this place has fast service.  SF Bay Area Korean is not that great; however, this place is pretty good and decently priced.
author: Kenneth Y.

description:
Never before have I seen 20+ people line up without knowing what they were getting. But that's how it was opening day at Sorabol, Korean BBQ, in the new San Francisco Westfield food court. We went for lunch, about 1 p.m. on Sept. 28. Frankly, Gieson and I picked Sorabol because it was the shortest line (who knew Buckhorn was soo popular), and we were right because it took a max of 10 minutes to pay and get the food. Nevermind that we didn't know what we were getting besides Korean BBQ.

So, when we got to pay, we found out there was only one thing on the menu: a BBQ chicken meal with rice, brocolli and kimchi for $7.50. Sodas, $1.

The result: Normal food court food. Nothing spectacular, but a good place to refuel. The chicken was cooked well; it wasn't dry. And the kimchi was tame enough for me (I pass on the hot sauce at Taco Bell).

The food court seating is a step above other malls. The bambo plants on each table add a nice touch, as the loungelike seating near Beard Papa's. Off course, on opening day it was too crowded to enjoy it all. Overall, Sorabol was efficient, servicewise and foodwise.
author: rosanna c.

description:
It isn't anything to write home about. Not truly remarkable-nor is it easy to forget. It is simply Mediocre Korean food. A step below Hahn's Hibachi since it is inside a mall.

Please note...I am not a K-food expert. I just know good K-food doesn't exist in Westfield Centre.
author: James J.

description:
I work across the street from here, and can't get enough of their lemon chicken and noodles as a lunch option.

My only concern is that there seems to be a lot of sugar in their sauces, which I think is a big contributing factor to the addiction I am developing..
author: M D.

description: Absolutely disgusting.  Every single piece of meat is fatty and chewy.  The dishes were disgusting, oily, lowest quality ingredients and it was not cheap. Worse than airport food. I had to spit out every piece of bulgogi. YUCK!!!!!!
author: Laurence S.

description:
I ordered the wrong thing!  In the heat of my flu fever, I somehow forgot that I was a vegetarian and ordered the chicken soup.  There is some medicinal purpose to chicken soup, the proteins released from the chicken when cooking it in the broth mimic the cold fighting ingredients in OTC medicine.  

But this chicken smelled bad.  And it was all dark meat.  LIke the chicken was parboiled, then chopped up and sprinkled on top of the chicken noodle soup.  It was too chicken-y of a smell.  You know how fresh fish isn't suppose to smell fishy?  And fresh chicken should behave the same way.  

The kimchee here was too sweet.  So was the japchae.  It was all a little too sweet for my taste.  I like it fiery and spicy.  Not sweet and syrupy.  Maybe that was it.  It tastes like they put corn syrup in their kimchee and japchae.
author: Christina C.

description: Yummy food but the kimchi wasn't that great. The staff didn't really speak to me, maybe because they didn't speak English, but I took it sort of offensively. They make great short ribs, though! Good place to go if you're in Downtown SF.
author: Tim W.

description:
Suggested by a well known Yelper who knows what he is talking about! :-) I believed it and I wasn't disappointed. We both tried this place out for the first time and it seems to get busier and busier as the clock reaches 12:15pm...

I ordered an eel bowl with the biggest portion of steam rice, some noodles, 3 medium pieces of eel and some broccoli. Definitely, my suggestion is to have a bit more vegetable choices (usually I prefer to fill at least half of my plate with that). Considering the portion sizes at this place...a must do --- more greens. 

The food was alright, a bit cold, so maybe that's why it tasted not as it should. If they would make a few tiny changes, this place would be even more popular. For about $10 you get a lot of food, so I guess it's worth it.
author: Katja S.

description:
The roasting of Sorabol Korean Restaurant : 

Restaurant? More like a tired assembly line of crap Korean food. I know my Korean cuisine quite well, and this hole in the wall doesn't even deserve their 20 feet of frontage down in the Westfield food court. 

The spicy snapper was a dried, overcooked disaster, and although the barbecue eel didn't suffer the same fate, I only got two little morsels of it! How selfish, overrated, overpriced can you possibly get before someone puts a "restaurant" in check? Well, I'll tell you: 

Within the next year, the worst of the overrated slave-kitchens down in this food court will go bankrupt and close their doors. Sorabol will most certainly be one of those belly-flops. Afterward, the tired, crabby, and overstressed workers here will have to shuffle around to their next miserable food service job.
author: Daniel C.

description:
There are two of these in the SF area I know of and neither actually serve anything remotely Korean.  It seems to be a new fusion of cheap leftover meat from Asian grocery stores and day old vegetables from Panda Express.  

As a Korean, I find it very insulting and now know how Chinese folks must feel walking into any of the variation of Panda Express.

The only thing Korean about his place might be the small servings of kimchee - but even that is not very good.
author: H L.

description:
Grabbed dinner here last night before hitting a movie; it was cheap, fast and tasty. What more can you ask for?

Sharing a two item plate between two people with an extra potsticker for me and all-you-can eat kimchee is more than enough. 

Shortribs are awesome. Tofu and the fish don't translate well to sitting around under the heat lamp. I'd stick with the land animal meats.
author: dana l.

description:
Mall food, it's its own creature.

That said, Sorabol is some pretty good stuff, even though the kimchee is a little bland. I like this place because it is consistently good, and consistently more than I can eat, so a meal here is usually lunch the next day as well.

The chicken is good, as is the spicy pork, the seafood doesn't look to hot though.
author: Dave M.

description:
Now, I know starting out that this is a mall place to eat, but still, the point is to eat...
I had the two item meal consisting of spicy pork and spicy chicken.  Allow me to say that the "spicy" part is all well and good, and this is one reason I ordered from here.  But well, when it come to the meat, that's getting pretty iffy...
The pork, it had stringy pieces of omentum or facia of the tissue in the food, so you had to peel the meat off the connective tissue, and the chicken... I assume it's chicken... pieces of it were so burnt I couldn't tell, and there was gristle and what I'm now assuming was the tail... all chicken (I still wonder) but can't they upscale to a occasional breast meat piece?  
For all the guess work of what I was eating and seperating my food from etable and non-etable, I think KFC would have at least been better quality.
author: Jim H.

description:
This place is good when you are hungry and want something fast, tasty and moderately priced.  I've tried the Kal-bi (short ribs), Bul Gogi (BBQ beef), and Dak Gui (bbq chicken), all are quite respectable.  The noodle soups are comforting/filling when it's cold and dreary.

We pick this place regularly when coming home late on a workday and we don't feel like cooking or cleaning.  But, in terms of being real authentic Korean, not so much...The banchan selection is definitely lacking.
author: Burrito M.

description: This place is like any of the Sorabols in any other mall. Great Mall is when I 1st had this but it's nothing special. My friend thinks the kim chee here is weak and needs more vinegarette. The portions are big but very very greasy. I would suggest just driving down Geary Blvd and get some great Korean food there instead.
author: Danster L.

description: Many days, Sorabol seems to have a crowd waiting while the food vendors next to them seem empty.  So the food must be good, right?  Actually, some of it is very decent, and the price is right.  The kalbi is good as many bbq places that charge much more.  The spicy pork is also quite good, and one pleasant surprise was the dumpling soup (mandoo-gook).  The chapchae that accompanies the plates is lacking though - it is oily and has no veggies. One thing I've noticed is that the amount served can vary depending on the person, so that's another inconsistency.  OK, so it isn't fine dining Korean style, but it's not bad (execept the chapchae) and it's cheap and filling.
author: Peter L.

description: This isn't the best Korean food, but it sure satisfies my cravings for it though.  It also isn't my first choice when coming to this food court, but if the line is short then I'm in it!  If you're eating here for lunch, avoid the fish - it gives you super bad breath and is really tough to get rid of when returning to the office.
author: Lisa R.

description: Stopped here for lunch before the holiday.  As usual, good portions especially if you eat-in (any other food court that serves dine-in on actual glassware?).  I had the combo, spicy pork and bbq chicken, which was tasty, but the pork tasted a little stale.  Jap chae and brocolli were done well.  Ask for sauce on rice as rice is a bit on the dry side.  I don't think there's any other food court with this kind of selection (Asquew, Buckhorn, Thai, Beard Papa, Crepes, pasta/pizza, burgers, Soup Co., etc.).
author: Mike C.

description: Their chicken was delicious but the meat is not recommended. I like Coriander next door way better though!
author: Dana S.

description: Honestly, I did not expect Sorabol to be good at all. A mall restaurant?? But surprise do come in steamy Korean food filled packages I guess. More pricey than a fast food or your typical steam-food tray Asian place at the mall, but the food is well worth it. Spicy pork, MHMMM!! So tasty, juicy (not sure what other yelpers ate), and very well made. Their BBQ chicken is average (just like every other place in the mall). The spicy pork is where they shine, but if thats where they shine, then their glass noodles are where they glow! Although, not the best I've had, it was definitely good for the price I paid and where I was, a mall. Definitely recommend this place, if you're in the mall and feeling some Asian food, it won't dissappoint.
author: Kevin L.

description:
When i first walked into the westfield mall i expected to see the usual crappy mall chains, but definitely not as this one.

I was in dire need of some Korean food/bbq and this was the first thing i saw when i walked into the food court.

The bulgogi and beef short ribs are some of the best you can get for such a cheap price. I bought a beef short rib plate which came with 6-7 strips of short ribs, steamed rice, steam vegetables, and a side of these transparent sweet tasting noodles that were to die for.

This place is a great stop for lunch, isn't too expensive, and has super fast service. A must try if you are in the mall!
author: Kenneth M.

description: I eat here sometimes. They give you a ton of food, which is awesome. Their bbq beef and chicken have weird tendon things that make it hard to chew tho. I am a big fan of their mackarel a la carte though! Delicious with a wedge of lemon :)
author: Xavier G.

description: All I order is a Veggie Bowl with BBQ chicken on the side and extra kimchee!!! NUFF SAID!! They cater how I want it.
author: Rick T.

description: "Sorry Bowl" would be a better name for this place.  I ordered the grilled chicken with rice.  The chicken was grilled to death --- dryer than you can imagine --- and such a large portion of food was heaped on the plate that it was extremely unappetizing.  The accompaniment of glass noodles was pretty good, but that did not make up for the poor quality of the rest of the dish.  Fortunately, SF Centre has plenty of other dining choices so I won't have to come to this place again.
author: J. L.

description: Korean comfort food! Americanized of course but tasty none the less. I went with the pretty basic bbq chicken which came with clear noodles, rice and broccoli. It was very filling, had leftovers for the next day. Well worth the price.
author: La C.

description:
Huge portion for less than $15 including drinks! I had their 2 item combo...had the short ribs and the salmon. My plate was loaded and I seriously had a hard time finishing it up! Luckily, my bf is a garbage disposal and he inhaled my left overs for me! 

The salmon was dry and the beef was kinda ehh...i think there are better to places to eat at in this food court!
author: Theresa B.

description: Great food and the best deal at the mall. For $8, you can feed 2 people.
author: Peter S.

description:
Spanish Mackeral....so difficult to find...non-Asians say: soooo fishy.

Okay, fish is fishy.  And Spanish Mackeral is quite fishy, and I adore it.  It doesn't need any adornment or spices.  Just a bit of salt, broil it, and it's ready. 

And that's the way Sorabol at Westfield Mall serves it.  You get some rice, some naemool, chapchae, kimchi, and it's perfect for lunch.

I can't wait to get some more Spanish Mackeral.
_____

Update: the LA ribs seemed a bit oversweet to me.  But it's still a great bargain: rice, chapchae, and 3 ribs for $8 with some broccoli and free kimchi.  And it's tough when you are jonesing for Korean food in downtown SF....gotta take what you can.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Not the best Korean food ever (it's in the food court of a mall) but it'll do when you're in a hurry and need quick take-out options and you're tired of sandwiches, salads, burritos, and other usual quick fare.  They give you a takeout container piled high with food (usually when you order one meat/fish/poultry it comes with rice, glass noodles, vegetable, and kimchi.)  Don't bother with the kimchi - it's not good kimchi - and I'm a fan of kimchi.  Theirs is oversalted and watered down, and a poor representative of kimchi for first-timers.

I like their BBQ beef and BBQ pork, and their grilled fish.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
Of all the delicacies that SF has to offer, it still misses the mark with Korean cuisine.  So to add a tad bit more salt to that gashing wound, they offer this.  Korean fast food?  Just because you spike your prices up, and offer it up in a nice bowl, doesn't quite do the trick for me.  How come the bulgogi and kalbi tastes SO SWEET? And why do they offer me a 'sweet sauce' once I get all the meats on my plate?  The only saving grace is that the small cups of kimchee can be unlimited...(as most of the time, I'm with non-adventurous ROUND-EYES, and they just plop their cups of the fermented goodness onto my tray!!!!!).

But maybe there's something that I don't know about, as this joint in the food court is constantly off the hook in terms of traffic.  Perhaps if they would offer soju on the menu to soothe the sweetness of the meat, would I  make a recommendation to a friend who is dying for a slice of K-food to try this joint....
author: Dale K.

description:
This place is hit or miss with me.
Today wasn't their day...or mine

I decided and  ordered the grilled chicken plate.

With the plate you get, 
A huge portion of grilled chicken
Steamed rice
Broccolli
Sauce

Here's the problem:
The chicken was undercooked
The rice was soggy and overcooked
And you call that sauce. It's more like sugary soy sauce and water...WTF
For my 8.50 I could've gotten better elsewhere. A friend of mine told me to try the beef next time, but I'll have to double think that after today's unpleasant experience. 

Come on people, you should know how to GRILL a MF chicken!
author: Charlene C.

description:
It looks like Korean food but it does not talk like Korean food. It does not speak to your tongue and intestines with the great fire and intensity that real Korean food of such color would. Everything is sugar but not much else spice, and not very nice at all.

Especially disappointing was the spicy pork, which with all that rich redness promised to make my eyes tear with joy and excruciating pain, but instead brought a plateful of greasy, gristly, sugary crap.

And ma-po tofu as one of the regular offerings? And at that appalling quality? Bitch, please.

Alongside that one Japanese place whose name I cannot (don't want to is more like it) remember, this is my absolute least favorite eatery at the Westfield cafeteria.
author: Nuri K.

description: I like the side of glossy noodles that comes w/ the meal. But I'm staying away from the pale off-white colored item that's suppose to be Salmon.
author: EmmettsGuRL C.

description:
The BBQ chicken was really good.  The pot stickers on the other hand were terrible.  I got it to go so the portion was very big, definitely enough for two people.

I work at SF state downtown so I have tried basically every place in this mall and they are all overpriced.  They same can be said about Sorabol as well.

Try a local Korean place, I am sure you will have a much better experience.
author: ben G.

description:
i am okay with this place. they sell me ginormous containers of kimchee for $3 and kind of side-eye me for not buying rice to go with it. i hate that i have to go to an effing mall food court to indulge my kimchee cravings. seriously, where my koreans at? i guess you all moved to north oakland? waaaah.

that said, if you can deal with all the maddeningly annoying aspects of malls, THIS is your cheap kimchee hookup in sf.
author: Jane P.

description:
SORABOL SLIPPING?

I eat at Sorabol every time I go to Westfield Mall Food Court. It's usually a good tasty value for around $10, without a soda. Being part Korean, I know what great Korean food is, and this place is a nice fast option. 

Tonight I had items I've had many times before, barbecue beef and mackerel. The beef had very little flavor, but worse than that, the quality of the meat was not like it usually is. The meat was really fatty and I actually had to spit out a large bite into my napkin. The mackerel had a lot more bones than it usually does, and this time I only got 1 piece of fish versus 2 when I ordered it in the past.

Maybe one of these days I'll venture over to the other food vendors...
author: Foodie F.

description:
It's food that makes you hungry for real Korean food.

That being said, it's filling, won't make you sick, and the price is right. The free kimchi is actually not bad at all. I don't dislike Sorabol, but it's definitely not a first-string player.
author: Mark W.

description: I really enjoyed this place! I guess it's because I'm used to going to KBBQs where you cook your own food. They don't have a place like this where I'm from. I was really happy with the food and the portions. They weren't very stingy on the food which always makes me happy.
author: Lauren Y.

description: I had the spicy beef soup and it was a good portion. Great for being inside a mall, price was under $10, the line was full. Would come back!
author: Tamila L.

description: Fast food Korean BBQ chicken with Tariyaki sauce is tasty.  Their kimchi is spicy woo~~~ water water!!
author: Bella A.

description: Having lived in Korea for quite a while, I had high hopes for Sorabol when visiting SanFran. The food isn't authentic (why so many carrots and broccoli on everything?) and tastes so-so. I concur with others that it's greasy and frankly just not very appetizing. I'm looking forward to a decent fast-casual/food Korean restaurant in this country.
author: Michael R.

description:
It's not that good.  As a hang-guk sa-ram, I'm fairly picky when it comes to Korean food.  I suspect that the majority of the good reviews for the place are from people that don't have extensive experience with korean food.  Otherwise, they'd see that the meats are overcooked, and the "noodles" are bland and tasteless.  

If you think this place is good, do yourself a favor and try a REAL Korean place!  

I wouldn't eat here even if I was at Westfield and craving Korean food.  I'd get something else, then a cream puff from the Beard Papa's there.
author: Matt P.

description:
It's really terribly mediocre - some kind of awkward replacement for Korean food.

BUT I give two stars since for the price, the portions are large, and an entree includes not only a bit of rice, but noodles as well - and kim-chee.
author: G J J.

description:
After a long day of shopping, I needed some carbs. My friend and I headed down to grab a bite.

I had the one item combo with the grilled chicken and it's served with a huge mound of white rice, chop chae (glass noodles) and two stalks of broccoli.

It came out to $8+ and you can help yourself to the kim chee, which was pretty tasty.

I can't say I've really had "authentic" Korean food, but this was great if you didn't want to spend a fortune ordering a la carte at some of the other food stalls.
author: Eva C.

description: They used to give you lots of  food BUT not anymore.....so expensive now  .I always stop to get  food  every  Fridays......now no more
author: Voo D.

description: Great pork pot stickers, tasty sauce on the spicy barbequed pork, free kimchi that tastes pretty good... did I forget anything? The people that work here don't speak Korean or English, I swear they talk Mongolian (goddamn Mongorians! it's not racism - it's South Park, in case you missed the reference). Oh, it's not very authentic, at all, and they don't know how to cook their rice properly, it's always too mushy... and Koreans don't eat Japchae with every meal. Broccoli is a fairly recent trend in imported vegetables in Korean cuisine. Oh, and Mapo Tofu isn't even Korean, it's Chinese, and green peas never really caught on in Korean cuisine, aside from the fact that a Korean person would not consume soft tofu in a sauce, it would be in a stew as a main ingredient. And no one in Asia uses that much sugar in their soups and marinades. This place is a lie!
author: Y K.

description: Glad they had the option of Korean food in the SF Westfield mall! Sorabol is consistently delicious for it being "fast food". However, having had sorabol in the LA area more often, I'd have to say this SF one does not taste as good as its sister branches. The portions were extremely generous, but the chap chae was bland and this particular sb did not give me the option of picking my pickles/vegetables (my favorite part of the dish!). Most of the time, they will just give you steamed broccoli with whatever meat you order. In order to get their legit pickles, you'd have to order a side "salad" dish for another ~$7. This sorabol is also a bit pricey ($8-$12 per dish) and did not give you as much flexibility as other sb's.
author: Kasey N.

description: First of all, this has got to be the most classy food court I've ever been to. With that said, the prices are fairly decent as well. And the food...well, the food is amazing! Actually, I speak of Sorabol since it's the only place I tried today but everything else looked quite appetizing. Had the bbq beef combo. For $10, you get a a huge mound of beef, rice, jab chae, a side of veggies and a side o kimchi. Seriously? Unheard of. The mister and I had a tough time finishing ONE plate b/c it was seriously THAT much food. Will be back for more and I'm not just saying that because of the quantity but the quality was top-notch. By that, I mean, restaurant quality food in a fast-food (food court) setting for the price of...CHEAP! Hit it up!
author: Allison M.

description: Very Disappointing. I had the beef ramen bowl (not spicy version). It had no flavor. Won't be going back to try anything else.
author: Arek M.

description: Pretty good place. very consistent. usually go here when visiting the mall. i always go for the spicy bbq pork or spicy bbq chicken rice. they give u glass noodles too. caution. if you can only tolerate mild spicyness, their "hot" really is hot. sometimes it's so hot that you can't enjoy the food, though they seem to have toned it down a bit lately. the kim chi is good. with bottled water, it'll come out to about $10. i didn't know until going to yelp that they have several restaurants in and around sf.
author: Hagow C.

description: Upon arriving in San Francisco and traveling on the BART, I arrived at the Westfield Centre pretty hungry. I walked through the mall and made my way to the food court to be pleasantly surprised. Food courts back home don't serve food on plates and bowls! After much thought, I decided on Sorabol. The glass noodles and the spicy BBQ chicken was just what I needed after a relatively long flight. The fried rice and kimchi were just okay but overall good solid food court food.
author: Mark Y.

description: WORST FOOD EVER! Don't let your eyes fool you. It looks good and it seems like you are getting what you are paying for. You may even call it a miracle to consume such good looking food with a decent price of about $8-$10. Don't be fooled! The chicken is hard and nasty! I feel like they just recently took it out of the freezer and left it out for a couple of hours to leave the impression that it's delicious. BUT ITS NOT! Not only will you loose $10 or less... But may ruin your whole experience at this mall! If I was you... Don't trust what you see! Trust with your taste budds and the rough and untender meat!
author: Ronnel C.

description:
Ate there lunchtime 10/16/06.  Got grilled chicken over glass noodles.  That was pretty good.  Chicken was nice and tender, not overcooked.

But, no water.  Not even glasses!  This is even worse than Coriander Gourmet Thai in the same food court!  What are they THINKING??
author: Tom H.

description:
This may not be totally authentic, but it's cheap and it's filling and it's good on its own.  

Note, proper uses of itses and it'ses.
author: Frankie D.

description:
Located in the fabulous food court in the new section of the SF Center.  This is the first time I tried Korean food in SF outside of Brother's on Geary.  Heck, it's the first time I've actually tried "Fast" Korean food.

For the most part the meat is pretty standard with your Gal-Bi, Bul-go-hi, Dae-ji, etc.  The meat is grilled there and seemed fresh, however I"m pretty biased to grilling my own meat over some hot coals.  I mean can you really eat Korean BBQ, without getting the smell of it on your clothes?

We tried this place out because they started serving noodle soup and we were in the mood for something soupy.  The soup was very bland, it was basically broth with stuff put in it.  The quantity was plentiful but the flavor was lacking.  

For as busy as the food court is, I'm pretty surprised at how friendly they were considering how rushed they can be.  I'd go for the meat if you need a quick fix of Korean munchies.  You get a lot for what you pay for, that's for sure.
author: Yehoy L.

description:
Not really Korean... but the portions are generous, have good sides (mmm Kim Chee)... and the food is pretty good. 

Really, when going to a food court, my expectations are pretty low to start, but this place definitely met them, and somewhat exceeded (given the relativity). 

Worth trying when you are looking for food in a pinch.
author: Jordan Y.

description: talk about quick and no nonsense grub...the bbq chicken will get you filled and energized for your after lunch or dinner event..the japchae is well made..love the free all u can eat kimchee and also friendly quick service with a smile is very welcoming :) the only place i go to besides out the door and buckhorn grill for grub in the mall. 4/5 hiyaaasss!!
author: Dustin G.

description: the food is not the great anymore..and they dont give free kimchi anymore with ur order....sucks
author: Gary N.

description: I had the veggie bowl with the bugolgi (marinated beef), after the lady behind the counter told me it was like bibimbop.  It's not really like bibimbop--there's no sauce and the "toppings" are kind of random.  You get cucumbers, broccoli, clear noodles, mushrooms, and at least two more things piled on top of rice.  The serving is HUGE.  The bugolgi was okay, not the tenderest but it had flavor.  So, this place is not authentic, but if you're really hungry, you get a lot of food for the money.  Two stars because I've had similarly priced bibimbop that was so much better.
author: Christine L.
