description: There was convention at Moscone center and some of my Korean engineers visited SF. and they wanted to have Korean food. so I brough them Sorabol. Well, Looks very nice and delicious. i couldn't even choose which I wanna have. cause most of them I wanted. :) It was quite big portion and very tasty! I love it!!!
author: Julie K.

description: They are always so crowded, no matter when I go! I asked my roommate what was so special about it, and she said that it was because they give you a lot of food. So when I was at the mall last week on a Wednesday around 3PM (aka empty from tourists and general food-consumers!) and noticed that there was no line, I immediately rushed in! They have a real menu, as well as one of those things where you pick rice or noodles and then 2 sides, but I just stuck with the regular menu, since the portions on their mainplate+sides looked so huge and I wasn't that hungry. I got the beef noodle soup, which came out to be about $9. And yes, the portion on this was still HUMONGOUS. And I got to collect a small container of kimchi too! Foodwise, the kimchi was fresh and well made, and so were the noodles. I just didn't feel like my beef was super well cooked, and I wish my soup had more seasoning...or something. Just tasted plain.
author: Melody L.

description: After spending the past 3 weeks craving Korean food, I was pretty excited to see this place in the mall food court. I don't know what it is - but it can barely be called Korean food.  It might as well be lumped together with all the other watered-down food court takeouts. The few things that did represent - the japchae could at least pass for japchae, and the kimchi was more authentic than i expected. I didn't try the short ribs. As for the rest, you might as well be eating beef with broccoli or pork with garlic sauce.
author: Bern H.

description:
Always such a long line!

It doesn't taste like real Korean food, a lot sweeter, actually, but still a good place when you feel like eating Korean dishes in a casual setting in the city.
author: Dyne L.

description:
I LOVE this place! I know generally the mall is not known for having great food, but as an employee in the mall, Sorabol has been one of my favorites since moving here in July. The food is great and even when I'm not working, I often bring friends to this place because it's always fresh and very quick.

Try the short ribs! It's delicious!
author: Katherine F.

description: Tasty, ostensibly expensive, but actually quite large and filling, "Korean-inspired" food that's also quick and convenient for lunch. I most often get the spicy BBQ chicken. One caveat: I didn't feel satisfied by the soup when I ordered it. With the meats, I usually have about a third of my food leftover and I bring it home for another meal for myself or my boyfriend.
author: Nicholas F.

description: Stopped here before hopping on the BART.  It's definitely not authentic Korean but for chain food, it did the trick.  Portions are crazy big, like hella big.  I barely finished half of my bulgogi.  I tasted the short ribs and they were good, also.  I appreciated the quick and friendly service.  Furthermore, this place is cheap, i spent a little under $10 for two meals worth of food.  Be warned though - my side of vegetables consisted of 4 pieces of broccoli.  Nice place if you're pressed for cash and time.
author: Ryan L.

description: Dined my college years away at Sorabol in Emeryville while studying for midterms, and have grown to love their huge portions. Their spicy chicken, while probably not authentic Korean food, is a great entree. They give you a HUGE amount of food, and have added things like chapchae noodles over the past 10 years. The new kalbi stew is also quite good. This is typically my first choice at this or the emeryville public market food courts.
author: Walter W.

description:
You can't beat the price for a two item at $8.95 which includes two choices of meat and rice noodles, rice, and veggies along with a side of kimchi. 

Get the kalbi (shortribs) and spicy chicken as you won't be disappointed. I didn't care too much for the kimchi as it was on the bland side. Not spicy enough for me.
author: S L.

description:
Once again, Korean food never disappoints me with their spicy food!
I am an absolute fan of spicy food!! and i suggest getting the spicy bbq chicken!!! yuma yumma yumma in the tummy :P... its a bit overpriced i would say, but its good!!! go for it!

-x3 shells
author: Lily X.

description:
I like this Korean restaurant,everytime I bored with another food,I always go there,say hi to my friend who work there and get delicius BBQ Chicken and BBQ short ribs.
Remind me when I was In Seoul...........................................................
kamsamida
author: chris j.

description: It's not exactly the best Korean around but for being in a food court, it's pretty damn good.  They have your basic Korean bbq- bulgogi, kalbi, etc. with rice and chap jae (clear noodles) for about $12 and I can make 2 meals out of that.  Don't forget to get some kimchee after you pay- it's in little plastic containers to the right of the cash registers.
author: Maxine S.

description: Well you really can't go wrong with Sorabol, the food is always good. This location gives pretty big portions, ribs are good noodles are good and the chicken is good!
author: Karen T.

description:
i know ima gonna loss all sorts of korean food cred here, but damn it, last night, the la kalbi and chicken plate was not that bad. actually better than that, it was pretty damn decent. 

i hate to give korean places good ratings. 

im korean. 

koreans dont like anyone whos not korean.... 

and they dont like each other all that much either. 

no but, yeah, im korean, i grew up on this shit. mama lee aint no joke in the kitchen. i am also a korean cooking genius. (and also humble!).

so back to the sorabol. man, i must say, i couldnt complain. this should actually be a four star review. for what you pay, its damn good. really damn good. i wouldnt mind eating it for lunch right now. 

but its crazy how they charge 3 bucks for a few pieces of banchan, but hey, mercedes and burberry dont pay for themselves right? stick with the free kimchee around the corner from the cashier. 

note must be made, actually, their kimchee is pretty damn decent too. VERY SURPRISING. most place take soooo many short cuts with their kimchee, it just inedible. this was really not that bad at all.


EDIT : LET ME MAKE THIS CLEAR. FOR WHAT YOU PAY, ITS PRETTY DECENT KOREAN FOOD. $10 FOR A PLATE OF DECENT MEAT AND RICE AND JAPCHAE.
author: Euge L.

description: I know, I know.  Not for the purists.  However...  Fast food Korean from a mall next to public transportation just rules, ok?  The veggie bowl (bibimbap) and soft tofu stew (soondooboo jigae) are hugely satisfying and tasty enough (and I mean hugely), especially for someone who can't drive out to the Richmond District for the real stuff.    The kimchee ain't bad either.
author: Esther R.

description: For fast food Korean, it wasn't bad.  A 2 item combo plate with drink ran me just under $10...which I consider pretty good being that it's in the new Westfield Mall.  For that I had huge plate filled with spicy chicken, short ribs, rice, noodles, and the dreaded vegetables.  I could not finish my plate, even though someone was helpin' me by picking at it.   It's better than the Italian place down there.
author: JeFF T.

description: The portions here are huge for lunch! I enjoyed the japchae or noodles, but the bulgogi (beef) wasn't that great.  If I'm back in the area, I'd probably try something else, but for the price it a'int bad.
author: Eugene H.

description: quick lunch here is awesome. I love how generous they are with their food portion. Pretty good for mall food. I like their short ribs and their noodles are tasty. Meals comes with free kim chee!! :)
author: Ernie P.

description:
My incident with Sorabol is a clear reflection of the state of our economy.  In line at Sorabol, I contemplated "just short ribs or pay another dollar for a second item?"  I concluded, "What the heck, my ribs could use a sick-kick."  I walked up to the woman, told her I wanted two items: short ribs and salmon.  She filled up my plate with rice, ONE PIECE of short rib, three sad pieces of dry salmon, and a crapload of broccolis and lemons.  My first thought to myself was "You're such a fat pig, why do you need to eat so much anyway?"  Then my glutton self got angry; I've been a patron here a ton of times before and I know they usually give you substantially more.  This is not right to try to gyp me.  

I asked the woman "Can you give me another piece of the short rib?"  She looked perplexed and walked back to the short ribs.  She took the piece that she had placed on my plate BACK and picked up another, asking "Is this piece fine?"  She thought I had wanted to switch the pieces!  A line of five parties had formed behind me.  I would have to be a real jerk to argue with this woman or cancel my order.  I said, "Forget it," and thought "I'll just pay for this and never show my face here again."  Despite the fact that they charge you up the butt, I still could have respected if they had admitted the truth, which is that the economy isn't doing too well and they need to make up for losses somehow.  Even if I haven't eaten my meal with bitterness, the salmon still would have been hard and dry.  It's MALL food, where you lacked in quality, you could at least try to make up with quantity, but no.  So they have nothing going for them.
author: Lily T.

description: There are so many choices to eat at this food court but I am always ordering food from this place.  When you are a fatty variety isn't that great especially when its not a buffet.  For some reason I always end up eating chop chae, fried rice, bbq beef and the teriyaki chicken here.  Why?  I have no freaking idea.  Its good but its not great.  Lately the portions have been shrinking in size.  Sorabol, when you see a fatty in line please give the fatty more food.  I didn't get fat by eating small protions.  *xoxo*
author: Fatty A.

description: The food actually wasn't bad at all but they were a little skimpy on the portions.  There was hardly any rice on the 2 item combo and if you pick short ribs as one of your combo choices they only give you one piece.  And it's not that cheap, $10 for mall food seems a bit much.
author: Jen C.

description: Pretty good Korean food, for a food court type place.  If this was a restaurant, I'd only give it maybe 3 stars.  But again, among food court booths, this was not bad.  A bit overpriced.  But good for a quick Korean food fix if you are in a rush and near Powell/Market.  Bi bim bap/bob I had was actually better than some full-on Korean restaurants in the city.
author: Jack H.

description: Best food I've had at a restaurant in a mall. The spicy pork was really good.
author: Anu J.

description: After checking out Bristol Farms, I was hungry.  I was overwhelmed by the crowds so I looked for a place that seemed familiar--this was it.  I did want to try something new but again, didn't want to get mobbed by the crowds. I love Sorabol so I went to the line.  Unlike the one in Stonestown, I felt that the portions were a little smaller (which is good) but they gave me a little bit of rice and needed more because there was more spicy chicken..but it's okay, I still ate the damn thing.  I got the spicy chicken bowl (again! and always!) and I  thought it was cool they put the food in an actual bowl rather than a styrofoam one.  Anyway, still got love for them!
author: Mel P.

description:
i used to go to school in the city and would come here on my lunch whenever i was craving korean bbq and was pressed for time. the menu selection is pretty wide considering it's located in a high scaled food court atmosphere. in terms of price and service, it's a bit outrageous for "mall food" that hired associates just splat food on to a plate for you. however, they are consistently friendly throughout the transaction.

portions here are huge so i would definitely suggest ordering as take out so you won't have to ask for a box later. i usually order ale carte to save the bucks and box. who wants to sit in a classroom smelling like kimchi right? the food isn't made to order, but rather sitting out on hot steam trays and made to fill. the quality and taste is still good though. satisfied my craving for the time being any how.

my only issue is that they're tad shady when it comes to the kimchi and pickled cucumbers. it's a one per order deal and trust me, they'll remind you several times if you try to take more.
author: Julia C.

description: for food court food, sorabol isn't bad. I like the vermicelli. The food's on the oily side, but it's alright. I like spicy food, but the spiciness of the bbq chicken was INTENSE! I couldn't stand it. For the pork, it was drenced in oil and VERY SPICY. I liked it, but they gave me a huge fat part, and I don't eat that part.. So -1 star for that, but I like it here. I like how they serve i on real plates.
author: Bonita C.

description: I liked their food I really did... but today I was NOT  happy. I had a 30 min lunch break so I went to Sorabol, ordered rice with short ribs and broccoli to go. Got my food in a quickness and headed back to my store. 15 mins left to eat and guess what I saw!! An unwanted  dead squiggly tiny thing on my broccoli!!!. So I took my order back and got my cash back. They gave me rice n short ribs for free... but I was still mad. 5 mins left for my break...and didnt enjoy my lunch at all. So therefore... sorry but I rate this place only 1 star because of that. I don't think I'll be going there for a while. or at least no more broccoli from sorabol.
author: joy c.

description: This our favorite amongst all the restaurants at the food court. The food is not bad, and exceptional when it comes to mall food. And they do give you a huge portion to make it worth the price. Especially compared to their chain at Stonestown, which gives out tiny teeny portions!
author: Chris Y.

description: Big portions. I order the bbq chicken or beef, and they give me extra rice when I turn down the noodles. So it comes down to a plate of beef/chicken, rice and some broccoli. The meat quality could be better, but it's something I can order at the Westfield Food Court for under $10.
author: Matt N.

description:
sorabol has some tasty and flavorful short-ribs! i wasn't expecting too much, but when i took the first bite. i was like,"ohhh, wow! they marinated the meat perfectly."  

also, they give really generous portions of side dishes (i.e.  steamed white rice, noodles & broccoli along with 3 long pieces of short ribs) honestly, i feel like it's a great combination because you get a little bit of everything from veggies to meat.  

if you want a spicy kick to your taste buds, then you can grab some well-ripped kim-chi (complimentary) and they have some hot sauce called "goh-choo-jang."  it's so yummy when you dip the meat and eat it with rice.

so far, i've been there twice and this place is looking pretty good and  also made my stomach smile. :D

[happy eating!!!]
author: Deborah C.

description:
I tried the chicken cutlet for the first time and I would not recommend this dish to anybody. The chicken seems like it's been prepared way in advance. My food took too  long and when it came out, it was cold and tough. I thought the reason it took too long was they were grilling or deep frying the chicken - well, it was cooked in the microwave.

The only good thing about this dish is the clear noodles and the eggs. 

Seemed like this place was not prepared for a long crowd. With that many people working (about 7), they did not have their act together. 

If any of you had the ribs, bbq chicken or the chicken - definitely order these dishes but not the chicken cutlet.
author: Lileth M.

description:
kinda surprised to find decent mall food.
of course, i had the kalbi.  marinade was decent...
sure, it can be variable overall since it's fast food
I recommend going when there is a line so that there is faster turnover of their food.
u get enough to share.
banchan extra...what?!
author: Rob C.

description: What can you say? It's food court food. Simple dishes warming over hot plates a la buffet. But as far as food court's go, it's not bad. They load up your plate with a lot so after a few bites I'm full... an amazing feat since I love eating and am known to clean the plate. There's usually too much leftover to throw away so I take it home for lunch the next day. :) All that good food wasted!? You crazy? ...starving kids and whatnot.
author: Frances L.

description: For a meal in a mall, it doesn't get better than this. Yes, the entire food court at Westfield is fairly to die for, but this place rocks big time.  The short ribs melt in your mouth and the glass noodles are quite the party. Chickens pretty good and the rice is well prepared. Wish you got a few more veggies, but still, totally worth every penny...
author: Brittany T.

description: After reading great reviews on Sorabol, I tried it this afternoon.  I ordered the short ribs.  However, it was too fatty and there was barely any meat on them.  It is true about the huge portions but I was bummed out on the short ribs.
author: Megan R.

description: 4-stars for the $7.99 Lunch Special - Seafood Tofu Soup.  Huge steaming bowl enough for two, but I ate most of it since it was pretty darn good!
author: A. L.

description: I went there last night for dinner, and not 2 hours later i was already throwing up! i don't think their food is really fresh! I was sick all night and will never eat there again!
author: Carole G.

description: Huge, HUGE portions, so this is a good place to eat at the mall if you've overspent upstairs.  The relative bang for the buck is compromised by the quality though.  The vegetables are invariably over or undercooked and the meat's texture has been a bit gristly in the past.  Now that I've been disappointed twice, I'll just stick with a Beard Papa snack.
author: Katina M.

description: When I met my fiance, I hated white rice.  But let's face it, when you date or marry an Asian man, you need to learn to love it.   Seriously.  Also, my mother only served us white meat chicken when I was growing up.  But let's face it, when you date or marry an Asian man, you need to learn to eat some sketchy cuts of chicken, or you won't eat at all (especially at the divey places in the Sunset).  Anywhoo, the spicy chicken rice plate at Sorabol is pretty good.  It comes with chicken, rice, an ENORMOUS helping of glass noodles, and some steamed broccoli.  Naturally, the meat is often chewy (gristly) albeit plentiful.  It's all about quantity over quality here at Sorabol Korean Restaurant.
author: Poker B.

description:
maybe they read one of the yelp reviews (re: tiny girl claims portions are too small) because i am not a tiny asian girl and i eat tons and i couldn't finish my portion of food.  eh eh eh?  how's that possible?

anyways, i thought their portion was pretty large... unless the server got really frazzled by the crazy homeless lady in front of me in line that just started banging at the glass that she forgot she was still piling on chicken on my plate. 

their bulgogi does NOT look good, looks like it's over cooked and soggy, so i opted for the chicken, which was pretty tasty.  the clear noodles were pretty blargh at first, but then i kinda liked them.  the broccoli is a definite "no" though.  if i'm going to eat a big ol' pile of meat, i don't expect trying to balance it out with tasteless broccoli.
author: H. L.

description: Best Sorabol that I've been to.  They give you heaping amounts of food.  The best part is the complimentary kimchee.  Love that I can get as many cups of kimchee as I want without paying extra ;)
author: Katelynn L.

description: If you don't mind BBQ chicken that's been pre-made and sitting in the buffet for awhile, then this is a good place for some fast Korean food.  Their jap chae is good albeit greasy, and I just wish they'd warm up the broccoli instead of serving it cold.
author: Lisey W.

description: Korean food, fast food style. Of course it's not going to be the world's best Korean food you would ever have in your life but it was pretty good coming from food court. If you are looking for a quick Korean fix, this would be you a good bet.
author: Jerald G.

description:
I always order the BBQ short ribs, with silver noodles (must try) and fried rice, and broccoli, drizzled with teriyaki sauce. It's really good. Kimchi is "comp", and you can get two cups of it. I sometimes order the seaweed on the side, or the sweetened anchovies (not sure actually if those are anchovies). Taste is good.

The only problem, as you may have noticed from the other reviews , is that the servings are TOO LARGE. Not human size at all. Quite pricey too for a food court-type of restaurant. I don't think you can spend less than $12 at this place. Ok, huge servings, so big bill: makes sense. But I just wish they could trim down the serving as well as the bill. Sure you can share the food with your friend and split the bill, but that's not always convenient, especially when you have different picks from the menu. 

But service is definitely quick.
author: Ryan M.

description: For awhile this was the only place I'd eat at in the Bloomingdale shopping mall because they give they hugest portions at ok prices.  Now their prices have increased and the portions have slimmed down a bit.  Avoid the bland soup noodles and stick to the barbeque plates.
author: Michael H.

description: My opinion might be biased as I ate here after a busy day at work where I didn't even get a chance to eat lunch. I was apprehensive about mall food but this place was SO tasty. I loved their noodles and I got the bbq chicken and it was delicious and flavorly. I also got their assorted sides which were yummy too. It's a little pricey for mall food in my opinion but I will definitely come back in the future for lunch.
author: Cathy T.

description:
Ok I'm going to 'fess to eating at this chain and liking it. Especially the Sorabol in Tanforan Center. Tops. The one at Stonestown? Not good. Flavorless. Which considering it's Korean food, is very weird to taste. It's all about the marinades and spices and they somehow lack it.

The Westfield Centre location one is great comparatively. The menu is very much limited, just basic chicken, pork and beef dishes. And then there are the noodle and soup dishes. We tried the rice plates. BBQ chicken, spicy pork and short ribs. The portions were just right. BBQ chicken was juicy without being underdone. The spicy pork was actually spicy. Which for mall food is an amazing thing. So many vendors think that customers don't actually want it to be spicy hot when that is 'the' description. I mean I know there are people that dumb who will complain 'Hey, that was too spicy!' Well, duh. that's why they call it 'spicy pork'. The short ribs were decent. The sides chosen were chap chae (sesame bean thread noodles) and bean sprouts. Tasty. The kimchee was not bad either. Though I always wonder why they give it out in such tiny little paper cups. I mean unless you truly love kim chee, a little bit will do you very nicely. It's just when you see how tiny the cups are, it makes you think 'cheap'. Nothing wrong with that. Just an impression.

The line to this place is pretty long but it's constantly moving and also this means that the food doesn't sit around for very long on the steam table. The line is also long because I think that when people get a look at the plates and bowls leaving the counter, it has immediate eye appeal. 

The prices to this location seem to be about a dollar more than the one's I've been to. But considering that it's downtown, it's priced competitively.

****3.8.07 So I've eaten here quite a few times now. The menu has gotten a bit larger. They've added calamari, salmon, lamb and noodle soups. The noodle soups are my new favorite thing! A large bowl of noodle with carrots, cabbage, bean sprouts, green onions and a main ingredient of your choosing. Chicken, beef, fish ball, won ton, seafood and a couple others are listed. It's tasty without being overwhelming. If you want to add a little more something to your noodles, dump a bit of the kim chee into the bowl. That'll spice it up nicely.
author: cyndi L.

description: Edible Korean food.  I had the spicy pork and opted for all jap chae instead of rice + jap chae.  They were more than happy to accomodate my request.  The spicy pork wasn't as flavorful as it looked and it had lots of fatty pieces.  I'll only be back because it's convenient.
author: Joann C.

description: Not bad for the price and portion.  That being said the galbi is pretty low quality meat. I have no problems with the authenticity as their marinade is actually not bad and their kimchi is pretty decent as well.  I'd rather take the money and get some buns at Out the Door or get some Panda Express.
author: Dan Y.

description: This review is particularly for the Sorabol in the San Francisco Westfield mall food court.  I have had Sorabol at other malls, but this Sorabol location is special.  Here, they give a massive amount of meat (I like the chicken) and they provide unlimited kimchee at the register.  I always have leftovers here and the meat is surprisingly tender and delicious.  This is the most price friendly place in this food court, and it tastes good!
author: Jennifer D.

description: HUUUUUGE plate of fried rice + vermecelli + lemon chicken + broccolli = $8.71 (with tax). For the amount of food they gave, it's waaaay worth it. (: They gave hellllllllllllla chicken. Well worth it. Woot. Quality was pretty good. Had to take the rest home. Ate the leftovers this morning for breakfast, and it still tasted pretty good. Woot.
author: Ava A.

description: A chain located in the San Francisco mall off Powell. This take-out offers around $8 meals that include rice, kimchi and your choice of charbroiled meats: galbi, chicken, and pork. The portion is large and the chicken is of good quality. Very crowded on the weekends, but makes a  great place for take-out while cruising around the mall off Market Street and Union Square.
author: Uland L.

description: If your almost broke but craving korean food really really bad...sorabol is the place to go! it's korean food at a cheap price and i'm not complaining! the dishes i've had so far are pretty spot on. if they only had the soups i love then i'd be there every week!
author: Suzan L.

description: Came back and had the veggie bowl with spicy pork (your choice of meat).  Yummy!  They add white rice, vermicelli, broccoli/typical veggies but also some of the vinegar marinated ones like cucumber, seaweed, and mushroom.  A nice treat.
author: Melinda C.

description: Sorabol is a chain Korean restaurant and it's actually mall chain food. But this one for a chain is pretty good and at the Westfield mall this location gives you a huge amount of food. Its in the mall food court so don't expect it to be gourmet Korean but its pretty damn good. It's a 100 times better than Hans Hibachi which by the way is like Sbarro's authentic Italian. At least Sbarro's is close. Hans Hibachi is just all sorts of wrong to be called korean. Anyways Sorabol in the Westfield mall is super good. Probably the busiest line of all the restaurants for a reason.
author: Hyung L.

description:
cheap and TONS of yummy food. i always order to go because they give you enough for two meals! during lunch the lines are long, but go quickly. 

please check out my food blog for a full review with photos!
author: Lily K.

description: So many choices, especially with the different kinds of fish and meat! There's always something you will like. And they always come with the glass noodles or rice and some veggies (definitely would prefer to have more vegetables...) Also, the taste tends to be a bit on the spicy side.
author: T L.

description: This place is great! I'm sure there are many great Korean restaurants out there, but for a fast food korean style place, you can't beat it. I had the spicy bbq chicken and it had just the right amount of spice and the amount of food they give you for the price is really good. My boyfriend had the bbq chicken and pork and that was really good, as well. I wish they had more places like this in the malls in my area, or else I'd totally hit up the mall food courts more often. I'll be back here whenever I'm shopping in the city.
author: Melissa C.

description: I think they serve their left overs from the night before in the morning because that's what my food tasted like. My bbq chicken taste really dry and rubbery even with sauce on it.  The cashier even screwed up our order and almost charged us $40! She even had the nerve to be annoyed when we pointed it out. WOW.
author: Dong Q.

description:
sorabol is a lousy excuse for korean fast food.... of the two evils, i'd go with hahn's hibachi any day...
of all these great new food court eateries in the new westfield extention... why sorabol?  eeek... and using the name for such an establishment is blasphemy!
i can't get over the crappy stuff they call kimchi at these locations... what a shame...
i don't ever want to waste my money on this again
author: charlotte s.

description: Sorabol is the place to go for mounds of delicious protein. The short ribs are quite delightful. If you have a craving for Korean BBQ Kalbi but don't want to smell like meat afterward, Sorabol is a good option. Its also a much more frugal option than going to a traditional Korean restaurant. I do warn that the pickled veggies and kim chi are not Sorabol's strong point - skip them if you can.
author: Judy L.

description: My first meal in the new Westfield while waiting for the BART.  Not bad, the beef was a little bland.  But for less than $10, you get a FULL plate, and you can sit right across from the gelato place and get psyched for dessert.
author: Mark D.

description: I work at the marriott right next to the westfield mall and when i'm really hungry and not feeling the food in the cafeteria.. this is where i always go. For less then 10 dollars i can get a 2 item plate, which also consist of rice, jap chae(noodles), and broccoli, but if you want to add a drink it abouts 11-12. They give you such a big portion! i can't even finish it. The food pretty good for being a fast food place, and they have free kimchee as well!!
author: Brian P.

description: Fast food korean food!! i love the spicy chicken and pork and also try the bbq. Price was not too bad. I recommend trying this place out if your shopping in the area.
author: Lloyd C.

description: The two times that I've eaten here, I had the same combination: BBQ chicken, rice, broccoli, and potstickers. Filling, and so goood. I get the teryaki sauce on everything and one time, extra soy sauce on the rice.  The BBQ chicken is really soft, and super flavorful. The rice is good too, and the potstickers are great. The only flaw is the broccoli, which didn't taste fresh to me. I would definitely come back though :) Mostly for the chicken, rice and potstickers of course.
author: Juju B.

description: Four stars for unlimited kimchi. This Sorabol is a lot cleaner than the one in Emeryville. The beef short ribs were tasty. Generous portions.
author: Inigo M.

description: Came by on a week night and there was just a few ppl in line unlike the madeness of the opening weekend. Ordered the Spicy BBQ Chicken Bowl which came with rice, noodles and a few stalks of brocolli and a tiny side of kimchi. The chicken was tender but not so spicy. Unfortunately, IMHO, I thought it was just so-so. Perhaps the Short Rib or Beef might have been better choices? Hmmm... I still prefer Coriander Gourmet Thai right next door any time.
author: Yan M.

description: This is Korean fare for a food court. It's a chain but nonetheless, quite yummy and I think decently priced. For under $10, I got a two-item meals (I looooooove Korean marinated meat) and that comes with rice AND jap-chae (big perk here!!), veggies (mostly just fresh steamed broccoli), and kimchi. Yum yum yum
author: Annie W.

description: I HEART balls...fish balls that is.  When I'm in the mood for Asian soup with noodles and broth but don't want pho or ramen, I eat here (or the one at Stonestown).  The portions at the SF Centre seem to be much larger than compared to the other locations.  Anyway, I love the fish ball soup because it has lots of veggies, noodles, and not-too-salty broth.  It's especially good on a cold, foggy day or when you've got a hang over.
author: Em C.

description: For $9 or so, they give you portions equivalent to two meals. The spicy pork is decent enough, just don't try to clear your plate...
author: Maximillian M.

description: Mmmmm! it was so nice!!!!!! i should have tried earlier!!! As a native Korean... i just underestimate this place because i thought that sorabol is just a food-chain... and even the servers are not korean...haha it was such a studid thought i admit! well i tried the spicy pork, and it was awesome nice. but it wasn't cut so...that could be a little flaw. but anyway... and the quantity?! that was the best... it was so much! god, i ate them all though. oh and the kimch is nice. worthy to try unless you hate a spicy food. it was not the best kimch that i have ever tried, but average. i can say. just try! you won't be disappointed...
author: Joe T.

description:
Great food for the price, esp in the mall. I ordered the bbq chicken with broccoli and rice for $8. I liked the chicken because it wasn't overly sweet or salty. Broccoli was fresh. Self served kim chi. Portion was big.

My friend's bbq beef was a bit too sweet and too too salty in my opinion. Maybe too much soysauce and sugar?

Sounds like the best deal among all food places in the food court.
author: kat c.

description: I guess Sorabol has never really lived up to the name or hype ever since they first opened.  If you consider their goal is to open up Korean food to all races and people, I might give this place 4 stars.  However as a Korean-American who can be picky about his Korean, I say this place isn't worth the money you will spend.  After not having touched the Korean Panda Express for years, I hit up the new Westfield SF Shopping Centre food court location for short ribs, chap-chae, rice, and a little tiny cup of kimchi.  I think I could make better ribs and chap-chae myself (and I'm a guy!) but the kimchi was actually alright - probably store bought as it tasted like Mannani brand.  Don't get me wrong, it's a quick Korean eat if you're craving Korean, but hopefully next time I'll be able to control my cravings.
author: Sokokyu K.

description: I must say I love the Korean Barbecue short ribs with clear noodles.  It is always grilled fresh and very tasty.  I don't care who I'm sharing a table with this is barbecue that is eaten with your hands.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it.  I think I'll get some for lunch.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Maybe this is because I'm from Milpitas and spoiled from many unwaveringly delicious Korean restaurants. The noodles had no flavor at all. Trust me, you can find cheaper Korean food that tastes a LOT better. The portions were big but bland. I consider this place overpriced. Even the dough on my potsticker was uncooked!
author: Taun T.

description:
I dont care too much that this place is in the mall, it's absolutely wonderful! I'll admit, i've only had one thing from here, but it was so good, i couldnt bring myself to try anything else. 

I always get the one item, spicy chicken with steamed rice. I knocked a star of because this combo comes with vegetables, but they seriously give you like 3 pieces of broccoli, and it's cold. What's really the point? Id prefer a little more veggies to balance out the meal a bit, but it's so much food as it is, I probably couldn't handle much more. 

That being said, Sorabol=yummy. If yu're in the area, stop at the mall food court and try your best to decide between Sorabol and Buckhorn...both quality "fast food" locations!
author: Sarah I.

description: Not the best Korean food I've had, but it's not bad for the $$$.  Each plate is around $8, and the portion is huge.  Their steamed broccoli is not good.  It's raw and sometimes tastes bitter.  Yep, bitter.  I usually get spicy bbq pork (Bulgogi).  It comes with clear noodle (chap-chae), rice, and broccoli.  The meat was not tender enough, but it was quite flavorful.  It's probably my favorite "fast food" in the area.
author: Jessica N.

description: It may not be authentic, but it's pretty damned good for mall fare.
author: Ziad E.

description: Good, inexpensive Korean barbeque. The barbeque Chicken, Beef and Short Rib (Kal bi) with noodles plate lunches are my favorites. I just wish they would give more veggies. Noodles are tasty and cheap too. There is a constant line here no matter what time you go, but they go pretty fast. Cash only. For those familiar wwith the Emeryville market place, this is the same restaurant.
author: Arlene C.

description: Oh, goddamn was that good:  rice noodles with cabbage, your choice of a dozen kinds of meat, broccoli, and kim chee, for less than $10 -- and the portion was so big I could barely finish it.  (Next time I need to bring a friend and split it.)  Spicy BBQ chicken is best, followed by the short ribs.  Avoid the spicy calamari.
author: Adam Z.

description: So the food here might not be authentic but its pretty delicious. I've only ever ordered the BBQ Chicken because its soooo tasty. As far as mall chain food goes I would say Sorabol is one of the best I've had. The price is kind of steep (about $10) but portions are huge so you can have leftovers later.
author: Angie B.

description: For mall food...I thought this place is probably better than other restaurants...I always like to get the BBQ beef/terriyaki chicken and the clear noodles! The portion is definitely big enough to eat for two meals!
author: JenJen W.

description:
Sorabol is a decent place to get Korean food if you are at the Westfield San Francisco. I always get the Kalbi with rice and Jap Chae. The food portions used to be bigger, a mountain of ribs over a bed of rice and a heap of Jap Chae. Now they seem to have skimped to only 3 strips of Kalbi, a scoop of rice and a blob of the Jap Chae. The flavor is pretty good.

If you are looking for Korean food and are at the Westfield SF, go here...its your only choice! HAHA!
author: Matt K.

description: This place is definitely not Brother's.  Where's my freshly cooked Korean BBQ with all of the side dishes?  But, for fast Korean close to work this is your place.  I wouldn't trust the Bim Bim Bap without the crock pot, but the hot pork bowl is tasty.  It comes with Chap Chae & Rice.
author: Dbear T.

description: I like it. It's not the best Korean food (I'd go to Brother's for that) but it's pretty good. They give you a crap load of food and the prices aren't terrible for SF. I always get the noodles with grilled chicken and beef short ribs. It's a pretty solid combination.
author: Mike C.

description:
I used to go to Sorabol Stonestown and I think their food are ok but not special especially the service is not that good, too. 
I went there around 8.00 PM which is a good time because the line is short and i didn't have to wait for a long time. I ended up trying Sorabol at the the Emporium because i was wandering the food court for 15 minutes and still couldn't decide what i wanted to eat for dinner. 

I looked at their food and was surprised that they have spicy calamari which i don't see in their other locations. I ordered the two combo plate which consists rice, clear noodle, grilled chicken, spicy calamari and greens. It all costs a bit over $9.00 with no drinks. I was full and satisfied with the big portion and went home happy.
author: sofie W.

description: I supper love this place! the food is so amazing, WoW! 10 bucks for lunch is a bit much, but the food is GREAT! I have eaten at all the places down stairs in the SF shopping center and this is BY FAR the best! the clear noodles are so yummy, i dont ever get the rice, i always get all noodles. The spicy meat is really spicy, non of that panda express "spicy" crap, you'll actualy taste the food hear, not just salt and soy sauce!
author: David P.

description: I usual hit up the Sorabol at Rincon but I happened to be near Westfield on Market at lunch time today. So, I thought I'd hit the food court. Coming down the escalator, I saw an Asian family with piles of noodles and beef short ribs and chicken on their plates. So, Sorabol it was.  I got in line and watched as the people in front of me got their orders piled high on their plate - generous portions. My turn. Tiny portions. My plate was about one third of all the other plates I saw.  I politely asked if they would put more meat on the plate. The server looked at me like I was crazy. I asked why all the people ahead of me had tons of food and my plate was barely filled. Then she tells me she can add more for another $2.75. What!?  Then I realized... I wasn't Asian!  All the filled plates were for Asians.  All non Asians got a fraction.  I'm white. So I get s**t.  The manager told the server to just go ahead and fill up my plate after over hearing me protest. I know Asians hook up other asains all the time - but this was way too obvious.  I thanked the manager, but told him to forget it.  I went to the Thai place next door and had great service and great food.  I'm not giving a dime to Sorrybowl...
author: Jason E.

description: can't say much about the bbq but i had the spicy seafood noodle soup. wow, it was really bad. mainly the broth had absolutely no flavor and the noodles were i don't even know how to describe it. bland, textureless, worse than instant noodles. avoid at all cost.
author: Jen S.

description: i am in love with korean bbq.  i've made it my own mission to perfect the korean bbq marinade and sorabol offers a very delicious short ribs.  as always, the serving size is pretty plentiful...rice, glass noodles, broccoli, and 4 pieces of short ribs.  i should try to save half for later and do some portion controlling, but who am i kidding...i eat it all!  oh, and you get a little side of kimchi...yum!
author: Marjie T.

description: an extra star for the free kimchi which i always make sure to  load up on and it's actually really good imo.  mainstream korean food which is fine by me considering how speedy and plentiful it is.  the roast chicken is decent as is the jap chae.  skip the bean curd and get the little mixed veggie bowl- mushrooms, sprouts, carrots etc.  wish there were more sorabols around!
author: Suzanne V.

description: cheap, good, and healthy.  nothing there is overly breaded and deep-fried, so i don't quite get the panda express analogy.  you see them cook the chicken on the grill in front of your eyes.  you can substitute all broccoli for rice and noodles to keep things healthy.  definitely my favorite in the food court.
author: Jesse C.

description: Eating here was a horrible experience.  I tried the bbq chicken, and it was so bad that I ended up walking away after 3 bites.  The chicken was dry, cold and tasteless, the brocoli was overcooked, the rice was the best thing on my plate even though it was cold also.  Service was awful ("What you want?").  I will eat somewhere else in the future.
author: Marijke D.

description: The amount of food you get at this place is amazing-- I got four pieces of salmon, two scoops of of rice (I told them to go light on the serving of rice) and tons of glass noodles and sprouts and a diet 7-up for $10.50. And this was for the 1 item entree order. Basically it is three times the servings of any of the Out the Door items. The food is pretty good and very satisfying. Oh yea, not that I care, but they don't use MSG either.
author: Mama L.

description: surprisingly tasty mall food when i'm looking to stay cheap.  love the little salted fish with plain rice, asian style, and the noodles are good too. lose 2 stars because 1) it still feels a little skanky eating in a mall, and 2) they're kinda mean but then i guess i should expect that from a food court?
author: yolanda f.

description: i love the glass noodles here! i wish i could just order a plate of that. and yes the portions are big! they can fill up two hungry people without feeling bloated. and only 8-9 dollars=) can get really busy during lunch time, but the lines move pretty fast so dont get discouraged!
author: christy w.

description: Sorabol was the most amazing discovery I made during WWDC this year.  I'd always known that the food court at the mall had a Korean BBQ place, but Sorabol took my expectations and blew them away.  MASSIVE quantities of kalbi, plus rice and japchae and broccoli for 9.71$?  We're talking a TON of meat.  I came here 3 days for lunch in one week, I was so in love with the place.  Thank god I don't live close to here, otherwise I'd literally be coming here every single day.  They even take credit card!
author: emilie k.

description: OMG, so I'm going to review this place because I LOVE IT! Me and my LL always go here or Panda Express even when there are so many other places to go in the city. It's just sometimes, you gotta go semi-fast food. The glass noodles at Sorabol -- the bomb! And the Kalbi -- wicked awesome! Need I say more?
author: Michelle R.

description: I love this place, what can I say?  The line can be long at times, but moves very quickly as long as there aren't any cell phone idiots in front of you who can't decide what they want.  The food is fresh and doesn't have time to sit and get stale.  I always order either the spicy barbeque chicken or the grilled chicken.  You get rice and clear noodles as well, but I always stick with the noodles.  Plus they give you some nice, crunchy green broccoli with a tasty light sauce.  You order potstickers individually, so I usually get 2-3.  With a soft drink I'm usually in the $10-1$12 range.  The service is friendly  and fast, they move you right along.  Steve, the manager, is a nice gent who recognizes if you're a regular, so he makes sure you get big portions and good deals.   I work nearby and go there 2-3 times a week.  I wish there was one in Lafayette, too!  If you're hungry and find yourself at Westfield, I recommend Sorabol very much.
author: Richard G. P.

description: I don't think this place serve real Korean food. All I can say is that their prices are reasonable.
author: Cathrina D.

description: totally decent korean food, considering it's a mall establishment. portions are huge - the veggie bowl is large enough to share with a friend. not the best korean food i've had, but if you want a quick fix and you're at the mall, it'll do.
author: Leesee A.
